<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Ethiopia</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Country in the Horn of Africa</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">This article is about the country. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Ethiopia_(disambiguation)" title="Ethiopia (disambiguation)">Ethiopia (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">This article contains several <a href="/wiki/Patronymic" title="Patronymic">patronymic</a> names rather than family names. These persons are addressed by their <a href="/wiki/Given_name" title="Given name">given name</a>, and not by their <a href="/wiki/Surname" title="Surname">surname</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>

class="infobox-data"><a href="/wiki/.et" title=".et">.et</a></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Ethiopia</b>, officially the <b>Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia</b>, is a <a href="/wiki/Landlocked_country" title="Landlocked country">landlocked country</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Horn_of_Africa" title="Horn of Africa">Horn of Africa</a>. It shares borders with <a href="/wiki/Eritrea" title="Eritrea">Eritrea</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Eritrea%E2%80%93Ethiopia_border" title="Eritrea–Ethiopia border">north</a>, <a href="/wiki/Djibouti" title="Djibouti">Djibouti</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Djibouti%E2%80%93Ethiopia_border" title="Djibouti–Ethiopia border">northeast</a>, <a href="/wiki/Somalia" title="Somalia">Somalia</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia%E2%80%93Somalia_border" title="Ethiopia–Somalia border">east and northeast</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kenya" title="Kenya">Kenya</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia%E2%80%93Kenya_border" title="Ethiopia–Kenya border">south</a>, <a href="/wiki/South_Sudan" title="South Sudan">South Sudan</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia%E2%80%93South_Sudan_border" title="Ethiopia–South Sudan border">west</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sudan" title="Sudan">Sudan</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia%E2%80%93Sudan_border" title="Ethiopia–Sudan border">northwest</a>. Ethiopia has a total area of 1,100,000 square kilometres (420,000 sq mi). As of 2022, it is home to around 113.5 million inhabitants, making it the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population" title="List of countries and dependencies by population">12th-most populous</a> country in the world and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_African_countries_by_population" title="List of African countries by population">2nd-most populous in Africa</a> after <a href="/wiki/Nigeria" title="Nigeria">Nigeria</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-csa2_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-csa2-15">[15]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP-16">[16]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-UN_WPP_2022_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-UN_WPP_2022-17">[17]</a></sup> The national capital and largest city, <a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa" title="Addis Ababa">Addis Ababa</a>, lies several kilometres west of the <a href="/wiki/East_African_Rift" title="East African Rift">East African Rift</a> that splits the country into the <a href="/wiki/African_Plate" title="African Plate">African</a> and <a href="/wiki/Somali_Plate" title="Somali Plate">Somali</a> tectonic plates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA2_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-CIA2-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Early_modern_human" title="Early modern human">Anatomically modern humans</a> emerged from modern-day Ethiopia and set out to the <a href="/wiki/Near_East" title="Near East">Near East</a> and elsewhere in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Paleolithic" title="Middle Paleolithic">Middle Paleolithic</a> period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-19"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-21"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> Southwestern Ethiopia has been proposed as a possible <a href="/wiki/Afroasiatic_homeland" title="Afroasiatic homeland">homeland of the Afroasiatic language family</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blench2006_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-Blench2006-24">[24]</a></sup> In 980 BCE, the Kingdom of <a href="/wiki/D%CA%BFmt" title="Dʿmt">D'mt</a> extended its realm over Eritrea and the northern region of Ethiopia, while the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Aksum" title="Kingdom of Aksum">Kingdom of Aksum</a> maintained a unified civilization in the region for 900 years. Christianity was embraced by the kingdom in 330,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> and Islam arrived by the <a href="/wiki/Migration_to_Abyssinia" title="Migration to Abyssinia">first Hijra</a> in 615.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> After the collapse of Aksum in 960, a variety of kingdoms, largely tribal confederations, existed in the land of Ethiopia. The <a href="/wiki/Zagwe_dynasty" title="Zagwe dynasty">Zagwe dynasty</a> ruled the north-central parts until being overthrown by <a href="/wiki/Yekuno_Amlak" title="Yekuno Amlak">Yekuno Amlak</a> in 1270, inaugurating the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Empire" title="Ethiopian Empire">Ethiopian Empire</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Solomonic_dynasty" title="Solomonic dynasty">Solomonic dynasty</a>, claimed descent from the biblical <a href="/wiki/Solomon" title="Solomon">Solomon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Queen_of_Sheba" title="Queen of Sheba">Queen of Sheba</a> under their son <a href="/wiki/Menelik_I" title="Menelik I">Menelik I</a>. By the 14th century, the empire grew in prestige through territorial expansion and fighting against adjacent territories; most notably, the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian%E2%80%93Adal_War" title="Ethiopian–Adal War">Ethiopian–Adal War</a> (1529–1543) contributed to fragmentation of the empire, which ultimately fell under a decentralization known as <i><a href="/wiki/Zemene_Mesafint" title="Zemene Mesafint">Zemene Mesafint</a></i> in mid-18th century. <a href="/wiki/Emperor_of_Ethiopia" title="Emperor of Ethiopia">Emperor</a> <a href="/wiki/Tewodros_II" title="Tewodros II">Tewodros II</a> ended <i>Zemene Mesafint</i> at the beginning of his reign in 1855, marking the reunification and modernization of Ethiopia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-27"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup>
</p><p>From 1878 onwards, Emperor <a href="/wiki/Menelik_II" title="Menelik II">Menelik II</a> launched a series of conquests known as <a href="/wiki/Menelik%27s_Expansions" title="Menelik's Expansions">Menelik's Expansions</a>, which resulted in the formation of current border of Ethiopia. Externally, during the late–19th-century, Ethiopia defended itself against foreign invasions, including from <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian%E2%80%93Egyptian_War" title="Ethiopian–Egyptian War">Egypt</a> and <a href="/wiki/First_Italo-Ethiopian_War" title="First Italo-Ethiopian War">Italy</a>; as a result, Ethiopia and <a href="/wiki/Liberia" title="Liberia">Liberia</a> preserved their sovereignty during the <a href="/wiki/Scramble_for_Africa" title="Scramble for Africa">Scramble for Africa</a>. In 1935, Ethiopia was occupied by <a href="/wiki/Fascist_Italy_(1922%E2%80%931943)" title="Fascist Italy (1922–1943)">Fascist Italy</a> and annexed with Italian-possessed <a href="/wiki/Italian_Eritrea" title="Italian Eritrea">Eritrea</a> and <a href="/wiki/Italian_Somaliland" title="Italian Somaliland">Somaliland</a>, later forming <a href="/wiki/Italian_East_Africa" title="Italian East Africa">Italian East Africa</a>. In 1941, during <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, it was <a href="/wiki/East_African_campaign_(World_War_II)" title="East African campaign (World War II)">occupied by the British Army</a>, and its full sovereignty was <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Ethiopian_Agreement#Negotiating_a_new_agreement" title="Anglo-Ethiopian Agreement">restored in 1944</a> after a period of <a href="/wiki/Occupied_Enemy_Territory_Administration_(Ethiopia)" title="Occupied Enemy Territory Administration (Ethiopia)">military administration</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Derg" title="Derg">Derg</a>, a Soviet-backed military junta, took power in 1974 after <a href="/wiki/1974_Ethiopian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1974 Ethiopian coup d'état">deposing</a> Emperor <a href="/wiki/Haile_Selassie" title="Haile Selassie">Haile Selassie</a> and the Solomonic dynasty, ruled the country nearly 17 years, initiating the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Civil_War" title="Ethiopian Civil War">Ethiopian Civil War</a>. Following the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_the_Derg" title="Fall of the Derg">dissolution of the Derg</a> in 1991, the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_People%27s_Revolutionary_Democratic_Front" title="Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front">Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front</a> (EPRDF) dominated the country with a <a href="/wiki/1995_Constitution_of_Ethiopia" title="1995 Constitution of Ethiopia">new constitution</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_federalism#Ethiopia" title="Ethnic federalism">ethnic-based federalism</a>. Since then, Ethiopia has suffered from prolonged and unsolved <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_discrimination_in_Ethiopia" title="Ethnic discrimination in Ethiopia">inter-ethnic clashes</a> and political instability marked by <a href="/wiki/Democratic_backsliding" title="Democratic backsliding">democratic backsliding</a>. From 2018, regional and ethnically based factions carried out armed attacks in <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_civil_conflict_(2018%E2%80%93present)" title="Ethiopian civil conflict (2018–present)">multiple ongoing wars throughout Ethiopia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC1120_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC1120-28">[28]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ethiopia is a <a href="/wiki/Multinational_state" title="Multinational state">multi-ethnic state</a> with over 80 different <a href="/wiki/List_of_ethnic_groups_in_Ethiopia" title="List of ethnic groups in Ethiopia">ethnic groups</a>. <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> is the most widely professed faith in the country, with significant minorities of the adherents of <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> and a small percentage to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Traditional_African_religion" title="Traditional African religion">traditional faiths</a>. This <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_state" title="Sovereign state">sovereign state</a> is a founding member of the UN, the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_24" title="Group of 24">Group of 24</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_77" title="Group of 77">Group of 77</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_African_Unity" title="Organisation of African Unity">Organisation of African Unity</a>. Addis Ababa is the headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/African_Union" title="African Union">African Union</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pan_African_Chamber_of_Commerce_and_Industry" title="Pan African Chamber of Commerce and Industry">Pan African Chamber of Commerce and Industry</a>, the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Economic_Commission_for_Africa" title="United Nations Economic Commission for Africa">United Nations Economic Commission for Africa</a>, the <a href="/wiki/African_Standby_Force" title="African Standby Force">African Standby Force</a> and many of the global <a href="/wiki/Non-governmental_organization" title="Non-governmental organization">non-governmental organizations</a> focused on Africa. Ethiopia is considered an <a href="/wiki/Emerging_power" title="Emerging power">emerging power</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Developing_country" title="Developing country">developing country</a>, having the <a href="/wiki/List_of_African_countries_by_GDP_growth" title="List of African countries by GDP growth">fastest economic growth</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Sub-Saharan Africa">Sub-Saharan African</a> countries because of <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">foreign direct investment</a> in expansion of agricultural and manufacturing industries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> However, in terms of <a href="/wiki/Per_capita_income" title="Per capita income">per capita income</a> and the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> the country is regarded as poor with high rates of <a href="/wiki/Poverty_in_Ethiopia" title="Poverty in Ethiopia">poverty</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> poor respect for <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Ethiopia" title="Human rights in Ethiopia">human rights</a>, and a literacy rate of only 49%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Ethiopia" title="Agriculture in Ethiopia">Agriculture</a> is the largest economic sector in Ethiopia, accounting for 36% of the country's <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">gross domestic product</a> as of 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-35"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup>
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Aethiopia" title="Aethiopia">Aethiopia</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a> name <a href="/wiki/Aethiopia" title="Aethiopia">Αἰθιοπία</a> (from <span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text"><span lang="grc">Αἰθίοψ</span></span>, <i>Aithiops</i>, "an Ethiopian") is a compound word, derived from the two Greek words, from <span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text"><span lang="grc">αἴθω</span></span> + <span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text"><span lang="grc">ὤψ</span></span> (<i>aithō</i> "I burn" + <i>ōps</i> "face"). According to the <a href="/wiki/A_Greek%E2%80%93English_Lexicon" title="A Greek–English Lexicon">Liddell-Scott Jones Greek-English Lexicon</a>, the designation properly translates as <i>burnt-face</i> in noun form and <i>red-brown</i> in adjectival form.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> The historian <a href="/wiki/Herodotus" title="Herodotus">Herodotus</a> used the appellation to denote those parts of Africa south of the <a href="/wiki/Sahara" title="Sahara">Sahara</a> that were then known within the <a href="/wiki/Ecumene" title="Ecumene">Ecumene</a> (habitable world).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Herodotus1_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-Herodotus1-38">[38]</a></sup> Since the Greeks understood the term as "dark-faced", they divided the Ethiopians into two, those in Africa and those to the east from eastern Turkey to India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-39"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> This Greek name was borrowed into <a href="/wiki/Amharic" title="Amharic">Amharic</a> as ኢትዮጵያ, <i>ʾĪtyōṗṗyā</i>.
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">Greco</a>-<a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman</a> epigraphs, <i>Aethiopia</i> was a specific toponym for ancient <a href="/wiki/Nubia" title="Nubia">Nubia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hatke_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hatke-40">[40]</a></sup> At least as early as c. 850,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-41"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> the name <i>Aethiopia</i> also occurs in many translations of the <a href="/wiki/Old_Testament" title="Old Testament">Old Testament</a> in allusion to Nubia. The ancient <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_language" title="Hebrew language">Hebrew</a> texts identify Nubia instead as <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Kush" title="Kingdom of Kush">Kush</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> However, in the <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a>, the Greek term Aithiops does occur, referring to a servant of the <a href="/wiki/Kandake" title="Kandake">Kandake</a>, the queen of Kush.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the Hellenic and biblical traditions, the <a href="/wiki/Monumentum_Adulitanum" title="Monumentum Adulitanum">Monumentum Adulitanum</a>, a 3rd-century inscription belonging to the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Aksum" title="Kingdom of Aksum">Aksumite Empire</a>, indicates that Aksum's ruler governed an area which was flanked to the west by the territory of Ethiopia and Sasu. The Aksumite King <a href="/wiki/Ezana_of_Axum" title="Ezana of Axum">Ezana</a> eventually conquered Nubia the following century, and the Aksumites thereafter appropriated the designation "Ethiopians" for their own kingdom. In the <a href="/wiki/Ge%CA%BDez" title="Geʽez">Ge'ez</a> version of the Ezana inscription, Aἰθίοπες is equated with the unvocalized <i>Ḥbšt</i> and <i>Ḥbśt</i> (Ḥabashat), and denotes for the first time the highland inhabitants of Aksum. This new <a href="/wiki/Demonym" title="Demonym">demonym</a> was subsequently rendered as <i>ḥbs</i> ('Aḥbāsh) in <a href="/wiki/Sabaean_language" title="Sabaean language">Sabaic</a> and as <i>Ḥabasha</i> in <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hatke_40-1"><a href="#cite_note-Hatke-40">[40]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 15th-century Ge'ez <i><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Axum" title="Book of Axum">Book of Axum</a></i>, the name is ascribed to a legendary individual called <i>Ityopp'is</i>. He was an extra-biblical son of <a href="/wiki/Cush_(Bible)" title="Cush (Bible)">Cush, son of Ham</a>, said to have founded the city of <a href="/wiki/Axum" title="Axum">Axum</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Agrvt_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-Agrvt-44">[44]</a></sup>
</p><p>In English, and generally outside of Ethiopia, the country was historically known as Abyssinia. This toponym was derived from the Latinized form of the ancient <i>Habash</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Ethiopia" title="History of Ethiopia">History of Ethiopia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_historiography" title="Ethiopian historiography">Ethiopian historiography</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_Ethiopia" title="Prehistoric Ethiopia">Prehistoric Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Homo_Sapiens_Idaltu.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Homo_Sapiens_Idaltu.JPG/220px-Homo_Sapiens_Idaltu.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Homo_Sapiens_Idaltu.JPG/330px-Homo_Sapiens_Idaltu.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Homo_Sapiens_Idaltu.JPG/440px-Homo_Sapiens_Idaltu.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Homo_Sapiens_Idaltu.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <i><a href="/wiki/Herto_Man" title="Herto Man">Homo sapiens idaltu</a></i> hominid skull</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kibish_formation_area_of_archaeology_dig.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Kibish_formation_area_of_archaeology_dig.jpg/220px-Kibish_formation_area_of_archaeology_dig.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Kibish_formation_area_of_archaeology_dig.jpg/330px-Kibish_formation_area_of_archaeology_dig.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Kibish_formation_area_of_archaeology_dig.jpg/440px-Kibish_formation_area_of_archaeology_dig.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kibish_formation_area_of_archaeology_dig.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Kibish_River" title="Kibish River">Kibish</a> has the site of oldest fossil of human bones believed to be 195,000 years old along with <a href="/wiki/Omo_River" title="Omo River">Omo River</a>. The skull remains are 40,000 older than in Herto, Ethiopia</div></div></div>
<p>Several important finds have propelled Ethiopia and the surrounding region to the forefront of <a href="/wiki/Paleontology" title="Paleontology">palaeontology</a>. The oldest <a href="/wiki/Hominidae" title="Hominidae">hominid</a> discovered to date in Ethiopia is the 4.2 million-year-old <i><a href="/wiki/Ardipithecus" title="Ardipithecus">Ardipithicus ramidus</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Ardi" title="Ardi">Ardi</a>) found by <a href="/wiki/Tim_D._White" title="Tim D. White">Tim D. White</a> in 1994.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-OldestHuman_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-OldestHuman-46">[46]</a></sup> The most well-known hominid discovery is <i><a href="/wiki/Australopithecus_afarensis" title="Australopithecus afarensis">Australopithecus afarensis</a></i> (<a href="/wiki/Lucy_(Australopithecus)" title="Lucy (Australopithecus)">Lucy</a>). Known locally as <i>Dinkinesh</i>, the specimen was found in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Awash_Valley" title="Awash Valley">Awash Valley</a> of <a href="/wiki/Afar_Region" title="Afar Region">Afar Region</a> in 1974 by <a href="/wiki/Donald_Johanson" title="Donald Johanson">Donald Johanson</a>, and is one of the most complete and best preserved adult <a href="/wiki/Australopithecus" title="Australopithecus">Australopithecine</a> fossils ever uncovered. Lucy's taxonomic name refers to the region where the discovery was made. This hominid is estimated to have lived 3.2 million years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-47"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dinkinesh_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dinkinesh-48">[48]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-iho1_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-iho1-49">[49]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ethiopia is also considered one of the earliest sites of the emergence of <a href="/wiki/Early_modern_human" title="Early modern human">anatomically modern humans</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Human" title="Human">Homo sapiens</a></i>. The oldest of these local fossil finds, the <a href="/wiki/Omo_remains" title="Omo remains">Omo remains</a>, were excavated in the southwestern <a href="/wiki/Omo_Kibish_Formation" title="Omo Kibish Formation">Omo Kibish</a> area and have been dated to the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Paleolithic" title="Middle Paleolithic">Middle Paleolithic</a>, around 200,000 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mcdougall2005_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mcdougall2005-50">[50]</a></sup> Additionally, skeletons of <i><a href="/wiki/Herto_Man" title="Herto Man">Homo sapiens idaltu</a></i> were found at a site in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Awash" title="Middle Awash">Middle Awash</a> valley. Dated to approximately 160,000 years ago, they may represent an extinct subspecies of <i>Homo sapiens</i>, or the immediate ancestors of anatomically modern humans.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> Archaic <i>Homo sapiens</i> fossils excavated at the <a href="/wiki/Jebel_Irhoud" title="Jebel Irhoud">Jebel Irhoud</a> site in Morocco have since been dated to an earlier period, about 300,000 years ago,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> while Omo-Kibish I (Omo I) from southern Ethiopia is the oldest anatomically modern Homo sapiens skeleton currently known (196 ± 5 ka).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to some linguists, the first <a href="/wiki/Afroasiatic_languages" title="Afroasiatic languages">Afroasiatic</a>-speaking populations arrived in the region during the ensuing <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> era from the family's proposed <a href="/wiki/Afroasiatic_homeland" title="Afroasiatic homeland">urheimat</a> ("original homeland") in the <a href="/wiki/Nile" title="Nile">Nile Valley</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Zarins_54-0"><a href="#cite_note-Zarins-54">[54]</a></sup> or the <a href="/wiki/Near_East" title="Near East">Near East</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Aane_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-Aane-55">[55]</a></sup> The majority of scholars today propose that the Afroasiatic family developed in northeast Africa because of the higher diversity of lineages in that region, a telltale sign of linguistic origin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Blench143144_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-Blench143144-56">[56]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-57"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2019, archaeologists discovered a 30,000-year-old <a href="/wiki/Middle_Stone_Age" title="Middle Stone Age">Middle Stone Age</a> rock shelter at the <a href="/wiki/Fincha_Habera,_Ethiopia" title="Fincha Habera, Ethiopia">Fincha Habera</a> site in <a href="/wiki/Bale_Mountains" title="Bale Mountains">Bale Mountains</a> at an elevation of 3,469 metres above sea level. At this high altitude humans are susceptible both to <a href="/wiki/Hypoxemia#Environmental_oxygen" title="Hypoxemia">hypoxia</a> and to extreme weather. According to a study published in the journal <i><a href="/wiki/Science_(journal)" title="Science (journal)">Science</a></i>, this dwelling is proof of the earliest permanent human occupation at high altitude yet discovered. Thousands of animal bones, hundreds of stone tools, and ancient fireplaces were discovered, revealing a diet that featured giant <a href="/wiki/Spalacidae" title="Spalacidae">mole rats</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-59"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-60"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-62"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-65"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup>
</p><p>Evidence of some of the earliest known stone-tipped projectile weapons (a characteristic tool of <i>Homo sapiens</i>), the stone tips of javelins or throwing spears, were discovered in 2013 at the Ethiopian site of <a href="/wiki/Gademotta" title="Gademotta">Gademotta</a>, which date to around 279,000 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SahlePLOS1_66-0"><a href="#cite_note-SahlePLOS1-66">[66]</a></sup> In 2019, additional Middle Stone Age projectile weapons were found at Aduma, dated 100,000–80,000 years ago, in the form of points considered likely to belong to darts delivered by spear throwers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sahle_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sahle-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Antiquity">Antiquity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/D%CA%BFmt" title="Dʿmt">Dʿmt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Aksum" title="Kingdom of Aksum">Kingdom of Aksum</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ET_Axum_asv2018-01_img37_Stelae_Park.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4597" data-file-width="3678" decoding="async" height="212" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/ET_Axum_asv2018-01_img37_Stelae_Park.jpg/170px-ET_Axum_asv2018-01_img37_Stelae_Park.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/ET_Axum_asv2018-01_img37_Stelae_Park.jpg/255px-ET_Axum_asv2018-01_img37_Stelae_Park.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/ET_Axum_asv2018-01_img37_Stelae_Park.jpg/340px-ET_Axum_asv2018-01_img37_Stelae_Park.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ET_Axum_asv2018-01_img37_Stelae_Park.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Obelisk_of_Axum" title="Obelisk of Axum">Obelisk of Axum</a> dates from the 4th century</div></div></div>
<p>In 980 BCE, <a href="/wiki/D%CA%BFmt" title="Dʿmt">Dʿmt</a> was established in present-day <a href="/wiki/Eritrea" title="Eritrea">Eritrea</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Tigray_Region" title="Tigray Region">Tigray Region</a> of Ethiopia. This polity's capital was located at <a href="/wiki/Yeha" title="Yeha">Yeha</a> in what is now northern Ethiopia. Most modern historians consider this civilization to be a native Ethiopian one, although in earlier times many suggested it was <a href="/wiki/Sabaeans" title="Sabaeans">Sabaean</a>-influenced because of the latter's hegemony of the <a href="/wiki/Red_Sea" title="Red Sea">Red Sea</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Munro-Hay57_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-Munro-Hay57-68">[68]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other scholars regard Dʿmt as the result of a union of Afroasiatic-speaking cultures of the Cushitic and Semitic branches; namely, local <a href="/wiki/Agaw_people" title="Agaw people">Agaw peoples</a> and Sabaeans from Southern Arabia. However, <a href="/wiki/Ge%CA%BDez" title="Geʽez">Ge'ez</a>, the ancient Semitic language of Ethiopia, is thought to have developed independently from the <a href="/wiki/Sabaean_language" title="Sabaean language">Sabaean language</a>. As early as 2000 BCE, other Semitic speakers were living in Ethiopia and Eritrea where Ge'ez developed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup> Sabaean influence is now thought to have been minor, limited to a few localities, and disappearing after a few decades or a century. It may have been a trading or military colony in alliance with the Ethiopian civilization of Dʿmt or some other proto-Axumite state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Munro-Hay57_68-1"><a href="#cite_note-Munro-Hay57-68">[68]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:KingEndybisEthiopia227-235CE.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="652" data-file-width="1283" decoding="async" height="112" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/KingEndybisEthiopia227-235CE.jpg/220px-KingEndybisEthiopia227-235CE.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/KingEndybisEthiopia227-235CE.jpg/330px-KingEndybisEthiopia227-235CE.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/KingEndybisEthiopia227-235CE.jpg/440px-KingEndybisEthiopia227-235CE.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:KingEndybisEthiopia227-235CE.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Aksumite_currency" title="Aksumite currency">Aksumite currency</a> of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Axumite_kings" title="Axumite kings">Aksumite king</a> called <a href="/wiki/Endubis" title="Endubis">Endubis</a>, 227–35, at the <a href="/wiki/British_Museum" title="British Museum">British Museum</a>. The inscriptions in <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">Ancient Greek</a> read "ΑΧΩΜΙΤΩ ΒΑΣΙΛΕΥΣ" ("King of Axum") and "ΕΝΔΥΒΙΣ ΒΑΣΙΛΕΥΣ" ("King Endubis"), the Greek language was the <a href="/wiki/Lingua_franca" title="Lingua franca">lingua franca</a> by that time so its use in coins simplified foreign trade.</div></div></div>
<p>After the fall of Dʿmt during the 4th century BCE, the Ethiopian plateau came to be dominated by smaller successor kingdoms. In the 1st century CE, the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Aksum" title="Kingdom of Aksum">Kingdom of Aksum</a> emerged in what is now Tigray Region and Eritrea. According to the medieval <i><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Axum" title="Book of Axum">Book of Axum</a></i>, the kingdom's first capital, Mazaber, was built by Itiyopis, son of Cush.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Agrvt_44-1"><a href="#cite_note-Agrvt-44">[44]</a></sup> Aksum would later at times extend its rule into Yemen on the other side of the Red Sea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> The Persian prophet <a href="/wiki/Mani_(prophet)" title="Mani (prophet)">Mani</a> listed Axum with Rome, Persia, and China as one of the four great powers of his era, during the 3rd century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup> It is also believed that there was a connection between Egyptian and Ethiopian churches. There is diminutive evidence that the Aksumites were associated with the <a href="/wiki/Queen_of_Sheba" title="Queen of Sheba">Queen of Sheba</a>, via their royal inscription.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:5_73-0"><a href="#cite_note-:5-73">[73]</a></sup>
</p><p>Around 316 CE, <a href="/wiki/Frumentius" title="Frumentius">Frumentius</a> and his brother Edesius from <a href="/wiki/Tyre,_Lebanon" title="Tyre, Lebanon">Tyre</a> accompanied their uncle on a voyage to Ethiopia. When the vessel stopped at a Red Sea port, the natives killed all the travellers except the two brothers, who were taken to the court as <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_Ethiopia" title="Slavery in Ethiopia">slaves</a>. They were given positions of trust by the monarch, and they converted members of the royal court to Christianity. Frumentius became the first bishop of Aksum.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-isbn0-313-32273-2_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-isbn0-313-32273-2-74">[74]</a></sup> A coin dated to 324 shows that Ethiopia was the second country to officially adopt Christianity (after Armenia did so in 301), although the religion may have been at first confined to court circles; it was the first major power to do so. The Aksumites were accustomed to the Greco-Roman sphere of influence, but embarked on significant cultural ties and trade connections between the <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a> and the Roman Empire via the <a href="/wiki/Silk_Road" title="Silk Road">Silk Road</a>, primarily exporting <a href="/wiki/Ivory_trade" title="Ivory trade">ivory</a>, tortoise shell, gold and emeralds, and importing silk and spices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:5_73-1"><a href="#cite_note-:5-73">[73]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-britishmuseum.org_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-britishmuseum.org-75">[75]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Daily_Life_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-Daily_Life-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Middle_Ages">Middle Ages</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia_in_the_Middle_Ages" title="Ethiopia in the Middle Ages">Ethiopia in the Middle Ages</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Kingdom_of_Aksum.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="20000" data-file-width="17877" decoding="async" height="246" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/The_Kingdom_of_Aksum.png/220px-The_Kingdom_of_Aksum.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/The_Kingdom_of_Aksum.png/330px-The_Kingdom_of_Aksum.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/The_Kingdom_of_Aksum.png/440px-The_Kingdom_of_Aksum.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Kingdom_of_Aksum.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Aksum" title="Kingdom of Aksum">Kingdom of Aksum</a> at its peak in the 6th century</div></div></div>
<p>The kingdom adopted the name "Ethiopia" during the reign of <a href="/wiki/Ezana_of_Axum" title="Ezana of Axum">Ezana</a> in the 4th century. After the conquest of <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Kush" title="Kingdom of Kush">Kingdom of Kush</a> in 330, the Aksumite territory reached its peak between the 5th and 6th centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Munro-Hay57_68-2"><a href="#cite_note-Munro-Hay57-68">[68]</a></sup> This period was interrupted by several incursions into the South Arabian protectorate, including <a href="/wiki/Jews" title="Jews">Jewish</a> <a href="/wiki/Dhu_Nuwas" title="Dhu Nuwas">Dhu Nuwas</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Himyarite_Kingdom" title="Himyarite Kingdom">Himyarite Kingdom</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Aksumite%E2%80%93Persian_wars" title="Aksumite–Persian wars">Aksumite–Persian wars</a>. In 575, the Aksumites <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_reconquest_of_Yemen" title="Sasanian reconquest of Yemen">besieged and retook Sana'a</a> following the assassination of its governor <a href="/wiki/Sayf_ibn_Dhi_Yazan" title="Sayf ibn Dhi Yazan">Sayf ibn Dhī Yazan</a>. The port city of <a href="/wiki/Adulis" title="Adulis">Adulis</a> was plundered by Arab Muslims in the 8th century; along with irrevocable <a href="/wiki/Land_degradation" title="Land degradation">land degradation</a>, claimed <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Climate_change_(general_concept)" title="Climate change (general concept)">climate change</a> and sporadic rainfall precipitation from 730 to 760,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-77"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> the kingdom likely said to decline its power and important trade route, and Red Sea was left to the <a href="/wiki/Rashidun_Caliphate" title="Rashidun Caliphate">Rashidun Caliphate</a> in 646.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Munro-Hay57_68-3"><a href="#cite_note-Munro-Hay57-68">[68]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:12_78-0"><a href="#cite_note-:12-78">[78]</a></sup>
</p><p>Aksum came to an end in 960 when <a href="/wiki/Gudit" title="Gudit">Queen Gudit</a> defeated the last king of Aksum. Gudit's reign, which lasted for 40 years, aimed to abolish Christianity (a religion first accepted by King Ezana of the Axumite dynasty) by burning down churches and crucifying people who remained faithful to the Orthodox Tewahedo Church, which at the time was considered as the religion of the state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> Gudit tried to force many people to change their religion and destroyed much historical heritage of the Axumite dynasty, earning her the epithet of Yodit Gudit (in <a href="/wiki/Amharic" title="Amharic">Amharic</a>: ዮዲት ጉዲት a play on words approximating to Judith the Evil One). Gudit's devastation caused the remnant of the Aksumite population to shift into the southern region and establish the <a href="/wiki/Zagwe_dynasty" title="Zagwe dynasty">Zagwe dynasty</a>, changing its capital to <a href="/wiki/Lalibela" title="Lalibela">Lalibela</a>. The dynasty was ruled by ethnic <a href="/wiki/Agaw_people" title="Agaw people">Agaw</a> from circa 912, although most native sources indicate 1137 when its founder <a href="/wiki/Mara_Takla_Haymanot" title="Mara Takla Haymanot">Mara Takla Haymanot</a> overthrew the last Aksumite <a href="/wiki/List_of_kings_of_Axum" title="List of kings of Axum">king</a> <a href="/wiki/Dil_Na%27od" title="Dil Na'od">Dil Na'od</a> and married his daughter. The Zagwe dynasty was known for the revival of Christianity, and by the 13th century Christianity reached the Shewan region.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Yekuno_Amlak_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="709" data-file-width="449" decoding="async" height="237" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Yekuno_Amlak_%28cropped%29.jpg/150px-Yekuno_Amlak_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Yekuno_Amlak_%28cropped%29.jpg/225px-Yekuno_Amlak_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Yekuno_Amlak_%28cropped%29.jpg/300px-Yekuno_Amlak_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Yekuno_Amlak_(cropped).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Emperor <a href="/wiki/Yekuno_Amlak" title="Yekuno Amlak">Yekuno Amlak</a> portrait allegedly from the 18th century</div></div></div>
<p>Zagwe's rule ended when an <a href="/wiki/Amhara_people" title="Amhara people">Amhara</a> noble man <a href="/wiki/Yekuno_Amlak" title="Yekuno Amlak">Yekuno Amlak</a> revolted against King <a href="/wiki/Yetbarak" title="Yetbarak">Yetbarak</a> and established the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Empire" title="Ethiopian Empire">Ethiopian Empire</a> (known by exonym "Abyssinia"). He inaugurated the <a href="/wiki/Solomonic_dynasty" title="Solomonic dynasty">Solomonic dynasty</a> that supposedly traced to the biblical <a href="/wiki/Solomon" title="Solomon">Solomon</a> and <a href="/wiki/Queen_of_Sheba" title="Queen of Sheba">Queen of Sheba</a>, a claim that <a href="/wiki/Menelik_I" title="Menelik I">Menelik I</a> was their firstborn inaugurated the dynasty and the first <a href="/wiki/Emperor_of_Ethiopia" title="Emperor of Ethiopia">Emperor of Ethiopia</a> in the 10th century BCE. According to the medieval Ethiopian chronicle <i><a href="/wiki/Kebra_Nagast" title="Kebra Nagast">Kebra Nagast</a></i>, which was translated to Ge'ez in 1321, his name was <i>Bäynä Ləḥkəm</i> (from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arabic_language" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span dir="rtl" lang="ar">ابن الحكيم</span>, <span title="American Library Association – Library of Congress transliteration"><i lang="ar-Latn">Ibn Al-Hakim</i></span>, "Son of the Wise"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup>).
</p><p>In the early 15th century, Ethiopia sought to make diplomatic contact with European kingdoms for the first time since the Aksumite era. A letter from <a href="/wiki/Henry_IV_of_England" title="Henry IV of England">Henry IV of England</a> to the Ethiopian emperor survives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup> In 1428, <a href="/wiki/Yeshaq_I" title="Yeshaq I">Yeshaq I</a> sent two emissaries to <a href="/wiki/Alfonso_V_of_Aragon" title="Alfonso V of Aragon">Alfonso V of Aragon</a>, who sent his own emissaries that failed to complete the return trip home to <a href="/wiki/Aragon" title="Aragon">Aragon</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> The first continuous relations Europeans began in 1508 with Portugal under <a href="/wiki/Dawit_II" title="Dawit II">Dawit II</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Abyssinian.E2.80.93Adal_War_.281529.E2.80.931543.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Abyssinian–Adal_War_(1529–1543)">Abyssinian–Adal War (1529–1543)</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian%E2%80%93Adal_War" title="Ethiopian–Adal War">Ethiopian–Adal War</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:YagbeaSionBattlingAdaSultan.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1524" data-file-width="2379" decoding="async" height="141" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/YagbeaSionBattlingAdaSultan.JPG/220px-YagbeaSionBattlingAdaSultan.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/YagbeaSionBattlingAdaSultan.JPG/330px-YagbeaSionBattlingAdaSultan.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/YagbeaSionBattlingAdaSultan.JPG/440px-YagbeaSionBattlingAdaSultan.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:YagbeaSionBattlingAdaSultan.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Sultan of Adal (right) and his troops battling Emperor <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yagbea-Sion" title="Yagbea-Sion">Yagbea-Sion</a> and his men.</div></div></div>
<p>The Ethiopian Empire embarked on territorial expansion starting with <a href="/wiki/Amda_Seyon_I" title="Amda Seyon I">Amda Seyon I</a>, who conquered the first Muslim state in the region, <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Ifat" title="Sultanate of Ifat">Ifat Sultanate</a>, in the 14th century after seizing the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Damot" title="Kingdom of Damot">Kingdom of Damot</a> around 1317, and expansion efforts were sustained by Emperor <a href="/wiki/Zara_Yaqob" title="Zara Yaqob">Zara Yaqob</a> who conquered <a href="/wiki/Massawa" title="Massawa">Massawa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dahlak_Archipelago" title="Dahlak Archipelago">Dahlak Archipelago</a> around 1465.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3b_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-:3b-86">[86]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEConnelKillion2011160_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEConnelKillion2011160-87">[87]</a></sup> Ifat's successor, the <a href="/wiki/Adal_Sultanate" title="Adal Sultanate">Adal Sultanate</a>, emerged in 1415 with its capital at Zelia, situated in the present-day Somaliland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Cristofano_dell%E2%80%99Altissimo,_Portrait_of_Lebn%C3%A4-Dengel._c._1552-1568.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1327" data-file-width="1027" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Cristofano_dell%E2%80%99Altissimo%2C_Portrait_of_Lebn%C3%A4-Dengel._c._1552-1568.jpg/170px-Cristofano_dell%E2%80%99Altissimo%2C_Portrait_of_Lebn%C3%A4-Dengel._c._1552-1568.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Cristofano_dell%E2%80%99Altissimo%2C_Portrait_of_Lebn%C3%A4-Dengel._c._1552-1568.jpg/255px-Cristofano_dell%E2%80%99Altissimo%2C_Portrait_of_Lebn%C3%A4-Dengel._c._1552-1568.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Cristofano_dell%E2%80%99Altissimo%2C_Portrait_of_Lebn%C3%A4-Dengel._c._1552-1568.jpg/340px-Cristofano_dell%E2%80%99Altissimo%2C_Portrait_of_Lebn%C3%A4-Dengel._c._1552-1568.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Cristofano_dell%E2%80%99Altissimo,_Portrait_of_Lebn%C3%A4-Dengel._c._1552-1568.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Emperor_of_Ethiopia" title="Emperor of Ethiopia">Emperor</a> <a href="/wiki/Dawit_II" title="Dawit II">Dawit II</a> (Lebna Dengel) contemporary portrait by <a href="/wiki/Cristofano_dell%27Altissimo" title="Cristofano dell'Altissimo">Cristofano dell'Altissimo</a></div></div></div>
<p>The Adals, supported by <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Turks" title="Ottoman Turks">Ottoman Turks</a>, initially tried to encroach the Ethiopian Empire under <a href="/wiki/Ahmad_ibn_Ibrahim_al-Ghazi" title="Ahmad ibn Ibrahim al-Ghazi">Imam Ahmad ibn Ibrahim al-Ghazi</a> in 1529, launching the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian%E2%80%93Adal_War" title="Ethiopian–Adal War">Ethiopian–Adal War</a>. After several campaigns, Al-Ghazi overwhelmed the Ethiopian troops at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Amba_Sel" title="Battle of Amba Sel">Battle of Amba Sel</a> in 1531. <a href="/wiki/Crist%C3%B3v%C3%A3o_da_Gama" title="Cristóvão da Gama">Cristóvão da Gama</a> played a prominent role in the war, helping the Ethiopian Empire with 400 musketeers at <a href="/wiki/Massawa" title="Massawa">Massawa</a>. His vital efforts eventually led to his death at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Wofla" title="Battle of Wofla">Battle of Wofla</a> in 1542. In 1543, the Abyssinian troops led by Emperor <a href="/wiki/Gelawdewos" title="Gelawdewos">Gelawdewos</a> decisively defeated the Adal forces at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Wayna_Daga" title="Battle of Wayna Daga">Battle of Wayna Daga</a>; the Imam was fatally wounded, where tradition states that Ahmad was wounded by a Portuguese musketeer who had charged alone into the Muslim lines and died. The wounded Imam was then chased and beheaded by an Ethiopian cavalry commander, named <i>Azmach</i> Calite. Upon learning of his death, the Adal troops immediately withdrew the area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup>
</p><p>Gelawdewos was beheaded at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Fatagar" title="Battle of Fatagar">Battle of Fatagar</a> in 1559.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> In response, Abyssinian Ras Hamalmal sacked the Adal capital of <a href="/wiki/Harar" title="Harar">Harar</a> and killed the Sultan <a href="/wiki/Barakat_ibn_Umar_Din" title="Barakat ibn Umar Din">Barakat ibn Umar Din</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-93"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup> These series of conflicts paved the way for 16th-century <a href="/wiki/Oromo_migrations" title="Oromo migrations">Oromo migrations</a> to the northern highlands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Oromo_migrations_.2816th_century.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Oromo_migrations_(16th_century)">Oromo migrations (16th century)</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Oromo_migrations" title="Oromo migrations">Oromo migrations</a></div>
<p>By the 16th century, an influx of migration by ethnic <a href="/wiki/Oromo_people" title="Oromo people">Oromo</a> into northern parts of the region fragmented the empire's power, referred to as the "Great Oromo Expansions." Embarking from present-day <a href="/wiki/Guji_Zone" title="Guji Zone">Guji</a> and <a href="/wiki/Borena_Zone" title="Borena Zone">Borena Zone</a>, the Oromos were largely motivated by several folkloric conceptions—beginning with <i>Moggaasaa</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> and <i>Liqimssa</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-96"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup>—many of whom related to their raids. Early expansion was marked by rapid raids, as the raiders captured most cattle and booty and then returned to their homeland. This technique persisted until <i>gada</i> of Meslé.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPankhurst1997301_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPankhurst1997301-97">[97]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:8_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-:8-98">[98]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Bahrey" title="Bahrey">Abba Bahrey</a>, the earliest expansion occurred under Emperor Dawit II (<i>luba</i> Melbah), when they encroached to <a href="/wiki/Bale_Province,_Ethiopia" title="Bale Province, Ethiopia">Bale</a> before invading Adal Sultanate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Reference_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-Reference-99">[99]</a></sup>
</p><p>Emperor <a href="/wiki/Sarsa_Dengel" title="Sarsa Dengel">Sarsa Dengel</a> unsuccessfully attempted to suppress the invasion in the south after they had taken Wej in 1572.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPankhurst1997287_100-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPankhurst1997287-100">[100]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Jesuit_influence_.281555.E2.80.931632.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Jesuit_influence_(1555–1632)">Jesuit influence (1555–1632)</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Susenyos_Wellcome_L0031387_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2406" data-file-width="1973" decoding="async" height="183" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Susenyos_Wellcome_L0031387_%28cropped%29.jpg/150px-Susenyos_Wellcome_L0031387_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Susenyos_Wellcome_L0031387_%28cropped%29.jpg/225px-Susenyos_Wellcome_L0031387_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Susenyos_Wellcome_L0031387_%28cropped%29.jpg/300px-Susenyos_Wellcome_L0031387_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Susenyos_Wellcome_L0031387_(cropped).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Emperor <a href="/wiki/Susenyos_I" title="Susenyos I">Susenyos I</a> was the first emperor converted to Roman Catholic in 1622, stressing the populace attitude of Orthodox Tewahedo Christianity</div></div></div>
<p>Ethiopia saw major diplomatic contact with Portugal from the 17th century, mainly related to religion. Beginning in 1555,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup> the Portuguese Jesuits attempted to develop Roman Catholicism as the state religion. After several failures, they sent several missionaries in 1603, including the most influential Spanish Jesuit <a href="/wiki/Pedro_P%C3%A1ez" title="Pedro Páez">Pedro Paez</a>. Paez's enthusiastic relation had huge favorable effects on the political sphere. The Jesuits, including <a href="/wiki/Manuel_de_Almeida" title="Manuel de Almeida">Manoel de Almeida</a>, <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Manoel_Barradas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Manoel Barradas (page does not exist)">Manoel Barradas</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jer%C3%B3nimo_Lobo" title="Jerónimo Lobo">Jerónimo Lobo</a>, wrote a half dozen histories regarding the first interaction with Ethiopians. Their book, however, was unknown until the 20th century when it was fully published.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup> Under Emperor <a href="/wiki/Susenyos_I" title="Susenyos I">Susenyos I</a>, Roman Catholicism became the state religion of the Ethiopian Empire in 1622.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Parfitt2019_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-Parfitt2019-103">[103]</a></sup> This unprecedented decision immediately caused an uprising by the Orthodox populace.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-berndl2005_104-0"><a href="#cite_note-berndl2005-104">[104]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Gondarine_period_.281632.E2.80.931769.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Gondarine_period_(1632–1769)">Gondarine period (1632–1769)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Gondarine_period" title="Gondarine period">Gondarine period</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:162px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Emperor-fasilides-king-of-ethiopia.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="607" data-file-width="480" decoding="async" height="202" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Emperor-fasilides-king-of-ethiopia.jpg/160px-Emperor-fasilides-king-of-ethiopia.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Emperor-fasilides-king-of-ethiopia.jpg/240px-Emperor-fasilides-king-of-ethiopia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Emperor-fasilides-king-of-ethiopia.jpg/320px-Emperor-fasilides-king-of-ethiopia.jpg 2x" width="160"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Emperor-fasilides-king-of-ethiopia.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Emperor <a href="/wiki/Fasilides" title="Fasilides">Fasilides</a> (r. 1632–1667) was a major figure of <a href="/wiki/Gondarine_period" title="Gondarine period">Gondarine period</a></div></div></div>
<p>In 1632, Emperor <a href="/wiki/Fasilides" title="Fasilides">Fasilides</a> successfully halted Roman Catholic state administration and restored <a href="/wiki/Orthodox_Tewahedo" title="Orthodox Tewahedo">Orthodox Tewahedo</a> as the state religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Parfitt2019_103-1"><a href="#cite_note-Parfitt2019-103">[103]</a></sup> Fasilides' reign sparked solidification of imperial power and moved the capital to <a href="/wiki/Gondar" title="Gondar">Gondar</a> in 1636, commencing a period of transition known as "<a href="/wiki/Gondarine_period" title="Gondarine period">Gondarine period</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup>  He expelled Jesuits by reclaiming possessed lands and relegating them to <a href="/wiki/Fremona" title="Fremona">Fremona</a>. During his reign, he built one of the most iconic royal fortress, <a href="/wiki/Fasil_Ghebbi" title="Fasil Ghebbi">Fasil Ghebbi</a>, forty-four churches were built<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_art" title="Ethiopian art">Ethiopian art</a> was revived. He also credited with constructing seven stone bridges over <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Blue_Nile_River" title="Blue Nile River">Blue Nile River</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup>
</p><p>Rebellion of the Agaw population in <a href="/wiki/Lasta" title="Lasta">Lasta</a> endured the reformation. Fasilides conducted <a href="/wiki/Punitive_expedition" title="Punitive expedition">punitive expeditions</a> to Lasta and successfully suppress it, which was described by the Scottish traveler <a href="/wiki/James_Bruce" title="James Bruce">James Bruce</a>, "almost the whole army perished amidst the mountains; great part from famine, but a greater still from cold, a very remarkable circumstance in these latitudes."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup> Fasilides tried to establish firm relations with Yemeni Imam <a href="/wiki/Al-Mutawakkil_Isma%27il" title="Al-Mutawakkil Isma'il">Al-Mutawakkil Isma'il</a> between 1642 and 1647 to discuss a trade route through Ottoman-held Massawa, which was unsuccessful.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:162px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Iyoas_I_of_Ethiopia.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="413" data-file-width="425" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Iyoas_I_of_Ethiopia.jpg/160px-Iyoas_I_of_Ethiopia.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Iyoas_I_of_Ethiopia.jpg/240px-Iyoas_I_of_Ethiopia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Iyoas_I_of_Ethiopia.jpg/320px-Iyoas_I_of_Ethiopia.jpg 2x" width="160"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Iyoas_I_of_Ethiopia.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Emperor <a href="/wiki/Iyoas_I" title="Iyoas I">Iyoas I</a> (r. 1755–1769) prematurely murdered at his reign by <i>Ras</i> <a href="/wiki/Mikael_Sehul" title="Mikael Sehul">Mikael Sehul</a> in 1769</div></div></div>
<p>Gondar's power and reputation decayed following the death of <a href="/wiki/Iyasu_I" title="Iyasu I">Iyasu I</a> in 1706 because most emperors preferred to enjoy luxurious life rather than spending in politics. After <a href="/wiki/Iyasu_II" title="Iyasu II">Iyasu II</a> death in 1755, Empress <a href="/wiki/Mentewab" title="Mentewab">Mentewab</a> brought her brother, <a href="/wiki/Ras_(title)" title="Ras (title)">Ras</a> Wolde Leul, to Gondar and made him Ras Bitwaded, resulted in regnal conflict between Mentewab's <i>Quaregnoch</i> and Wollo group led by Wubit. In 1767, Ras <a href="/wiki/Mikael_Sehul" title="Mikael Sehul">Mikael Sehul</a>, a regent in <a href="/wiki/Tigray_Province" title="Tigray Province">Tigray Province</a>, seized Gondar and murdered the child <a href="/wiki/Iyoas_I" title="Iyoas I">Iyoas I</a> in 1769, who was emperor at the time, and installed 70-year-old <a href="/wiki/Yohannes_II" title="Yohannes II">Yohannes II</a>, marking the beginning of the decentralized Zemene Mesafint era.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Zemene_Mesafint_.281769.E2.80.931889.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Zemene_Mesafint_(1769–1889)">Zemene Mesafint (1769–1889)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Zemene_Mesafint" title="Zemene Mesafint">Zemene Mesafint</a></div>
<p>Between 1769 and 1855, Ethiopia experienced a period of isolation referred to as the Zemene Mesafint or "Age of Princes". The emperors became figureheads, controlled by regional lords and noblemen like <i>Ras</i> Mikael Sehul, Ras <a href="/wiki/Wolde_Selassie" title="Wolde Selassie">Wolde Selassie</a> of Tigray, and by the <a href="/wiki/Yejju" title="Yejju">Yejju</a> Oromo dynasty of the <a href="/wiki/Zemene_Mesafint#Wara_Sheh_rulers_(Yejju)_(1784–1855)" title="Zemene Mesafint">Wara Sheh</a>, such as Ras <a href="/wiki/Gugsa_of_Yejju" title="Gugsa of Yejju">Gugsa of Yejju</a>. Prior to the Zemene Mesafint, Emperor Iyoas I had introduced the Oromo language (<i>Afaan Oromo</i>) at court, instead of Amharic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:T%C3%A9wodros_II_-_2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="504" data-file-width="377" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/T%C3%A9wodros_II_-_2.jpg/170px-T%C3%A9wodros_II_-_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/T%C3%A9wodros_II_-_2.jpg/255px-T%C3%A9wodros_II_-_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/T%C3%A9wodros_II_-_2.jpg/340px-T%C3%A9wodros_II_-_2.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:T%C3%A9wodros_II_-_2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Emperor <a href="/wiki/Tewodros_II" title="Tewodros II">Tewodros II</a> (<span style="white-space:nowrap;"><abbr title="reigned">r.</abbr> 1855–1868</span>) brought an end of <i>Zemene Mesafint</i></div></div></div>
<p>Ethiopian isolationism ended following a British mission that concluded with an alliance between the two nations, but it was not until 1855 that the Amhara kingdoms of northern Ethiopia (Gondar, <a href="/wiki/Gojjam" title="Gojjam">Gojjam</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Shewa" title="Shewa">Shewa</a>) were briefly united after the power of the emperor was restored beginning with the reign of <a href="/wiki/Tewodros_II" title="Tewodros II">Tewodros II</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Middleton2015_113-0"><a href="#cite_note-Middleton2015-113">[113]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-114"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> Tewodros II began a process of consolidation, centralisation, and state-building that would be continued by succeeding emperors. This process reduced the power of regional rulers, restructured the empire's administration, and created a professional army. These changes created the basis for establishing the effective sovereignty and territorial integrity of the Ethiopian state.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-115"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup>
</p><p>Conversely, Tewodros suffered several rebellions inside his empire. Northern Oromo militias, Tigrayan rebellions, and the constant incursion of the Ottoman Empire and Egyptian forces near the Red Sea brought the weakening and the final downfall of Tewodros II. He killed himself in 1868 during his last fight with the <a href="/wiki/British_expedition_to_Abyssinia" title="British expedition to Abyssinia">British expedition to Abyssinia</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Magdala" title="Battle of Magdala">Battle of Magdala</a>. After Tewodros' death, <a href="/wiki/Tekle_Giyorgis_II" title="Tekle Giyorgis II">Tekle Giyorgis II</a> was proclaimed emperor but was defeated in the Battles of Zulawu (21 June 1871) and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Adwa_(1871)" title="Battle of Adwa (1871)">Adwa</a> (11 July 1871).
</p><p>The victorious Mercha Kassai was subsequently declared <a href="/wiki/Yohannes_IV" title="Yohannes IV">Yohannes IV</a> on 21 January 1872. In 1875 and 1876, Ottoman/Egyptian forces, accompanied by many European and American 'advisors', twice <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian%E2%80%93Egyptian_War" title="Ethiopian–Egyptian War">invaded Abyssinia</a> but were initially defeated: once at the Battle of Gundit losing 800 men, and then in the second invasion, they were decisively defeated at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Gura" title="Battle of Gura">Battle of Gura</a> on 7<span class="nowrap"> </span>March 1875, where the invading forces lost at least 3,000 men by death or capture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the council of <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Boru_Meda&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Boru Meda (page does not exist)">Boru Meda</a> in 1878, Yohannes came out with a decree that Ethiopian Muslims must accept Christianity or be banned. Those that refused were executed on the spot. Tens of thousands were killed and more left their land and belongings to flee to Harar, Bale, Arsi, Jimma, and even to Sudan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup> From 1885 to 1889, Ethiopia joined the <a href="/wiki/Mahdist_War" title="Mahdist War">Mahdist War</a> allied to Britain, Turkey, and Egypt against the Sudanese Mahdist State. In 1887, Menelik II, king of <a href="/wiki/Shewa" title="Shewa">Shewa</a>, invaded the <a href="/wiki/Emirate_of_Harar" title="Emirate of Harar">Emirate of Harar</a> after his victory at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Chelenqo" title="Battle of Chelenqo">Battle of Chelenqo</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> On 10 March 1889, Yohannes IV was killed by the Sudanese Khalifah Abdullah's army whilst leading his army in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Gallabat" title="Battle of Gallabat">Battle of Gallabat</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="From_Menelik_II_to_Adwa_.281889.E2.80.931913.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="From_Menelik_II_to_Adwa_(1889–1913)">From Menelik II to Adwa (1889–1913)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/First_Italo-Ethiopian_War" title="First Italo-Ethiopian War">First Italo-Ethiopian War</a> and <a href="/wiki/Menelik%27s_Expansions" title="Menelik's Expansions">Menelik's Expansions</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Menelik_campaign_map_1_3.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="952" data-file-width="1026" decoding="async" height="204" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Menelik_campaign_map_1_3.jpg/220px-Menelik_campaign_map_1_3.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Menelik_campaign_map_1_3.jpg/330px-Menelik_campaign_map_1_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/Menelik_campaign_map_1_3.jpg/440px-Menelik_campaign_map_1_3.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Menelik_campaign_map_1_3.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The conquests of Emperor <a href="/wiki/Yohannes_IV" title="Yohannes IV">Yohannes IV</a>, <i><a href="/wiki/Negus" title="Negus">Negus</a></i> <a href="/wiki/Menelik_II" title="Menelik II">Menelik</a> and general <a href="/wiki/Ras_Alula" title="Ras Alula">Ras Alula</a> in 1879–1889</div></div></div>
<p>Ethiopia in roughly its current form began under the reign of Menelik II, who was Emperor from 1889 until his death in 1913. From his base in the central province of Shewa, Menelik set out to annex territories to the south, east, and west<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_120-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-120">[120]</a></sup> — areas inhabited by the Oromo, <a href="/wiki/Sidama_people" title="Sidama people">Sidama</a>, Gurage, <a href="/wiki/Welayta_people" title="Welayta people">Welayta</a>, and other peoples.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-igg_121-0"><a href="#cite_note-igg-121">[121]</a></sup> He achieved this with the help of <i>Ras</i> <a href="/wiki/Gobana_Dacche" title="Gobana Dacche">Gobana Dacche</a>'s Shewan Oromo militia, which occupied lands that had not been held since Ahmad ibn Ibrahim al-Ghazi's war, as well as other areas that had never been under Ethiopian rule.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-122"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> During the conquest of the Oromo, the <a href="/wiki/Army_of_the_Ethiopian_Empire" title="Army of the Ethiopian Empire">Ethiopian Army</a> carried out atrocities against the Oromo population including mass mutilation, mass killings, and large-scale slavery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceD_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceD-123">[123]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-124"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup> Some estimates of the number of people killed as a result of the conquest are in the millions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-125"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceD_123-1"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceD-123">[123]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceE_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceE-126">[126]</a></sup> Large-scale atrocities were also committed against the <a href="/wiki/Dizi_people" title="Dizi people">Dizi people</a> and the people of the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Kaffa" title="Kingdom of Kaffa">Kingdom of Kaffa</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ReferenceE_126-1"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceE-126">[126]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup> Menelik's campaign against Oromos outside his army was largely in retaliation for centuries of Oromo expansionism and the <i>Zemene Mesafint</i>, a period during which a succession of Oromo feudal rulers dominated the highlanders.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kanno_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kanno-128">[128]</a></sup> Chief among these was the <a href="/wiki/Yejju" title="Yejju">Yejju</a> dynasty, which included <a href="/wiki/Aligaz_of_Yejju" title="Aligaz of Yejju">Aligaz of Yejju</a> and his brother <a href="/wiki/Ali_I_of_Yejju" title="Ali I of Yejju">Ali I of Yejju</a>. The latter founded the town of <a href="/wiki/Debre_Tabor" title="Debre Tabor">Debre Tabor</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Amhara_Region" title="Amhara Region">Amhara Region</a>, which became the dynasty's capital.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup>
</p><p>Menelik II was the son of <a href="/wiki/Haile_Melekot" title="Haile Melekot">Haile Melekot</a>, Negus of Shewa, and Ejegayehu Lema Adeyamo, a palace servant.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Menelik2_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-Menelik2-130">[130]</a></sup> He was born at Angolala in an Oromo area and lived his first twelve years with Shewan Oromos, with whom he thus had much in common.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Menelik1_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-Menelik1-131">[131]</a></sup> During Menelik's reign, road construction, electricity, and education advanced, and a central <a href="/wiki/Taxation_in_Ethiopia" title="Taxation in Ethiopia">taxation system</a> was developed. The city of Finfinne was rebuilt and renamed <i><a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa" title="Addis Ababa">Addis Ababa</a></i>; in 1889-1891 it became the new capital of the Ethiopian Empire.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Menelik_-_Adoua-2_(cropped).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3524" data-file-width="3103" decoding="async" height="193" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Menelik_-_Adoua-2_%28cropped%29.jpg/170px-Menelik_-_Adoua-2_%28cropped%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Menelik_-_Adoua-2_%28cropped%29.jpg/255px-Menelik_-_Adoua-2_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/Menelik_-_Adoua-2_%28cropped%29.jpg/340px-Menelik_-_Adoua-2_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Menelik_-_Adoua-2_(cropped).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Menelik II at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Adwa" title="Battle of Adwa">Battle of Adwa</a></div></div></div>
<p>For his leadership, despite opposition from more traditional elements of society, Menelik II was heralded as a national hero. He had signed the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Wuchale" title="Treaty of Wuchale">Treaty of Wuchale</a> with Italy in May 1889, by which Italy would recognize Ethiopia's sovereignty so long as Italy could control an area north of Ethiopia (now part of modern Eritrea). In return, Italy was to provide Menelik with weapons and support him as emperor. The Italians used the time between the signing of the treaty and its ratification by the Italian government to expand their territorial claims. This <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_Italo%E2%80%93Ethiopian_War" title="First Italo–Ethiopian War">First Italo–Ethiopian War</a> culminated in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Adwa" title="Battle of Adwa">Battle of Adwa</a> on 1 March 1896, in which Italy's colonial forces were defeated by the Ethiopians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-igg_121-1"><a href="#cite_note-igg-121">[121]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> In 1896, the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Addis_Ababa" title="Treaty of Addis Ababa">Treaty of Addis Ababa</a> was signed, replacing the Treaty of Wuchale with conditions more favorable to Ethiopia.
</p><p>About a third of the population died in the <a href="/wiki/Famines_in_Ethiopia" title="Famines in Ethiopia">Great Ethiopian Famine</a> (1888 to 1892).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-134"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Haile_Selassie_I_era_.281916.E2.80.931974.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Haile_Selassie_I_era_(1916–1974)">Haile Selassie I era (1916–1974)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Haile_Selassie" title="Haile Selassie">Haile Selassie</a> and <a href="/wiki/Modernization_under_Haile_Selassie" title="Modernization under Haile Selassie">Modernization under Haile Selassie</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Addis_Ababa-8e00855u.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3388" data-file-width="4592" decoding="async" height="162" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Addis_Ababa-8e00855u.jpg/220px-Addis_Ababa-8e00855u.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Addis_Ababa-8e00855u.jpg/330px-Addis_Ababa-8e00855u.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Addis_Ababa-8e00855u.jpg/440px-Addis_Ababa-8e00855u.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Addis_Ababa-8e00855u.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Haile_Selassie" title="Haile Selassie">Haile Selassie</a> at his study in <a href="/wiki/National_Palace,_Addis_Ababa" title="National Palace, Addis Ababa">Jubilee Palace</a> (1942)</div></div></div>
<p>The early 20th century was marked by the reign of Emperor <a href="/wiki/Haile_Selassie" title="Haile Selassie">Haile Selassie</a> <i>(Ras Tafari)</i>. Haile Selassie I was born to parents with ethnic links to three Afroasiatic-speaking populations of Ethiopia: the Oromo and Amhara, the country's two largest ethnic groups, as well as the <a href="/wiki/Gurage_people" title="Gurage people">Gurage</a>.
