He came to power after <a href="/wiki/Lij_Iyasu" title="Lij Iyasu">Lij Iyasu</a> was deposed, and undertook <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Modernization_under_Haile_Selassie_I" title="Modernization under Haile Selassie I">a nationwide modernization campaign</a> from 1916 when he was made a <i>Ras</i> and Regent (<i>Inderase</i>) for the <a href="/wiki/Queen_regnant" title="Queen regnant">Empress Regnant</a> <a href="/wiki/Zewditu" title="Zewditu">Zewditu</a>, and became the <i>de facto</i> ruler of the Ethiopian Empire. Following Zewditu's death, on 2 November 1930, he succeeded her as emperor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup> In 1931, Haile Selassie endowed Ethiopia with its first-ever <a href="/wiki/1931_Constitution_of_Ethiopia" title="1931 Constitution of Ethiopia">Constitution</a> in emulation of Imperial Japan's <a href="/wiki/Meiji_Constitution" title="Meiji Constitution">1890 Constitution</a>, through which the <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central Europe</a> a model of unitary and homogenous ethnolinguistic <a href="/wiki/Nation_state" title="Nation state">nation-state</a> was adopted for the Ethiopian Empire.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Fascist_Italy_occupation_.281936.E2.80.931941.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Fascist_Italy_occupation_(1936–1941)">Fascist Italy occupation (1936–1941)</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Second_Italo-Ethiopian_War" title="Second Italo-Ethiopian War">Second Italo-Ethiopian War</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_Ethiopia" title="Italian Ethiopia">Italian Ethiopia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_East_Africa" title="Italian East Africa">Italian East Africa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arbegnoch" title="Arbegnoch">Arbegnoch</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Black_Lions" title="Black Lions">Black Lions</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Abyssinian-soldiers-1936-142348340618.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="722" data-file-width="949" decoding="async" height="167" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Abyssinian-soldiers-1936-142348340618.jpg/220px-Abyssinian-soldiers-1936-142348340618.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Abyssinian-soldiers-1936-142348340618.jpg/330px-Abyssinian-soldiers-1936-142348340618.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e5/Abyssinian-soldiers-1936-142348340618.jpg/440px-Abyssinian-soldiers-1936-142348340618.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Abyssinian-soldiers-1936-142348340618.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ethiopian cavalry during the <a href="/wiki/Second_Italo-Ethiopian_War" title="Second Italo-Ethiopian War">Second Italo-Ethiopian War</a> in 1936</div></div></div>
<p>The independence of Ethiopia was interrupted by the <a href="/wiki/Second_Italo-Ethiopian_War" title="Second Italo-Ethiopian War">Second Italo-Ethiopian War</a>, beginning when it was invaded by <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy#Fascist_regime_(1922–1943)" title="Kingdom of Italy">Fascist Italy</a> in early October 1935, and by subsequent Italian rule of the country (1936–1941) after Italian victory in the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup> During this time, Haile Selassie exiled and appealed to the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a> in 1935, delivering an address that made him a worldwide figure, and the 1935 <a href="/wiki/Time_Person_of_the_Year" title="Time Person of the Year"><i>Time</i> Man of the Year</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup> As the majority of the Ethiopian population lived in rural towns, Italy faced continued resistance and ambushes in urban centers throughout its rule over Ethiopia. Haile Selassie fled into exile in <a href="/wiki/Fairfield_House,_Bath" title="Fairfield House, Bath">Fairfield House, Bath</a>, England. Mussolini was able to proclaim <a href="/wiki/Italian_Ethiopia" title="Italian Ethiopia">Italian Ethiopia</a> and the assumption of the imperial title by the Italian King <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vittorio_Emanuele_III" title="Vittorio Emanuele III">Vittorio Emanuele III</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1937, the Italian massacre of <a href="/wiki/Yekatit_12" title="Yekatit 12">Yekatit 12</a> took place, in which between 1,400 and 30,000 civilians were killed and many others imprisoned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:02_140-0"><a href="#cite_note-:02-140">[140]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup> This massacre was a reprisal for the attempted assassination of <a href="/wiki/Rodolfo_Graziani" title="Rodolfo Graziani">Rodolfo Graziani</a>, the viceroy of <a href="/wiki/Italian_East_Africa" title="Italian East Africa">Italian East Africa</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup> The Italians employed the use of asphyxiating chemical weapons in their Ethiopian invasion. The Italians regularly dropped bombs throughout Ethiopia that carried mustard gas and debilitated the Ethiopian forces. On the whole, the Italians dropped about 300 tons of mustard gas as well as thousands of other artillery. This use of chemical weapons amounted to egregious war crimes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:RAS_Abissini_Pd-italy-005.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="750" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/RAS_Abissini_Pd-italy-005.jpg/220px-RAS_Abissini_Pd-italy-005.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/RAS_Abissini_Pd-italy-005.jpg/330px-RAS_Abissini_Pd-italy-005.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/RAS_Abissini_Pd-italy-005.jpg/440px-RAS_Abissini_Pd-italy-005.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:RAS_Abissini_Pd-italy-005.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ras <a href="/wiki/Seyoum_Mengesha" title="Seyoum Mengesha">Seyoum Mengesha</a>, Ras Getachew Abate and Ras Kebede Gubret with <a href="/wiki/Benito_Mussolini" title="Benito Mussolini">Benito Mussolini</a> on 6 February 1937 in Rome, Italy, after the Italian occupation of Ethiopia</div></div></div>
<p>The Italians made investments in Ethiopian infrastructure development during their rule over Ethiopia. They created the so-called "imperial road" between Addis Ababa and Massaua.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> More than 900 km of railways were reconstructed, dams and hydroelectric plants were built, and many public and private companies were established. The Italian government abolished <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_Ethiopia" title="Slavery in Ethiopia">slavery</a>, a practice that existed in the country for centuries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Accessed_15_May_2008_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-Accessed_15_May_2008-146">[146]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the entry of Italy into <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a> forces, together with the <i><a href="/wiki/Arbegnoch" title="Arbegnoch">Arbegnoch</a></i> (literally, "patriots", referring to armed resistance soldiers) liberated Ethiopia in the course of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/East_African_Campaign_(World_War_II)" title="East African Campaign (World War II)">East African Campaign</a> in 1941. An <a href="/wiki/Italian_guerrilla_war_in_Ethiopia" title="Italian guerrilla war in Ethiopia">Italian guerrilla warfare campaign</a> continued until 1943. The country was placed under <a href="/wiki/Occupied_Enemy_Territory_Administration_(Ethiopia)" title="Occupied Enemy Territory Administration (Ethiopia)">British military administration</a>. This was followed by British recognition of Ethiopia's full <a href="/wiki/Sovereignty" title="Sovereignty">sovereignty</a>, without any special British privileges, when the <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Ethiopian_Agreement" title="Anglo-Ethiopian Agreement">Anglo-Ethiopian Agreement</a> was signed in December 1944,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup> although <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Ethiopian_Agreement#British_Ogaden" title="Anglo-Ethiopian Agreement">some regions</a> remained under British control for more years. Under the peace treaty of 1947, Italy recognized the sovereignty and independence of Ethiopia.
</p><p>On 26 August 1942, Haile Selassie issued a proclamation that removed legal basis for <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_Ethiopia" title="Slavery in Ethiopia">slavery</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup> Ethiopia had between two and four million slaves in the early 20th century, out of a total population of about eleven million.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECampbellMiersMiller2007219_149-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECampbellMiersMiller2007219-149">[149]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Post-World_War_II_.281941.E2.80.931974.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-World_War_II_(1941–1974)">Post-World War II (1941–1974)</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/1960_Ethiopian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_attempt" title="1960 Ethiopian coup d'état attempt">1960 Ethiopian coup d'état attempt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Federation_of_Ethiopia_and_Eritrea" title="Federation of Ethiopia and Eritrea">Federation of Ethiopia and Eritrea</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Eritrean_War_of_Independence" title="Eritrean War of Independence">Eritrean War of Independence</a></div>
<p>In 1952, Haile Selassie orchestrated a <a href="/wiki/Federation_of_Ethiopia_and_Eritrea" title="Federation of Ethiopia and Eritrea">federation with Eritrea</a>. He dissolved this in 1962 and <a href="/wiki/Annexation" title="Annexation">annexed</a> Eritrea, resulting in the <a href="/wiki/Eritrean_War_of_Independence" title="Eritrean War of Independence">Eritrean War of Independence</a>. 
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:272px;max-width:272px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:126px;max-width:126px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:205px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:General-Mengistu-Neway-1919-1961.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="574" data-file-width="346" decoding="async" height="206" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/General-Mengistu-Neway-1919-1961.jpg/124px-General-Mengistu-Neway-1919-1961.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/General-Mengistu-Neway-1919-1961.jpg/186px-General-Mengistu-Neway-1919-1961.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/General-Mengistu-Neway-1919-1961.jpg/248px-General-Mengistu-Neway-1919-1961.jpg 2x" width="124"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:142px;max-width:142px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:205px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Germame_Neway.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="165" data-file-width="113" decoding="async" height="204" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/36/Germame_Neway.jpg" width="140"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flow-root"><div class="thumbcaption" style="text-align:center">General <a href="/wiki/Mengistu_Neway" title="Mengistu Neway">Mengistu</a> (left) and <a href="/wiki/Germame_Neway" title="Germame Neway">Germame Neway</a> (right) were the two perpetrators of the failed <a href="/wiki/1960_Ethiopian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_attempt" title="1960 Ethiopian coup d'état attempt">1960 coup d'état attempt</a> against Emperor Haile Selassie</div></div></div></div>
<p>Haile Selassie was nearly deposed in the <a href="/wiki/1960_Ethiopian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_attempt" title="1960 Ethiopian coup d'état attempt">1960 coup d'état</a> in a conspiracy by the chiefly progressive opposition group led by brothers <a href="/wiki/Germame_Neway" title="Germame Neway">Germame</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mengistu_Neway" title="Mengistu Neway">Mengistu Neway</a> whilst Selassie was on a state visit to <a href="/wiki/Brazil" title="Brazil">Brazil</a>. On the evening of Tuesday, 13 December, a group deceived the Ministers of the Imperial Crown and important personages to enter the National Palace, taking them hostage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup> Fighting began on the next day primarily between the Loyalist imperial army (Kebur Zebegna) and rebels led by General Tsege and Colonel Warqenah. At its start, Germame and his fellow combatants killed 15 of the hostages held in Genetta Leul Palace. Central of these were officials such as then Prime Minister <i>Ras</i> <a href="/wiki/Abebe_Aregai" title="Abebe Aregai">Abebe Aregai</a>, Makonnen Habte-Wolde and Major General Mulugeta.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-151"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup>
</p><p>Heavily subdued by the imperial army, General Tsege was killed in fighting, Colonel Warqenah committed suicide,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Clapham-497_152-0"><a href="#cite_note-Clapham-497-152">[152]</a></sup> and the brothers Mengistu and Germame Neway was near <a href="/wiki/Mojo,_Ethiopia" title="Mojo, Ethiopia">Mojo</a> on 24 December, who would soon executed by hanging at church square in Addis Ababa but Germame evaded by committing suicide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Milkias2011_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-Milkias2011-153">[153]</a></sup> The coup considered one of serious threat to Haile Selassie until 1974 <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Revolution" title="Ethiopian Revolution">Ethiopian Revolution</a>. In 1963, Haile Selassie played a leading role in the formation of the <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_African_Unity" title="Organisation of African Unity">Organisation of African Unity</a> (OAU).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup>
</p><p>Opinion within Ethiopia turned against Haile Selassie owing to the worldwide <a href="/wiki/1973_oil_crisis" title="1973 oil crisis">1973 oil crisis</a> causing a sharp increase in gasoline prices starting on 13 February 1974. The high gasoline prices motivated taxi drivers and teachers to go on strike on 18 February 1974, and students and workers in Addis Ababa began demonstrating against the government on 20 February 1974.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup> There were resulting food shortages, uncertainty regarding the succession, border wars, and discontent in the middle class created through modernization.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Black_Book2_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-Black_Book2-156">[156]</a></sup> The feudal oligarchical cabinet of <a href="/wiki/Aklilu_Habte-Wold" title="Aklilu Habte-Wold">Aklilu Habte-Wold</a> was toppled, and a new government was formed with <a href="/wiki/Endelkachew_Makonnen" title="Endelkachew Makonnen">Endelkachew Makonnen</a> serving as Prime Minister.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-157"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="The_Derg_era_.281974.E2.80.931991.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Derg_era_(1974–1991)">The Derg era (1974–1991)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Revolution" title="Ethiopian Revolution">Ethiopian Revolution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Derg" title="Derg">Derg</a>, <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Democratic_Republic_of_Ethiopia" title="People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia">People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Civil_War" title="Ethiopian Civil War">Ethiopian Civil War</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eritrean_War_of_Independence" title="Eritrean War of Independence">Eritrean War of Independence</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1983%E2%80%9385_famine_in_Ethiopia" title="1983–85 famine in Ethiopia">1983–85 famine in Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:EPRP.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="454" data-file-width="371" decoding="async" height="208" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/EPRP.jpg/170px-EPRP.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/EPRP.jpg/255px-EPRP.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/EPRP.jpg/340px-EPRP.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:EPRP.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_People%27s_Revolutionary_Party" title="Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Party">Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Party</a> (EPRP) clashed with the <a href="/wiki/Derg" title="Derg">Derg</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Red_Terror_(Ethiopia)" title="Red Terror (Ethiopia)">Red Terror</a></div></div></div>
<p>Haile Selassie's rule ended on 12 September 1974, when he was <a href="/wiki/1974_Ethiopian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="1974 Ethiopian coup d'état">deposed</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Derg" title="Derg">Derg</a>, a non-ideological committee made up of military and police officers led by <a href="/wiki/Aman_Andom" title="Aman Andom">Aman Andom</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup> After the execution of <a href="/wiki/Massacre_of_the_Sixty" title="Massacre of the Sixty">60 former government and military officials</a> including Aman in November 1974,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-159"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup> the new <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Provisional_Military_Administrative_Council" title="Provisional Military Administrative Council">Provisional Military Administrative Council</a> now led by <a href="/wiki/Tafari_Benti" title="Tafari Benti">General Tafari Benti</a> abolished the monarchy in March 1975 and established Ethiopia as a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Marxist-Leninist_state" title="Marxist-Leninist state">Marxist-Leninist state</a> with itself as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vanguard_party" title="Vanguard party">vanguard party</a> in a <a href="/wiki/Provisional_government" title="Provisional government">provisional government</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-160"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup> The abolition of <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">feudalism</a>, increased <a href="/wiki/Literacy" title="Literacy">literacy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nationalization" title="Nationalization">nationalization</a>, and sweeping <a href="/wiki/Land_reform" title="Land reform">land reform</a> including the <a href="/wiki/Resettlement_and_villagization_in_Ethiopia" title="Resettlement and villagization in Ethiopia">resettlement and villagization</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Highlands" title="Ethiopian Highlands">Ethiopian Highlands</a> became priorities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-161"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup>
</p><p>After internal conflicts that resulted in the execution of <a href="/wiki/Tafari_Benti" title="Tafari Benti">chairman Tafari Benti</a> and several of his supporters in February 1977, and the execution of <a href="/wiki/Atnafu_Abate" title="Atnafu Abate">vice-chairman Atnafu Abate</a> in November 1977, <a href="/wiki/Mengistu_Haile_Mariam" title="Mengistu Haile Mariam">Mengistu Halie Mariam</a> gained undisputed leadership of the Derg.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-162"><a href="#cite_note-162">[162]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Derg suffered several coups, uprisings, wide-scale drought, and a huge refugee problem. In 1977, Somalia, which had previously been receiving assistance and arms from the USSR, invaded Ethiopia in the <a href="/wiki/Ogaden_War" title="Ogaden War">Ogaden War</a>, capturing part of the Ogaden region. Ethiopia recovered it after it began receiving massive military aid from the Soviet bloc countries of the USSR, Cuba, South Yemen, East Germany,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-163"><a href="#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup> and North Korea. This included around 15,000 Cuban combat troops.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-164"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-165"><a href="#cite_note-165">[165]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Derg.gif"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="273" data-file-width="400" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Derg.gif/220px-Derg.gif" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Derg.gif/330px-Derg.gif 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/53/Derg.gif 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Derg.gif" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ethiopian leader <a href="/wiki/Mengistu_Haile_Mariam" title="Mengistu Haile Mariam">Mengistu Haile Mariam</a> (left) with fellow Derg members <a href="/wiki/Tafari_Benti" title="Tafari Benti">Tafari Benti</a> (middle) and <a href="/wiki/Atnafu_Abate" title="Atnafu Abate">Atnafu Abate</a> (right). Mengistu was sentenced to death in Ethiopia for <a href="/wiki/Red_Terror_(Ethiopia)" title="Red Terror (Ethiopia)">crimes</a> committed during his government, which killed up to 500,000 people;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-166">[166]</a></sup> he lived in exile in Zimbabwe as of 2018.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1976–78, up to 500,000 were killed as a result of the <a href="/wiki/Red_Terror_(Ethiopia)" title="Red Terror (Ethiopia)">Red Terror</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_166-1"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-166">[166]</a></sup> a violent <a href="/wiki/Political_repression" title="Political repression">political repression</a> campaign by the Derg against various opposition groups most notably the Marxist–Leninist <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_People%27s_Revolutionary_Party" title="Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Party">Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Party</a> (EPRP).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Black_Book2_156-1"><a href="#cite_note-Black_Book2-156">[156]</a></sup> The Red Terror was carried out in response to what the Derg termed the 'White Terror', a chain of violent events, assassinations, and killings carried out by what it called "<a href="/wiki/Petite_bourgeoisie" title="Petite bourgeoisie">petty bourgeois</a> reactionaries" who desired a reversal of the 1974 revolution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup>
In 1987, the Derg dissolved itself and established the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Democratic_Republic_of_Ethiopia" title="People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia">People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia</a> (PDRE) upon the adoption of the <a href="/wiki/1987_Constitution_of_Ethiopia" title="1987 Constitution of Ethiopia">1987 Constitution of Ethiopia</a> modeled on the <a href="/wiki/1977_Constitution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="1977 Constitution of the Soviet Union">1977 Constitution of the Soviet Union</a> with modified provisions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-169"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1983%E2%80%9385_famine_in_Ethiopia" title="1983–85 famine in Ethiopia">1983–85 famine in Ethiopia</a> affected around eight million people, resulting in one million dead. Insurrections against <a href="/wiki/Authoritarianism" title="Authoritarianism">authoritarian</a> rule sprang up, particularly in the northern regions of Eritrea and Tigray. The <a href="/wiki/Tigray_People%27s_Liberation_Front" title="Tigray People's Liberation Front">Tigray People's Liberation Front</a> (TPLF) merged with other ethnically based opposition movements in 1989, to form the coalition known as the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_People%27s_Revolutionary_Democratic_Front" title="Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front">Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front</a> (EPRDF).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-170"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup>
</p><p>Concurrently, under <a href="/wiki/Mikhail_Gorbachev" title="Mikhail Gorbachev">Mikhail Gorbachev</a>, the Soviet Union began to retreat from building world communism towards <i><a href="/wiki/Glasnost" title="Glasnost">glasnost</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Perestroika" title="Perestroika">perestroika</a></i> policies, marking a dramatic reduction in aid to Ethiopia from Socialist Bloc countries. This resulted in more economic hardship and the collapse of the military in the face of determined onslaughts by guerrilla forces in the north. The collapse of Marxism–Leninism in general, and in <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Europe" title="Eastern Europe">Eastern Europe</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1989" title="Revolutions of 1989">revolutions of 1989</a>, coincided with the Soviet Union stopping aid to Ethiopia altogether in 1990. To garner international support Mengistu embraced a <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed economy</a> and an end to one party rule but it was too late to save his regime.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-171"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-172"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup>
</p><p>EPRDF forces advanced on Addis Ababa in May 1991, and the Soviet Union did not intervene to save the government side. Mengistu fled the country and was granted asylum in Zimbabwe, where he still resides.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-175"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2006, after a trial that lasted 12 years, Ethiopia's <a href="/wiki/High_Court_of_Ethiopia" title="High Court of Ethiopia">Federal High Court</a> in Addis Ababa found Mengistu guilty of <a href="/wiki/Genocides_in_history#Ethiopia" title="Genocides in history">genocide</a> <i>in absentia</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[176]</a></sup> Numerous other top leaders of his government were also found guilty of <a href="/wiki/War_crime" title="War crime">war crimes</a>. Mengistu and others who had fled the country were tried and sentenced <i>in absentia</i>. Numerous former officials received the death sentence and tens of others spent the next 20 years in jail, before being pardoned from life sentences.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-178"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-179"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-180"><a href="#cite_note-180">[180]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Federal_Democratic_Republic_.281991.E2.80.93present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Federal_Democratic_Republic_(1991–present)"><span id="AnchorFederal">Federal Democratic Republic (1991–present)</span></span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethiopia_under_federal_republic" title="Ethiopia under federal republic">Ethiopia under federal republic</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eritrean_independence_referendum,_1993" title="Eritrean independence referendum, 1993">Eritrean independence referendum, 1993</a></div><p>
In July 1991, the EPRDF convened a National Conference to establish the <a href="/wiki/Transitional_Government_of_Ethiopia" title="Transitional Government of Ethiopia">Transitional Government of Ethiopia</a> composed of an 87-member Council of Representatives and guided by a national charter that functioned as a transitional constitution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELyons1996121–23_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELyons1996121–23-181">[181]</a></sup> In June 1992, the <a href="/wiki/Oromo_Liberation_Front" title="Oromo Liberation Front">Oromo Liberation Front</a> withdrew from the government; in March 1993, members of the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Ethiopia_Peoples%27_Democratic_Coalition" title="Southern Ethiopia Peoples' Democratic Coalition">Southern Ethiopia Peoples' Democratic Coalition</a> also left the government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup> In April 1993, <a href="/wiki/Eritrea" title="Eritrea">Eritrea</a> gained independence from Ethiopia after a <a href="/wiki/1993_Eritrean_independence_referendum" title="1993 Eritrean independence referendum">national referendum</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup> In 1994, a new constitution was written that established a parliamentary republic with a bicameral legislature and a judicial system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitution2_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-Constitution2-185">[185]</a></sup></p><div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Meles_Zenawi_-_World_Economic_Forum_Annual_Meeting_2012.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3043" data-file-width="2435" decoding="async" height="212" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Meles_Zenawi_-_World_Economic_Forum_Annual_Meeting_2012.jpg/170px-Meles_Zenawi_-_World_Economic_Forum_Annual_Meeting_2012.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Meles_Zenawi_-_World_Economic_Forum_Annual_Meeting_2012.jpg/255px-Meles_Zenawi_-_World_Economic_Forum_Annual_Meeting_2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Meles_Zenawi_-_World_Economic_Forum_Annual_Meeting_2012.jpg/340px-Meles_Zenawi_-_World_Economic_Forum_Annual_Meeting_2012.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Meles_Zenawi_-_World_Economic_Forum_Annual_Meeting_2012.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Former Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Meles_Zenawi" title="Meles Zenawi">Meles Zenawi</a> at the 2012 <a href="/wiki/World_Economic_Forum" title="World Economic Forum">World Economic Forum</a> annual meeting</div></div></div>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethiopian_general_election,_1995" title="Ethiopian general election, 1995">first multiparty election</a> took place in May 1995, which was won by the EPRDF.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELyons1996142_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELyons1996142-186">[186]</a></sup> The president of the transitional government, EPRDF leader <a href="/wiki/Meles_Zenawi" title="Meles Zenawi">Meles Zenawi</a>, became the first <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Ethiopia" title="Prime Minister of Ethiopia">Prime Minister</a> of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia, and <a href="/wiki/Negasso_Gidada" title="Negasso Gidada">Negasso Gidada</a> was elected its president.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup> In post-Derg Ethiopia's <a href="/wiki/1995_Constitution_of_Ethiopia" title="1995 Constitution of Ethiopia">Constitution</a> (promulgated in 1995), the EPRDF not only took over the Derg's Soviet-inspired promise of cultural and administrative autonomy for the country's over 80 ethnic groups but also borrowed the right to independence (secession) from the <a href="/wiki/1977_Constitution_of_the_Soviet_Union" title="1977 Constitution of the Soviet Union">Soviet Constitution</a>. In this manner, an <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_federalism" title="Ethnic federalism">ethnoterritorial federal</a> model of statehood was adopted for Ethiopia (as originally developed in the Central European empire of <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a> and in the <a href="/wiki/Korenizatsiya" title="Korenizatsiya">interwar Soviet Union</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-188"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 1998, a border dispute with Eritrea led to the <a href="/wiki/Eritrean%E2%80%93Ethiopian_War" title="Eritrean–Ethiopian War">Eritrean–Ethiopian War</a>, which lasted until June 2000 and cost both countries an estimated $1 million a day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup> This had a negative effect on Ethiopia's economy,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup> but strengthened the ruling coalition.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2017)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Ethiopia's <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethiopian_general_election,_2005" title="Ethiopian general election, 2005">3rd multiparty election</a> on 15 May 2005 was highly disputed, with many opposition groups claiming fraud. Though the <a href="/wiki/Carter_Center" title="Carter Center">Carter Center</a> approved the pre-election conditions, it expressed its dissatisfaction with post-election events. <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> election observers cited state support for the EPRDF campaign, as well as irregularities in ballot counting and results publishing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup> The opposition parties gained more than 200 parliamentary seats, compared with just 12 in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethiopian_general_election,_2000" title="Ethiopian general election, 2000">2000 elections</a>. While most of the opposition representatives joined the parliament, some leaders of the <a href="/wiki/Coalition_for_Unity_and_Democracy" title="Coalition for Unity and Democracy">CUD</a> party who refused to take up their parliamentary seats were accused of inciting the post-election violence and were imprisoned. <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a> considered them "<a href="/wiki/Prisoner_of_conscience" title="Prisoner of conscience">prisoners of conscience</a>" and they were subsequently released.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[192]</a></sup>
</p><p>A coalition of <a href="/wiki/List_of_political_parties_in_Ethiopia" title="List of political parties in Ethiopia">opposition parties</a> and some individuals were established in 2009 to oust the government of the EPRDF in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethiopian_general_election,_2010" title="Ethiopian general election, 2010">legislative elections of 2010</a>. Meles' party, which has been in power since 1991, published its 65-page manifesto in Addis Ababa on 10 October 2009. The opposition won most votes in Addis Ababa, but the EPRDF halted the counting of votes for several days. After it ensued, it claimed the election, amidst charges of fraud and intimidation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup>
</p><p>In mid-2011, two consecutively missed rainy seasons precipitated the worst <a href="/wiki/2011_East_Africa_drought" title="2011 East Africa drought">drought in East Africa</a> seen in 60 years. Full recovery from the drought's effects did not occur until 2012, with long-term strategies by the national government in conjunction with development agencies believed to offer the most sustainable results.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Twdisyihoa_194-0"><a href="#cite_note-Twdisyihoa-194">[194]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Deputy_Secretary_of_Defense_Ashton_B._Carter,_left,_is_greeted_by_Ethiopian_Prime_Minister_Hailemariam_Desalegn_at_his_office_in_Addis_Ababa,_Ethiopia,_on_July_24,_2013_130724-M-EV637-339.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2805" data-file-width="4214" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Deputy_Secretary_of_Defense_Ashton_B._Carter%2C_left%2C_is_greeted_by_Ethiopian_Prime_Minister_Hailemariam_Desalegn_at_his_office_in_Addis_Ababa%2C_Ethiopia%2C_on_July_24%2C_2013_130724-M-EV637-339.jpg/220px-thumbnail.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Deputy_Secretary_of_Defense_Ashton_B._Carter%2C_left%2C_is_greeted_by_Ethiopian_Prime_Minister_Hailemariam_Desalegn_at_his_office_in_Addis_Ababa%2C_Ethiopia%2C_on_July_24%2C_2013_130724-M-EV637-339.jpg/330px-thumbnail.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Deputy_Secretary_of_Defense_Ashton_B._Carter%2C_left%2C_is_greeted_by_Ethiopian_Prime_Minister_Hailemariam_Desalegn_at_his_office_in_Addis_Ababa%2C_Ethiopia%2C_on_July_24%2C_2013_130724-M-EV637-339.jpg/440px-thumbnail.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Deputy_Secretary_of_Defense_Ashton_B._Carter,_left,_is_greeted_by_Ethiopian_Prime_Minister_Hailemariam_Desalegn_at_his_office_in_Addis_Ababa,_Ethiopia,_on_July_24,_2013_130724-M-EV637-339.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Former Prime Minister of Ethiopia <a href="/wiki/Hailemariam_Desalegn" title="Hailemariam Desalegn">Hailemariam Desalegn</a> meeting with former US Deputy Secretary of Defense <a href="/wiki/Ash_Carter" title="Ash Carter">Ash Carter</a> in Addis Ababa.</div></div></div>
<p>Meles died on 20 August 2012 in Brussels, where he was being treated for an unspecified illness.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup> Deputy Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Hailemariam_Desalegn" title="Hailemariam Desalegn">Hailemariam Desalegn</a> was appointed as a new prime minister until the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethiopian_general_election,_2015" title="Ethiopian general election, 2015">2015 elections</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup> and remained so afterwards with his party in control of every parliamentary seat.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AJE_HD_holds_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-AJE_HD_holds-197">[197]</a></sup>
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2016_Ethiopian_protests" title="2016 Ethiopian protests">Protests broke out across the country on 5 August 2016</a> and hundreds of protesters were subsequently shot and killed by police. The protesters demanded an end to human rights abuses, the release of political prisoners, a fairer redistribution of the wealth generated by over a decade of economic growth, and a return of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wolqayt" title="Wolqayt">Wolqayt District</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Amhara_Region" title="Amhara Region">Amhara Region</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC1_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC1-198">[198]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC2_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC2-199">[199]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Reuters1_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-Reuters1-200">[200]</a></sup> The events were the most violent crackdown against protesters in <a href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Sub-Saharan Africa">Sub-Saharan Africa</a> since the Ethiopian government killed at least 75 people during protests in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oromia_Region" title="Oromia Region">Oromia Region</a> in November and December 2015.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup> Following these protests, Ethiopia declared a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethiopia_State_of_Emergency_2016" title="Ethiopia State of Emergency 2016">state of emergency</a> on 6<span class="nowrap"> </span>October 2016.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[203]</a></sup> The state of emergency was lifted in August 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 16 February 2018, the government of Ethiopia declared a six-month nationwide state of emergency following the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Abdication_of_Hailemariam_Desalegn" title="Abdication of Hailemariam Desalegn">resignation</a> of Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Hailemariam_Desalegn" title="Hailemariam Desalegn">Hailemariam Desalegn</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[205]</a></sup> Hailemariam is the first ruler in modern Ethiopian history to step down; previous leaders have died in office or been overthrown.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup> He said that he wanted to clear the way for reforms.
</p>
<h3><span id="Abiy_Ahmed_and_the_Prosperity_Party_.282018.E2.80.93present.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Abiy_Ahmed_and_the_Prosperity_Party_(2018–present)">Abiy Ahmed and the Prosperity Party (2018–present)</span></h3>
<p><span class="anchor" id="Government_reforms_(2018–present)"></span>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_civil_conflict_(2018%E2%80%93present)" title="Ethiopian civil conflict (2018–present)">Ethiopian civil conflict</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tigray_War" title="Tigray War">Tigray War</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ethiopian_Prime_Minister_Abiy_Ahmed_receiving_the_Nobel_Peace_Prize_in_Oslo_2019.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3648" data-file-width="5472" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Ethiopian_Prime_Minister_Abiy_Ahmed_receiving_the_Nobel_Peace_Prize_in_Oslo_2019.jpg/220px-Ethiopian_Prime_Minister_Abiy_Ahmed_receiving_the_Nobel_Peace_Prize_in_Oslo_2019.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Ethiopian_Prime_Minister_Abiy_Ahmed_receiving_the_Nobel_Peace_Prize_in_Oslo_2019.jpg/330px-Ethiopian_Prime_Minister_Abiy_Ahmed_receiving_the_Nobel_Peace_Prize_in_Oslo_2019.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Ethiopian_Prime_Minister_Abiy_Ahmed_receiving_the_Nobel_Peace_Prize_in_Oslo_2019.jpg/440px-Ethiopian_Prime_Minister_Abiy_Ahmed_receiving_the_Nobel_Peace_Prize_in_Oslo_2019.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ethiopian_Prime_Minister_Abiy_Ahmed_receiving_the_Nobel_Peace_Prize_in_Oslo_2019.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Abiy_Ahmed" title="Abiy Ahmed">Abiy Ahmed</a> receiving the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Peace_Prize" title="Nobel Peace Prize">Nobel Peace Prize</a> in Oslo in 2019</div></div></div>
<p>The new Prime Minister was <a href="/wiki/Abiy_Ahmed" title="Abiy Ahmed">Abiy Ahmed</a>, who made an <a href="/wiki/2018_Eritrea%E2%80%93Ethiopia_summit" title="2018 Eritrea–Ethiopia summit">historic visit to Eritrea in 2018</a>, ending the <a href="/wiki/Eritrean%E2%80%93Ethiopian_border_conflict" title="Eritrean–Ethiopian border conflict">state of conflict between the two countries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-207"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup> For his efforts in ending the 20-year-long war between Ethiopia and Eritrea, Abiy Ahmed was awarded the Nobel prize for peace in 2019.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[208]</a></sup> After taking office in April 2018, <span class="currentage"></span>46-year-old Abiy released political prisoners, promised fair elections for 2019 and announced sweeping economic reforms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-209"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup> As of 6 June 2019,<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ethiopia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> all the previously censored websites were made accessible again, over 13,000 political prisoners were released and hundreds of administrative staff were fired as part of the reforms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[211]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[212]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[213]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Ethiopia#Ethnic_violence" title="Human rights in Ethiopia">Ethnic violence rose</a> with the political unrest. There were <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oromo%E2%80%93Somali_clashes" title="Oromo–Somali clashes">Oromo–Somali clashes</a> between the Oromo, who make up the largest ethnic group in the country, and the ethnic Somalis, leading to up to 400,000 have been displaced in 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-irinnews_214-0"><a href="#cite_note-irinnews-214">[214]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gedeo%E2%80%93Oromo_clashes" title="Gedeo–Oromo clashes">Gedeo–Oromo clashes</a> between the Oromo and the <a href="/wiki/Gedeo_people" title="Gedeo people">Gedeo people</a> in the south of the country led to Ethiopia having the largest number of people to flee their homes in the world in 2018, with 1.4 million newly displaced people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[215]</a></sup> Starting in 2019, in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metekel_conflict" title="Metekel conflict">Metekel conflict</a>, fighting in the <a href="/wiki/Metekel_Zone" title="Metekel Zone">Metekel Zone</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Benishangul-Gumuz_Region" title="Benishangul-Gumuz Region">Benishangul-Gumuz Region</a> in Ethiopia has reportedly involved militias from the <a href="/wiki/Gumuz_people" title="Gumuz people">Gumuz</a> people against Amharas and Agaws.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[216]</a></sup> In March 2020, the leader of an Amhara militia called <a href="/wiki/Fano_(militia)" title="Fano (militia)">Fano</a>, <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Solomon_Atanaw&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Solomon Atanaw (page does not exist)">Solomon Atanaw</a>, stated that they would not disarm until Metekel Zone and the <a href="/wiki/Tigray_Region" title="Tigray Region">Tigray Region</a> districts of <a href="/wiki/Welkait" title="Welkait">Welkait</a> and <a href="/wiki/Raya_Azebo" title="Raya Azebo">Raya</a> were returned to the control of <a href="/wiki/Amhara_Region" title="Amhara Region">Amhara Region</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[217]</a></sup> In September 2018, 23 people were killed in acts of ethnic violence against minorities in the <a href="/wiki/Oromia_Special_Zone_Surrounding_Finfinne" title="Oromia Special Zone Surrounding Finfinne">Special Zone of Oromia</a> near the Ethiopian capital Addis Ababa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[218]</a></sup> 35 people were later killed in Addis Ababa and in the surrounding Oromia Special Zone during protests against what many regarded as a lack of a response from the government to the violence. Some were killed by police.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[219]</a></sup>
</p><p>On 22 June 2019, factions of the security forces of the region attempted a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2019_Amhara_Region_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat_attempt" title="2019 Amhara Region coup d'état attempt">coup d'état</a> against the <a href="/wiki/Amhara_Region" title="Amhara Region">regional government</a>, during which the President of the Amhara Region, <a href="/wiki/Ambachew_Mekonnen" title="Ambachew Mekonnen">Ambachew Mekonnen</a>, was assassinated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:10_220-0"><a href="#cite_note-:10-220">[220]</a></sup> A bodyguard siding with the nationalist factions assassinated General <a href="/wiki/Se%27are_Mekonnen" title="Se'are Mekonnen">Se'are Mekonnen</a> – the <a href="/wiki/Chief_of_General_Staff_(Ethiopia)" title="Chief of General Staff (Ethiopia)">Chief of the General Staff</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_National_Defense_Force" title="Ethiopian National Defense Force">Ethiopian National Defense Force</a> – as well as his aide, Major General Gizae Aberra.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:10_220-1"><a href="#cite_note-:10-220">[220]</a></sup> The Prime Minister's Office accused Brigadier General <a href="/wiki/Asaminew_Tsige" title="Asaminew Tsige">Asaminew Tsige</a>, head of the Amhara region security forces, of leading the plot,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[221]</a></sup> and Tsige was shot dead by police near Bahir Dar on 24 June.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[222]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ethiopian_Civil_War_(2020-present).svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1494" data-file-width="1843" decoding="async" height="178" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Ethiopian_Civil_War_%282020-present%29.svg/220px-Ethiopian_Civil_War_%282020-present%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Ethiopian_Civil_War_%282020-present%29.svg/330px-Ethiopian_Civil_War_%282020-present%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Ethiopian_Civil_War_%282020-present%29.svg/440px-Ethiopian_Civil_War_%282020-present%29.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ethiopian_Civil_War_(2020-present).svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_civil_conflict_(2018%E2%80%93present)" title="Ethiopian civil conflict (2018–present)">Ethiopian civil conflict (2018–present)</a> – Territorial control as of February 2022:<br/><span style="font-size:85%;">(For a more detailed, up-to-date, interactive map, see <a href="/wiki/Template:Ethiopian_wars_and_insurgencies_detailed_map" title="Template:Ethiopian wars and insurgencies detailed map">here</a>)</span>.<br/> <b>Pro-federal government troops</b><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style><div class="legend" style="text-align:left;"><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#fcadad; color:black; -webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ethiopia" title="Government of Ethiopia">Ethiopian federal government</a> and regional allies</div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend" style="text-align:left;"><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#8b98f0ff; color:; -webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Eritrean_Defence_Forces" title="Eritrean Defence Forces">Eritrean Defence Forces</a></div> <b>Anti-federal government rebels</b> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend" style="text-align:left;"><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#a8ed9d; color:black; -webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Tigray_Defense_Forces" title="Tigray Defense Forces">Tigray Defense Forces</a></div> <link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend" style="text-align:left;"><span class="legend-color" style="background-color:#ffff44; color:black; -webkit-column-break-inside: avoid;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Oromo_Liberation_Army" title="Oromo Liberation Army">Oromo Liberation Army</a></div></div></div></div>
<p>The Fano militia is an Amhara youth group in Ethiopia, perceived as either a protest group or an armed militia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[223]</a></sup> An alliance between Fano and <a href="/wiki/Qeerroo" title="Qeerroo">Qeerroo</a>, its Oromo counterpart, played a crucial role in the bringing about the political and administrative changes associated with the <a href="/wiki/Premiership_of_Abiy_Ahmed" title="Premiership of Abiy Ahmed">premiership of Abiy Ahmed</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[224]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[225]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Tigray_War" title="Tigray War">Tigray War</a>, Fano supported federal and regional security forces against rebels aligned with the <a href="/wiki/Tigray_People%27s_Liberation_Front" title="Tigray People's Liberation Front">Tigray People's Liberation Front</a> or TPLF.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[226]</a></sup> Fano units are accused of participating in ethnic massacres, including that of 58 <a href="/wiki/Qemant_people" title="Qemant people">Qemant people</a> in <a href="/wiki/Metemma" title="Metemma">Metemma</a> during 10–11 January 2019,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[227]</a></sup> and of armed actions in <a href="/wiki/Humera" title="Humera">Humera</a> in November 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[228]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Hachalu_Hundessa_riots" title="Hachalu Hundessa riots">Protests</a> broke out across Ethiopia following the assassination of <a href="/wiki/Oromo_people" title="Oromo people">Oromo</a> musician <a href="/wiki/Hachalu_Hundessa" title="Hachalu Hundessa">Hachalu Hundessa</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[229]</a></sup> on 29 June 2020, leading to the deaths of at least 239 people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[230]</a></sup>
</p><p>The federal government, under the <a href="/wiki/Prosperity_Party" title="Prosperity Party">Prosperity Party</a>, requested that the <a href="/wiki/National_Election_Board_of_Ethiopia" title="National Election Board of Ethiopia">National Election Board of Ethiopia</a> cancel elections for 2020 due to health and safety concerns about <a href="/wiki/COVID-19" title="COVID-19">COVID-19</a>. No official date was set for the next election at that time, but the government promised that once a vaccine was developed for COVID-19 that elections would move forward.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[231]</a></sup> The Tigrayan ruling party, TPLF, opposed canceling the elections and, when their request to the federal government to hold elections was rejected, the TPLF proceeded to hold elections anyway on 9 September 2020. They worked with regional opposition parties and included international observers in the election process.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[232]</a></sup> It was estimated that 2.7 million people participated in the election.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[233]</a></sup>
</p><p>Relations between the federal government and the Tigray regional government deteriorated after the election,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[234]</a></sup> and on 4 November 2020, Abiy began a military offensive in the Tigray Region in response to attacks on army units stationed there, causing thousands of refugees to flee to neighbouring Sudan and triggering the Tigray War.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[235]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[236]</a></sup> More than 600 civilians were killed in a <a href="/wiki/Mai_Kadra_massacre" title="Mai Kadra massacre">massacre in the town of Mai Kadra</a> on 9 November 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[237]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[238]</a></sup> In April 2021, <a href="/wiki/Eritrea" title="Eritrea">Eritrea</a> confirmed its troops are fighting in Ethiopia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[239]</a></sup> As of March 2022, as many as 500,000 people had died as a result of violence and <a href="/wiki/Famine_in_the_Tigray_War" title="Famine in the Tigray War">famine in the Tigray War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[240]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[241]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Government_and_politics">Government and politics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Ethiopia" title="Politics of Ethiopia">Politics of Ethiopia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Ethiopia" title="Law of Ethiopia">Law of Ethiopia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Ethiopia" title="Judiciary of Ethiopia">Judiciary of Ethiopia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rulers_and_Heads_of_State_of_Ethiopia" title="Rulers and Heads of State of Ethiopia">Rulers and Heads of State of Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ethiopian_Parliament.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="720" data-file-width="1280" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Ethiopian_Parliament.jpg/220px-Ethiopian_Parliament.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Ethiopian_Parliament.jpg/330px-Ethiopian_Parliament.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Ethiopian_Parliament.jpg/440px-Ethiopian_Parliament.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ethiopian_Parliament.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/House_of_People%27s_Representatives" title="House of People's Representatives">House of People's Representatives</a> is the lower house of the Ethiopian <a href="/wiki/Federal_Parliamentary_Assembly" title="Federal Parliamentary Assembly">Federal Parliamentary Assembly</a></div></div></div>
<p>Ethiopia is a <a href="/wiki/Federalism" title="Federalism">federal</a> <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">parliamentary republic</a>, wherein the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Ethiopia" title="Prime Minister of Ethiopia">Prime Minister</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_government" title="Head of government">head of government</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Ethiopia" title="President of Ethiopia">President</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a> but with largely ceremonial powers. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Executive_power" title="Executive power">Executive power</a> is exercised by the government and federal <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Legislative_power" title="Legislative power">legislative power</a> vested in both the government and the two chambers of parliament. The <a href="/wiki/House_of_Federation" title="House of Federation">House of Federation</a> is the upper chamber of the bicameral legislature with 108 seats, and the lower chamber is the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Peoples%27_Representatives" title="House of Peoples' Representatives">House of Peoples' Representatives</a> (HoPR) with 547 seats. The House of Federation is chosen by the regional councils whereas MPs of the HoPR are elected directly, in turn, they elect the president for a six-year term and the prime minister for a 5-year term.
</p><p>The Ethiopian <a href="/wiki/Judiciary_of_Ethiopia" title="Judiciary of Ethiopia">judiciary</a> consists of dual system with two court structures: the federal and state courts. The FDRE Constitution vested federal judicial authority to the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Supreme_Court_of_Ethiopia" title="Federal Supreme Court of Ethiopia">Federal Supreme Court</a> which can overturn and review decisions of subordinate federal courts; itself has regular division assigned for fundamental <a href="/wiki/Error_(law)" title="Error (law)">errors of law</a>. In addition, the Supreme Court can perform <a href="/wiki/Circuit_court" title="Circuit court">circuit hearings</a> in established five states at any states of federal levels or "area designated for its jurisdiction" if deemed "necessary for the efficient rendering of justice".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[242]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-243"><a href="#cite_note-243">[243]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Federal Supreme Proclamation granted three subject matter principles: laws, parties and place to federal court jurisdiction, first "cases arising under the <a href="/wiki/1995_Constitution_of_Ethiopia" title="1995 Constitution of Ethiopia">Constitution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Federal_law" title="Federal law">federal laws</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/International_treaties" title="International treaties">international treaties</a>", second over "parties specified by federal laws".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[244]</a></sup>
</p><p>On the basis of Article 78 of the 1994 Ethiopian Constitution, the judiciary is completely independent of the executive and the legislature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[245]</a></sup> To ensure this, the vice-president and President of the Supreme Court appointed by Parliament on the nomination of Prime Minister. Once elected, the executive power has no authority to remove from office. Other judges are nominated by the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Judicial_Administration_Council" title="Federal Judicial Administration Council">Federal Judicial Administration Council</a> (FJAC) on the basis of transparent criteria and the Prime Minister's recommendation for appointment in the HoPR. In all cases, judges cannot be removed from their duty unless they retired, violated disciplinary rules, gross incompatibility, or inefficiency to unfit due to ill health. Contrary, the majority vote of HoPR have the right to sanction removal in federal judiciary level or state council in cases of state judges.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:7_246-0"><a href="#cite_note-:7-246">[246]</a></sup> In 2015, the realities of this provision were questioned in a report prepared by <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[247]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the <a href="/wiki/Democracy_Index" title="Democracy Index">Democracy Index</a> published by the United Kingdom-based <a href="/wiki/Economist_Intelligence_Unit" title="Economist Intelligence Unit">Economist Intelligence Unit</a> in late 2010, Ethiopia was an "authoritarian regime", ranking as the 118th-most democratic out of 167 countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[248]</a></sup> Ethiopia had dropped 12 places on the list since 2006, and the 2010 report attributed the drop to the government's crackdown on opposition activities, media, and civil society before the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethiopian_general_election,_2010" title="Ethiopian general election, 2010">2010 parliamentary election</a>, which the report argued had made Ethiopia a <a href="/wiki/Dominant-party_system" title="Dominant-party system"><i>de facto</i> one-party state</a>.
</p><p>However, since the appointment of <a href="/wiki/Abiy_Ahmed" title="Abiy Ahmed">Abiy Ahmed</a> as prime minister in 2018, the situation has rapidly evolved.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (February 2020)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Governance">Governance</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ethiopia" title="Government of Ethiopia">Government of Ethiopia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:258px;max-width:258px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:127px;max-width:127px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Abiy_Ahmed_with_LI_Yong_2018_(cropped).jpeg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1325" data-file-width="1074" decoding="async" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Abiy_Ahmed_with_LI_Yong_2018_%28cropped%29.jpeg/125px-Abiy_Ahmed_with_LI_Yong_2018_%28cropped%29.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Abiy_Ahmed_with_LI_Yong_2018_%28cropped%29.jpeg/188px-Abiy_Ahmed_with_LI_Yong_2018_%28cropped%29.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Abiy_Ahmed_with_LI_Yong_2018_%28cropped%29.jpeg/250px-Abiy_Ahmed_with_LI_Yong_2018_%28cropped%29.jpeg 2x" width="125"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Ethiopia" title="Prime Minister of Ethiopia">Prime Minister</a> <a href="/wiki/Abiy_Ahmed" title="Abiy Ahmed">Abiy Ahmed</a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:127px;max-width:127px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Sahle-Work_Zewde_in_2016.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1947" data-file-width="1579" decoding="async" height="154" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Sahle-Work_Zewde_in_2016.jpg/125px-Sahle-Work_Zewde_in_2016.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Sahle-Work_Zewde_in_2016.jpg/188px-Sahle-Work_Zewde_in_2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Sahle-Work_Zewde_in_2016.jpg/250px-Sahle-Work_Zewde_in_2016.jpg 2x" width="125"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/President_of_Ethiopia" title="President of Ethiopia">President</a> <a href="/wiki/Sahle-Work_Zewde" title="Sahle-Work Zewde">Sahle-Work Zewde</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>In post-1995 regime, Ethiopia's politics has been liberalized which promotes all-encompassing reforms to the country. Today, its economy is based on <a href="/wiki/Mixed_economy" title="Mixed economy">mixed</a>, <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market-oriented</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:7_246-1"><a href="#cite_note-:7-246">[246]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first <a href="/wiki/1994_Ethiopian_Constituent_Assembly_election" title="1994 Ethiopian Constituent Assembly election">election</a> of 547-member constituent assembly was held in June 1994. This assembly adopted the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Ethiopia" title="Constitution of Ethiopia">constitution of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia</a> in December 1994. The elections for Ethiopia's first popularly chosen national parliament and regional legislatures were held in May and June 1995. Most opposition parties chose to boycott these elections. There was a landslide victory for the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_People%27s_Revolutionary_Democratic_Front" title="Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front">Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front</a> (EPRDF). International and non-governmental observers concluded that opposition parties would have been able to participate had they chosen to do so.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The first government of Ethiopia under the new constitution was installed in August 1995 with <a href="/wiki/Negasso_Gidada" title="Negasso Gidada">Negasso Gidada</a> as president. The EPRDF-led government of Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Meles_Zenawi" title="Meles Zenawi">Meles Zenawi</a> promoted a policy of <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_federalism" title="Ethnic federalism">ethnic federalism</a>, devolving significant powers to regional, ethnically based authorities. Ethiopia today has eleven semi-autonomous administrative regions that have the power to raise and spend their own revenues. Under past governments, some fundamental freedoms, including <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_the_press" title="Freedom of the press">freedom of the press</a>, were circumscribed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FH_Ethiopia_249-0"><a href="#cite_note-FH_Ethiopia-249">[249]</a></sup>
</p><p>Citizens had little access to media other than the state-owned networks, and most private newspapers struggled to remain open and suffered periodic harassment from the government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FH_Ethiopia_249-1"><a href="#cite_note-FH_Ethiopia-249">[249]</a></sup> Starting from the 2005 elections, at least 18 journalists who had written articles critical of the government, were arrested on genocide and treason charges. The government used press laws governing libel to intimidate journalists who were critical of its policies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HRW_Ethiopia_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-HRW_Ethiopia-250">[250]</a></sup>
</p><p>Meles' government was elected in 2000 in the first-ever multiparty elections; however, the results were heavily criticized by international observers and denounced by the opposition as fraudulent. The EPRDF also won the 2005 election returning Meles to power. Although the opposition vote increased in the election, both the opposition and observers from the European Union and elsewhere stated that the vote did not meet international standards for fair and free elections.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FH_Ethiopia_249-2"><a href="#cite_note-FH_Ethiopia-249">[249]</a></sup> Ethiopian police are said to have massacred 193 protesters, mostly in the capital <a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa" title="Addis Ababa">Addis Ababa</a>, in the violence following the May 2005 elections in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethiopian_police_massacre" title="Ethiopian police massacre">Ethiopian police massacre</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[251]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Secretary_Kerry_and_Ethiopian_Foreign_Minister_Adhanom_Hold_a_News_Conference_in_Addis_Ababa_(3).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1848" data-file-width="2784" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Secretary_Kerry_and_Ethiopian_Foreign_Minister_Adhanom_Hold_a_News_Conference_in_Addis_Ababa_%283%29.jpg/220px-Secretary_Kerry_and_Ethiopian_Foreign_Minister_Adhanom_Hold_a_News_Conference_in_Addis_Ababa_%283%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Secretary_Kerry_and_Ethiopian_Foreign_Minister_Adhanom_Hold_a_News_Conference_in_Addis_Ababa_%283%29.jpg/330px-Secretary_Kerry_and_Ethiopian_Foreign_Minister_Adhanom_Hold_a_News_Conference_in_Addis_Ababa_%283%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Secretary_Kerry_and_Ethiopian_Foreign_Minister_Adhanom_Hold_a_News_Conference_in_Addis_Ababa_%283%29.jpg/440px-Secretary_Kerry_and_Ethiopian_Foreign_Minister_Adhanom_Hold_a_News_Conference_in_Addis_Ababa_%283%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Secretary_Kerry_and_Ethiopian_Foreign_Minister_Adhanom_Hold_a_News_Conference_in_Addis_Ababa_(3).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Former Foreign Minister of Ethiopia <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tedros_Adhanom" title="Tedros Adhanom">Tedros Adhanom</a> with former U.S. Secretary of State <a href="/wiki/John_Kerry" title="John Kerry">John Kerry</a></div></div></div>
<p>The government initiated a crackdown in the provinces as well; in Oromia Region, the authorities used concerns over insurgency and terrorism to use torture, imprisonment, and other repressive methods to silence critics following the election, particularly people sympathetic to the registered opposition party <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oromo_National_Congress" title="Oromo National Congress">Oromo National Congress</a> (ONC).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HRW_Ethiopia_250-1"><a href="#cite_note-HRW_Ethiopia-250">[250]</a></sup> The government has been engaged in a conflict with rebels in the <a href="/wiki/Ogaden" title="Ogaden">Ogaden</a> region since 2007. The biggest opposition party in 2005 was the <a href="/wiki/Coalition_for_Unity_and_Democracy" title="Coalition for Unity and Democracy">Coalition for Unity and Democracy</a> (CUD). After various internal divisions, most of the CUD party leaders have established the new <a href="/wiki/Unity_for_Democracy_and_Justice" title="Unity for Democracy and Justice">Unity for Democracy and Justice</a> party led by Judge <a href="/wiki/Birtukan_Mideksa" title="Birtukan Mideksa">Birtukan Mideksa</a>. A member of the country's <a href="/wiki/Oromo_people" title="Oromo people">Oromo</a> ethnic group, Birtukan Mideksa is the first woman to lead a political party in Ethiopia.
</p><p>In 2008, the top five opposition parties were the Unity for Democracy and Justice led by Judge Birtukan Mideksa, <a href="/wiki/United_Ethiopian_Democratic_Forces" title="United Ethiopian Democratic Forces">United Ethiopian Democratic Forces</a> led by <a href="/wiki/Beyene_Petros" title="Beyene Petros">Beyene Petros</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oromo_Federalist_Democratic_Movement" title="Oromo Federalist Democratic Movement">Oromo Federalist Democratic Movement</a> led by <a href="/wiki/Bulcha_Demeksa" title="Bulcha Demeksa">Bulcha Demeksa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oromo_People%27s_Congress" title="Oromo People's Congress">Oromo People's Congress</a> led by <a href="/wiki/Merera_Gudina" title="Merera Gudina">Merera Gudina</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Democratic_Party" title="Ethiopian Democratic Party">United Ethiopian Democratic Party – Medhin Party</a> led by <a href="/wiki/Lidetu_Ayalew" title="Lidetu Ayalew">Lidetu Ayalew</a>.  After the 2015 elections, Ethiopia lost its single remaining opposition MP;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AJE_opposition_252-0"><a href="#cite_note-AJE_opposition-252">[252]</a></sup> by 2015 there were no opposition MPs in the Ethiopian parliament.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC_Obama_trip_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_Obama_trip-253">[253]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Ethiopia" title="Foreign relations of Ethiopia">Foreign relations of Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_state_visit_of_Reuven_Rivlin_to_Ethiopia,_May_2018_(4382).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2538" data-file-width="3307" decoding="async" height="169" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/The_state_visit_of_Reuven_Rivlin_to_Ethiopia%2C_May_2018_%284382%29.jpg/220px-The_state_visit_of_Reuven_Rivlin_to_Ethiopia%2C_May_2018_%284382%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/The_state_visit_of_Reuven_Rivlin_to_Ethiopia%2C_May_2018_%284382%29.jpg/330px-The_state_visit_of_Reuven_Rivlin_to_Ethiopia%2C_May_2018_%284382%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f4/The_state_visit_of_Reuven_Rivlin_to_Ethiopia%2C_May_2018_%284382%29.jpg/440px-The_state_visit_of_Reuven_Rivlin_to_Ethiopia%2C_May_2018_%284382%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_state_visit_of_Reuven_Rivlin_to_Ethiopia,_May_2018_(4382).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ethiopian <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Ethiopia" title="Prime Minister of Ethiopia">Prime Minister</a> <a href="/wiki/Abiy_Ahmed" title="Abiy Ahmed">Abiy Ahmed</a> with Israeli <a href="/wiki/President_of_Israel" title="President of Israel">President</a> <a href="/wiki/Reuven_Rivlin" title="Reuven Rivlin">Reuven Rivlin</a> in May 2018</div></div></div>
