<p>Starting from the <a href="/wiki/Land_of_Punt" title="Land of Punt">Land of Punt</a>, Ethiopia has been a <a href="/wiki/Trading_nation" title="Trading nation">trading nation</a> that mainly exported goods such as <a href="/wiki/Gold" title="Gold">gold</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ivory" title="Ivory">ivory</a>, exotic animals, and <a href="/wiki/Incense" title="Incense">incense</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[254]</a></sup> Many historians concluded that modern diplomatic relationship of Ethiopia began under Emperor Tewodros II, whose reign was sought to establish Ethiopian border and later unsuccessfully diminished in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/1868_Expedition_to_Abyssinia" title="1868 Expedition to Abyssinia">British expedition of 1868</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[255]</a></sup> Since then, the country was seen redundant by world powers until the opening of <a href="/wiki/Suez_Canal" title="Suez Canal">Suez Canal</a> due to an influence of <a href="/wiki/Mahdist_War" title="Mahdist War">Mahdist War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[256]</a></sup>
</p><p>Today, Ethiopia maintains strong relations with <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93Ethiopia_relations" title="China–Ethiopia relations">China</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia%E2%80%93Israel_relations" title="Ethiopia–Israel relations">Israel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia%E2%80%93Mexico_relations" title="Ethiopia–Mexico relations">Mexico</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia%E2%80%93Turkey_relations" title="Ethiopia–Turkey relations">Turkey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia%E2%80%93India_relations" title="Ethiopia–India relations">India</a> as well as neighboring countries. The relationship with <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia%E2%80%93Sudan_relations" title="Ethiopia–Sudan relations">Sudan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Egypt%E2%80%93Ethiopia_relations" title="Egypt–Ethiopia relations">Egypt</a> is somewhat in dispute situation owing to the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Ethiopian_Renaissance_Dam" title="Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam">Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam</a> project, which was escalated in 2020.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[257]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[258]</a></sup> Despite six upstream countries (Ethiopia, <a href="/wiki/Kenya" title="Kenya">Kenya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uganda" title="Uganda">Uganda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rwanda" title="Rwanda">Rwanda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Burundi" title="Burundi">Burundi</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tanzania" title="Tanzania">Tanzania</a>) signed Nile Basin Initiative in 2010, Egypt and Sudan rejected water sharing treaty citing the reduction of amount of water to the <a href="/wiki/Nile_Basin" title="Nile Basin">Nile Basin</a> challenges their historic connection of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Water_rights" title="Water rights">water rights</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[259]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[260]</a></sup> In 2020, Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed warned that "No force can stop Ethiopia from building a dam. If there is need to go to war, we could get millions readied."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[261]</a></sup> Ethiopia is a strategic partner of Global <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/War_on_Terrorism" title="War on Terrorism">War on Terrorism</a> and <a href="/wiki/African_Growth_and_Opportunity_Act" title="African Growth and Opportunity Act">African Growth and Opportunity Act</a> (AGOA).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[262]</a></sup> US. Former <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">President</a> <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> was the first incumbent to visit Ethiopia in July 2015, while delivering speech in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Africa_Union" title="Africa Union">Africa Union</a>, he highlighted combatting the Islamic terrorism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[263]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[264]</a></sup> Ethiopia has concentrated emigrant to countries in Europe mainly in <a href="/wiki/Ethiopians_in_Italy" title="Ethiopians in Italy">Italy</a>, Saudi Arabia, <a href="/wiki/Ethiopians_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Ethiopians in the United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Canadians" title="Ethiopian Canadians">Canada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ethiopians_in_Sweden" title="Ethiopians in Sweden">Sweden</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Australians" title="Ethiopian Australians">Australia</a>. Ethiopia has Jewish emigrant in Israel about 155,300 as of 2019. They are collectively known as <a href="/wiki/Beta_Israel" title="Beta Israel">Beta Israel</a>. Ethiopia is founding member of the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_24" title="Group of 24">Group of 24</a> (G-24), the <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Group_of_77" title="Group of 77">G77</a>. In 1963, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Organization_of_African_Unity" title="Organization of African Unity">Organization of African Unity</a> later renamed itself the African Union was founded in Addis Ababa serving the political center of the Union. In addition, it is also a member of the <a href="/wiki/Pan_African_Chamber_of_Commerce_and_Industry" title="Pan African Chamber of Commerce and Industry">Pan African Chamber of Commerce and Industry</a>, the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Economic_Commission_for_Africa" title="United Nations Economic Commission for Africa">United Nations Economic Commission for Africa</a>, the <a href="/wiki/African_Standby_Force" title="African Standby Force">African Standby Force</a> and many of the global <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/NGO" title="NGO">NGOs</a> focused on Africa.
</p><p>Ethiopia is one of African countries and founding member of <a href="/wiki/League_of_Nations" title="League of Nations">League of Nations</a> now <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> since at least end of <a href="/wiki/New_Imperialism" title="New Imperialism">colonial era</a> in 1923. The UN tasks in Ethiopia is primarily of humanitarian issues and development. For example, UN Country Team (UNCT) in Ethiopia has representative of 28 UN funds and programmes and specialized agencies. Some of its agencies mandate regional ligature with <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Economic_Commission_for_Africa" title="United Nations Economic Commission for Africa">United Nations Economic Commission for Africa</a> and the African Union. The UN focuses all-encompassing affairs in Ethiopia, providing two goals: Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and National Development priority. This includes fighting against poverty, sustainable economic growth, climate change policy, educational and healthcare provision, increasing job employment and environmental protection.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[265]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Ethiopia" title="Military history of Ethiopia">Military history of Ethiopia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_National_Defense_Force" title="Ethiopian National Defense Force">Ethiopian National Defense Force</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:2014_01_22_Ethiopia_Welcome_Ceremony_001.jpg_(12086805304).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2800" data-file-width="4208" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/2014_01_22_Ethiopia_Welcome_Ceremony_001.jpg_%2812086805304%29.jpg/220px-2014_01_22_Ethiopia_Welcome_Ceremony_001.jpg_%2812086805304%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/2014_01_22_Ethiopia_Welcome_Ceremony_001.jpg_%2812086805304%29.jpg/330px-2014_01_22_Ethiopia_Welcome_Ceremony_001.jpg_%2812086805304%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/2014_01_22_Ethiopia_Welcome_Ceremony_001.jpg_%2812086805304%29.jpg/440px-2014_01_22_Ethiopia_Welcome_Ceremony_001.jpg_%2812086805304%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:2014_01_22_Ethiopia_Welcome_Ceremony_001.jpg_(12086805304).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Ethiopian National Defense Force soldiers during ceremony in <a href="/wiki/Baidoa" title="Baidoa">Baidoa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Somalia" title="Somalia">Somalia</a> to mark the inclusion of Ethiopia into the African Union peace keeping mission in the country on 22 January 2014</div></div></div>
<p>Historically, Ethiopia was heavily built on military and saw decisive invasions against external powers. Despite modern weapons equipped with assistance of European countries such as Portugal, Russia, France and Britain, the Ethiopian army largely relied on feudal system, so its army nearly consisted of peasant militia. Under <a href="/wiki/Amda_Seyon_I" title="Amda Seyon I">Amda Seyon I</a>, a legion named <a href="/wiki/Chewa_regiments" title="Chewa regiments">Chewa regiments</a> was formed in 14th century, became dominant military force in medieval times. It was normally composed up to several thousand men. The modern military dates back in 1917 created by <a href="/wiki/Haile_Selassie" title="Haile Selassie">Tafari Makonnen</a> which was called <a href="/wiki/Kebur_Zabagna" title="Kebur Zabagna">Kebur Zabagna</a>. The Ethiopian Army under <a href="/wiki/Kagnew_Battalion" title="Kagnew Battalion">Kagnew Battalion</a> unit involved in the <a href="/wiki/Korean_War" title="Korean War">Korean War</a> from 1950, fought as part of <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Command" title="United Nations Command">United Nations Command</a>. Some publications stated that Ethiopian troops remained for 15 years, though other stated they left until 1975, as part of the UN Command.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[266]</a></sup> The battalion sized 6,037 troops at the time of the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-autob_267-0"><a href="#cite_note-autob-267">[267]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ethiopian_soldiers_marching_in_a_military_parade_2019.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2573" data-file-width="3860" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Ethiopian_soldiers_marching_in_a_military_parade_2019.jpg/220px-Ethiopian_soldiers_marching_in_a_military_parade_2019.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Ethiopian_soldiers_marching_in_a_military_parade_2019.jpg/330px-Ethiopian_soldiers_marching_in_a_military_parade_2019.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Ethiopian_soldiers_marching_in_a_military_parade_2019.jpg/440px-Ethiopian_soldiers_marching_in_a_military_parade_2019.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ethiopian_soldiers_marching_in_a_military_parade_2019.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>ENDF soldiers marching in 2019 parade</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_National_Defense_Force" title="Ethiopian National Defense Force">Ethiopian National Defense Force</a> is the largest military in Africa<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[268]</a></sup> and is directed by <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defense_(Ethiopia)" title="Ministry of Defense (Ethiopia)">Ministry of Defense</a>. Other military branches include <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Ground_Forces" title="Ethiopian Ground Forces">ground forces</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Air_Force" title="Ethiopian Air Force">air force</a> and formerly <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Navy" title="Ethiopian Navy">naval force</a>. Since 1996, landlocked Ethiopia has had no navy but in 2018 Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed said on state TV: "We built one of the strongest ground and air forces in Africa<span class="nowrap"> </span>... we should build our naval force capacity in the future."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[269]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_enforcement">Law enforcement</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Law_enforcement_in_Ethiopia" title="Law enforcement in Ethiopia">Law enforcement in Ethiopia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Crime_in_Ethiopia" title="Crime in Ethiopia">Crime in Ethiopia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Police_brutality_in_Ethiopia" title="Police brutality in Ethiopia">Police brutality in Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ethiopian_Federal_Police_Marching_Band.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="360" data-file-width="480" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Ethiopian_Federal_Police_Marching_Band.jpg/220px-Ethiopian_Federal_Police_Marching_Band.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Ethiopian_Federal_Police_Marching_Band.jpg/330px-Ethiopian_Federal_Police_Marching_Band.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Ethiopian_Federal_Police_Marching_Band.jpg/440px-Ethiopian_Federal_Police_Marching_Band.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ethiopian_Federal_Police_Marching_Band.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Ethiopian Federal Police Marching Band performing on annual festival in <a href="/wiki/Meskel_Square" title="Meskel Square">Meskel Square</a>, Addis Ababa on 16 September 2017</div></div></div>
<p>The constitution guarantees law enforcement duty to the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Federal_Police" title="Ethiopian Federal Police">Ethiopian Federal Police</a> (EFP). The EFP is responsible for safeguarding and public welfare in federal level. Founded in 1995, the federal police surveyed by Federal Police Commissioner since October 2000; the Federal Police Commissioner then reports task to the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Peace_(Ethiopia)" title="Ministry of Peace (Ethiopia)">Ministry of Peace</a>, however it was overrode after political reforms in 2018, and directed to the parliament. In previous years, the federal police reports the Ministry's tasks directly. In addition, the federal police have ability to disclose regional police commissions, in order for assistance. Independently, the local militias uphold security.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Arbeitsbesuch_%C3%84thiopien_(24161781184).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2126" data-file-width="3200" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Arbeitsbesuch_%C3%84thiopien_%2824161781184%29.jpg/220px-Arbeitsbesuch_%C3%84thiopien_%2824161781184%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Arbeitsbesuch_%C3%84thiopien_%2824161781184%29.jpg/330px-Arbeitsbesuch_%C3%84thiopien_%2824161781184%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Arbeitsbesuch_%C3%84thiopien_%2824161781184%29.jpg/440px-Arbeitsbesuch_%C3%84thiopien_%2824161781184%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Arbeitsbesuch_%C3%84thiopien_(24161781184).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Three EFP officers on pickup truck arriving at Somali refugee camp on 1 February 2016</div></div></div>
<p>Nowadays, <a href="/wiki/Bribery" title="Bribery">bribery</a> is a basic concern, especially observed by traffic police. <a href="/wiki/Police_brutality_in_Ethiopia" title="Police brutality in Ethiopia">Police brutality</a> appeared as severe in recent years. On 26 August 2019, a video of handcuffed man beaten by two police officers as an elderly woman intervened the scene in Addis Ababa went viral. Recent police misconduct is said to be a failure of Federal Police Commissioner to abide Article 52 of the constitution, which states investigation of unlawful <a href="/wiki/Use_of_force" title="Use of force">use of force</a>, and dismissal of those misconducted officer. The African Union's Luanda and Robben Island Guidelines or the United Nations' Declaration on Justice for Victims of Abuse of Power and their Basic Principles on the Use of Force &amp; Firearms are once obligated to the Ethiopian government disciplinary committee to combat police brutality in both individual and systemic level.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-270"><a href="#cite_note-270">[270]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Human_rights">Human rights</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Ethiopia" title="Human rights in Ethiopia">Human rights in Ethiopia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/War_crimes_in_the_Tigray_War" title="War crimes in the Tigray War">War crimes in the Tigray War</a></div>
<p>Human rights violations often accompany <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_discrimination_in_Ethiopia" title="Ethnic discrimination in Ethiopia">endured ethnic and communal violence in the country</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[271]</a></sup> In a <a href="/wiki/2014%E2%80%932016_Oromo_protests" title="2014–2016 Oromo protests">2016 demonstration</a>, 100 peaceful protestors were killed by direct government gunfire in the <a href="/wiki/Oromia" title="Oromia">Oromia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Amhara_Region" title="Amhara Region">Amhara</a> regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[272]</a></sup> The UN has called for UN observers on the ground in Ethiopia to investigate this incident,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[273]</a></sup> however the EPRDF-dominated Ethiopian government has refused this call.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[274]</a></sup> The protestors are protesting land grabs and lack of basic human rights such as the freedom to elect their representatives. The TPLF-dominated EPRDF won 100% in an election marked by fraud which has resulted in Ethiopian civilians protesting on scale unseen in prior post-election protests.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reuters.com_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-reuters.com-275">[275]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Merera_Gudina" title="Merera Gudina">Merera Gudina</a>, leader of the <a href="/wiki/Oromo_People%27s_Congress" title="Oromo People's Congress">Oromo People's Congress</a>, said the East African country was at a "crossroads". He added in the interview with Reuters: "People are demanding their rights", he said. "People are fed up with what the regime has been doing for a quarter of a century. They're protesting against land grabs, reparations, stolen elections, the rising cost of living, many things. "If the government continue to repress while the people are demanding their rights in the millions that (civil war) is one of the likely scenarios."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-reuters.com_275-1"><a href="#cite_note-reuters.com-275">[275]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Omo_River_Valley_IMG_0463.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1080" data-file-width="1920" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Omo_River_Valley_IMG_0463.jpg/220px-Omo_River_Valley_IMG_0463.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Omo_River_Valley_IMG_0463.jpg/330px-Omo_River_Valley_IMG_0463.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Omo_River_Valley_IMG_0463.jpg/440px-Omo_River_Valley_IMG_0463.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Omo_River_Valley_IMG_0463.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Karo_people_(Ethiopia)" title="Karo people (Ethiopia)">Karo people</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Nations,_Nationalities,_and_Peoples%27_Region" title="Southern Nations, Nationalities, and Peoples' Region">Southern Nations, Nationalities, and Peoples' Region</a></div></div></div>
<p>According to surveys in 2003 by the National Committee on Traditional Practices in Ethiopia, <a href="/wiki/Bride_kidnapping" title="Bride kidnapping">marriage by abduction</a> accounts for 69% of the nation's marriages, with around 80% in the largest region, Oromia, and as high as 92% in the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Nations,_Nationalities,_and_Peoples%27_Region" title="Southern Nations, Nationalities, and Peoples' Region">Southern Nations, Nationalities, and Peoples' Region</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[276]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-277"><a href="#cite_note-277">[277]</a></sup> Journalists and activists have been threatened or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Misinformation_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic#Efforts_to_combat_misinformation" title="Misinformation related to the COVID-19 pandemic">arrested</a> for their coverage of the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Ethiopia" title="COVID-19 pandemic in Ethiopia">COVID-19 pandemic in Ethiopia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[278]</a></sup>
</p><p>Among the Omotic <a href="/wiki/Karo_language_(Ethiopia)" title="Karo language (Ethiopia)">Karo-speaking</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hamer_people" title="Hamer people">Hamer peoples</a> in southern Ethiopia, adults and children with physical abnormalities are considered to be <a href="/wiki/Mingi" title="Mingi">mingi</a>, "ritually impure". The latter are believed to exert an evil influence upon others; disabled infants have traditionally been murdered without a proper burial.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Petros_279-0"><a href="#cite_note-Petros-279">[279]</a></sup> The Karo officially banned the practice in July 2012.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[280]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2013, the <a href="/wiki/Oakland_Institute" title="Oakland Institute">Oakland Institute</a> released a report accusing the Ethiopian government of forcing the relocation of "hundreds of thousands of indigenous people from their lands" in the <a href="/wiki/Gambela_Region" title="Gambela Region">Gambela Region</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_281-0"><a href="#cite_note-:1-281">[281]</a></sup> According to several reports by the organization, those who refused were the subject of a variety of intimidation techniques including physical and sexual abuse, which sometimes led to deaths.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[282]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[283]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_284-0"><a href="#cite_note-:2-284">[284]</a></sup> A similar 2012 report by <a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch" title="Human Rights Watch">Human Rights Watch</a> also describes the Ethiopian government's 2010–2011 <a href="/wiki/Villagization" title="Villagization">villagization</a> program in Gambela, with plans to carry out similar resettlements in other regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[285]</a></sup> The Ethiopian government has denied the accusations of <a href="/wiki/Land_grabbing" title="Land grabbing">land grabbing</a> and instead pointed to the positive trajectory of the country's economy as evidence of the development program's benefits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:2_284-1"><a href="#cite_note-:2-284">[284]</a></sup>
A nationwide <a href="/wiki/October_2019_Ethiopian_clashes" title="October 2019 Ethiopian clashes">series of violent protests</a>, concentrated in the Oromia Region, broke out starting on 23 October 2019, sparked by activist and media owner <a href="/wiki/Jawar_Mohammed" title="Jawar Mohammed">Jawar Mohammed</a>'s allegation that security forces had attempted to detain him. According to official reports, 86 people were killed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-286"><a href="#cite_note-286">[286]</a></sup>
On 29 May 2020, <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a> released a report accusing the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_National_Defense_Force" title="Ethiopian National Defense Force">security forces of Ethiopia</a> of <a href="/wiki/Detention_(imprisonment)" title="Detention (imprisonment)">mass detentions</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Extrajudicial_killings" title="Extrajudicial killings">extrajudicial killings</a>. The report stated that in 2019, at least 25 people, suspected of supporting the <a href="/wiki/Oromo_Liberation_Front" title="Oromo Liberation Front">Oromo Liberation Army</a>, were killed by the forces in parts the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oromia_Region" title="Oromia Region">Oromia Region</a>. Besides, between January and September 2019, at least 10,000 people were detained under suspicion, where most were "subjected to brutal beatings".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[287]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="LGBT_rights">LGBT rights</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Ethiopia" title="LGBT rights in Ethiopia">LGBT rights in Ethiopia</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Homosexuality" title="Homosexuality">Homosexual acts</a> are illegal in Ethiopia. According to <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Criminal_Code" title="Ethiopian Criminal Code">Criminal Code</a> Article 629, same-sex activity is punished up to 15 years to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Life_in_prison" title="Life in prison">life in prison</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-288"><a href="#cite_note-288">[288]</a></sup> Ethiopia has been a socially conservative country. The majority of people are hostile towards LGBT people and persecution is commonplace on the grounds of religious and societal norms. Homosexuality came to light in the country since the failed 2008 appeal to the Council of Ministers, and the LGBT scene began to thrive slightly in major metropolitan locations, such as Addis Ababa. Some notable hotels like <a href="/wiki/Sheraton_Addis" title="Sheraton Addis">Sheraton Addis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hilton_Addis" title="Hilton Addis">Hilton Hotel</a> became hotbeds of accusations for alleged lobbying.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[289]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Ethiopian Orthodox church plays a frontal role in opposition; some of its members formed anti-gay organizations. For example, Dereje Negash, one prominent activist, founded "Zim Anlem" in 2014, which is a traditionalism and anti-gender movement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[290]</a></sup> According to the 2007 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pew_Global_Attitudes_Project" title="Pew Global Attitudes Project">Pew Global Attitudes Project</a>, 97 percent<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[291]</a></sup> of Ethiopians believe homosexuality is a way of life that society should not accept. This was the second-highest rate of non-acceptance in the 45 countries surveyed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[292]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Subdivisions_of_Ethiopia" title="Subdivisions of Ethiopia">Subdivisions of Ethiopia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Ethiopia" title="Regions of Ethiopia">Regions of Ethiopia</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_zones_of_Ethiopia" title="List of zones of Ethiopia">List of zones of Ethiopia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Ethiopia" title="Districts of Ethiopia">Districts of Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="center"><div class="thumb tnone"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:572px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_zones_of_Ethiopia.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1494" data-file-width="1843" decoding="async" height="462" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Map_of_zones_of_Ethiopia.svg/570px-Map_of_zones_of_Ethiopia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Map_of_zones_of_Ethiopia.svg/855px-Map_of_zones_of_Ethiopia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Map_of_zones_of_Ethiopia.svg/1140px-Map_of_zones_of_Ethiopia.svg.png 2x" width="570"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Map_of_zones_of_Ethiopia.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Map of <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Ethiopia" title="Regions of Ethiopia">regions</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_zones_of_Ethiopia" title="List of zones of Ethiopia">zones</a> of Ethiopia</div></div></div></div>
<p>Before 1996, Ethiopia was divided into thirteen <a href="/wiki/Provinces_of_Ethiopia" title="Provinces of Ethiopia">provinces</a>, many derived from historical regions. The nation now has a tiered governmental system consisting of a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Federal_government" title="Federal government">federal government</a> overseeing regional states, zones, <a href="/wiki/Districts_of_Ethiopia" title="Districts of Ethiopia">districts</a> (<i>woreda</i>), and <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kebele" title="Kebele">kebeles</a></i> ("neighbourhoods").<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Ethiopia is divided into eleven ethnically based and politically autonomous <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Ethiopia" title="Regions of Ethiopia">regional states</a> (<i>kililoch</i>, singular <i>kilil</i> ) and two chartered cities (<i>astedader akababiwoch</i>, singular <i>astedader akababi</i> ), the latter being <a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa" title="Addis Ababa">Addis Ababa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dire_Dawa" title="Dire Dawa">Dire Dawa</a>. The <i>kililoch</i> are subdivided into sixty-eight <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zones_of_Ethiopia" title="Zones of Ethiopia">zones</a>, and then further into 550 <i>woredas</i> and several special <i>woredas</i>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>The constitution assigns extensive power to regional states, which can establish their own government and democracy as long as it is in line with the federal government's constitution. Each region has at its apex a regional council where members are directly elected to represent the districts and the council has legislative and executive power to direct internal affairs of the regions.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Furthermore, Article 39 of the Ethiopian Constitution gives every regional state the right to secede from Ethiopia. There is debate, however, as to how much of the power guaranteed in the constitution is actually given to the states. The councils implement their mandate through an executive committee and regional sectoral bureaus. Such an elaborate structure of council, executive and sectoral public institutions is replicated at the next level (<i>woreda</i>).<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Ethiopia" title="Geography of Ethiopia">Geography of Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Wonchi_Lake_of_Ethiopia.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1920" data-file-width="2899" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Wonchi_Lake_of_Ethiopia.jpg/220px-Wonchi_Lake_of_Ethiopia.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Wonchi_Lake_of_Ethiopia.jpg/330px-Wonchi_Lake_of_Ethiopia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Wonchi_Lake_of_Ethiopia.jpg/440px-Wonchi_Lake_of_Ethiopia.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Wonchi_Lake_of_Ethiopia.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Wonchi_(volcano)" title="Wonchi (volcano)">Wonchi Lake</a> at the crossroads between <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ambo,_Oromia" title="Ambo, Oromia">Ambo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Waliso" title="Waliso">Waliso</a> in Oromia Region</div></div></div>
<p>At 1,104,300 square kilometres (426,372.61 sq mi),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA_World_Factbook_9-1"><a href="#cite_note-CIA_World_Factbook-9">[9]</a></sup> Ethiopia is the world's 28th-largest country, comparable in size to <a href="/wiki/Bolivia" title="Bolivia">Bolivia</a>. It lies between the <a href="/wiki/3rd_parallel_north" title="3rd parallel north">3rd parallel north</a> and the <a href="/wiki/15th_parallel_north" title="15th parallel north">15th parallel north</a> and longitudes <a href="/wiki/33rd_meridian_east" title="33rd meridian east">33rd meridian east</a> and <a href="/wiki/48th_meridian_east" title="48th meridian east">48th meridian east</a>.
</p><p>The major portion of Ethiopia lies in the <a href="/wiki/Horn_of_Africa" title="Horn of Africa">Horn of Africa</a>, which is the easternmost part of the African landmass. The territories that have frontiers with Ethiopia are Eritrea to the north and then, moving in a clockwise direction, Djibouti, Somaliland, Somalia, Kenya, South Sudan and Sudan. Within Ethiopia is a vast highland complex of mountains and dissected plateaus divided by the <a href="/wiki/Great_Rift_Valley,_Ethiopia" title="Great Rift Valley, Ethiopia">Great Rift Valley</a>, which runs generally southwest to northeast and is surrounded by lowlands, <a href="/wiki/Steppe" title="Steppe">steppes</a>, or semi-desert. There is a great diversity of terrain with wide variations in climate, soils, natural vegetation and settlement patterns.
</p><p>Ethiopia is an ecologically diverse country, ranging from the deserts along the eastern border to the tropical forests in the south to extensive <a href="/wiki/Afromontane" title="Afromontane">Afromontane</a> in the northern and southwestern parts. <a href="/wiki/Lake_Tana" title="Lake Tana">Lake Tana</a> in the north is the source of the <a href="/wiki/Blue_Nile" title="Blue Nile">Blue Nile</a>. It also has many <a href="/wiki/Endemism" title="Endemism">endemic</a> species, notably the <a href="/wiki/Gelada" title="Gelada">gelada</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Walia_ibex" title="Walia ibex">walia ibex</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_wolf" title="Ethiopian wolf">Ethiopian wolf</a> ("Simien fox"). The wide range of altitude has given the country a variety of ecologically distinct areas, and this has helped to encourage the evolution of endemic species in ecological isolation.
</p><p>The nation is a land of geographical contrasts, ranging from the vast fertile west, with its forests and numerous rivers, to the world's hottest settlement of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dallol,_Ethiopia" title="Dallol, Ethiopia">Dallol</a> in its north. The <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Highlands" title="Ethiopian Highlands">Ethiopian Highlands</a> are the largest continuous mountain ranges in Africa, and the <a href="/wiki/Sof_Omar_Caves" title="Sof Omar Caves">Sof Omar Caves</a> contains the largest cave on the continent. Ethiopia also has the second-largest number of <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Africa" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Africa">UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a> in Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[293]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Ethiopia" title="Climate of Ethiopia">Climate of Ethiopia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Climate_change_in_Ethiopia" title="Climate change in Ethiopia">Climate change in Ethiopia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Beautifying_Sheger" title="Beautifying Sheger">Beautifying Sheger</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Ethiopia.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1104" data-file-width="960" decoding="async" height="357" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Ethiopia.svg/310px-K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Ethiopia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Ethiopia.svg/465px-K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Ethiopia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Ethiopia.svg/620px-K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Ethiopia.svg.png 2x" width="310"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:K%C3%B6ppen_climate_types_of_Ethiopia.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen climate classification</a> of Ethiopia</div></div></div>
<p>The predominant climate type is tropical monsoon, with wide topographic-induced variation. The <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Highlands" title="Ethiopian Highlands">Ethiopian Highlands</a> cover most of the country and have a climate which is generally considerably cooler than other regions at similar proximity to the Equator. Most of the country's major cities are located at elevations of around 2,000–2,500 m (6,562–8,202 ft) above sea level, including historic capitals such as Gondar and Axum.
</p><p>The modern capital, Addis Ababa, is situated on the foothills of <a href="/wiki/Mount_Entoto" title="Mount Entoto">Mount Entoto</a> at an elevation of around 2,400 metres (7,900 ft). It experiences a mild climate year round. With temperatures fairly uniform year round, the seasons in Addis Ababa are largely defined by rainfall: a dry season from October to February, a light rainy season from March to May, and a heavy rainy season from June to September. The average annual rainfall is approximately 1,200 millimetres (47 in).
</p><p>There are on average seven hours of sunshine per day. The dry season is the sunniest time of the year, though even at the height of the rainy season in July and August there are still usually several hours per day of bright sunshine. The average annual temperature in Addis Ababa is 16 °C (60.8 °F), with daily maximum temperatures averaging 20–25 °C (68.0–77.0 °F) throughout the year, and overnight lows averaging 5–10 °C (41.0–50.0 °F).
</p><p>Most major cities and tourist sites in Ethiopia lie at a similar elevation to Addis Ababa and have a comparable climate. In less elevated regions, particularly the lower lying <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_xeric_grasslands_and_shrublands" title="Ethiopian xeric grasslands and shrublands">Ethiopian xeric grasslands and shrublands</a> in the east of Ethiopia, the climate can be significantly hotter and drier. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dallol,_Ethiopia" title="Dallol, Ethiopia">Dallol</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Danakil_Depression" title="Danakil Depression">Danakil Depression</a> in this eastern zone, has the world's highest average annual temperature of 34 °C (93.2 °F).
</p><p>Ethiopia is vulnerable to many of the effects of climate change. These include increases in temperature and changes in precipitation. Climate change in these forms threatens food security and the economy, which is agriculture based.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[294]</a></sup> Many Ethiopians have been forced to leave their homes and travel as far as the Gulf, Southern Africa and Europe.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[295]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since April 2019, the Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed has promoted <a href="/wiki/Beautifying_Sheger" title="Beautifying Sheger">Beautifying Sheger</a>, a development project that aims to reduce the negative effects of climate change – among other things – in the capital city Addis Ababa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[296]</a></sup> In the following May, the government held "Dine for Sheger", a fundraising event in order to cover some of the $1 billion needed through the public.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[297]</a></sup> $25 million was raised through the expensive event, both through the cost of attending and donations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[298]</a></sup> Two Chinese railway companies under the <a href="/wiki/Belt_and_Road_Initiative" title="Belt and Road Initiative">Belt and Road Initiative</a> between China and Ethiopia had supplied funds to develop 12 of the total 56 kilometres.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[299]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Ethiopia" title="Wildlife of Ethiopia">Wildlife of Ethiopia</a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Environmental_issues_in_Ethiopia" title="Environmental issues in Ethiopia">Environmental issues in Ethiopia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Deforestation_in_Ethiopia" title="Deforestation in Ethiopia">Deforestation in Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mountain_Nyala_(M),_Bale,Ethiopia_(14496349688).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1024" data-file-width="1024" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Mountain_Nyala_%28M%29%2C_Bale%2CEthiopia_%2814496349688%29.jpg/220px-Mountain_Nyala_%28M%29%2C_Bale%2CEthiopia_%2814496349688%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Mountain_Nyala_%28M%29%2C_Bale%2CEthiopia_%2814496349688%29.jpg/330px-Mountain_Nyala_%28M%29%2C_Bale%2CEthiopia_%2814496349688%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/Mountain_Nyala_%28M%29%2C_Bale%2CEthiopia_%2814496349688%29.jpg/440px-Mountain_Nyala_%28M%29%2C_Bale%2CEthiopia_%2814496349688%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mountain_Nyala_(M),_Bale,Ethiopia_(14496349688).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mountain_nyala" title="Mountain nyala">Mountain nyalas</a> in <a href="/wiki/Bale_Mountains_National_Park" title="Bale Mountains National Park">Bale Mountains National Park</a>, one of several wildlife reserves in Ethiopia</div></div></div>
<p>Ethiopia has 31 <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Endemic" title="Endemic">endemic</a> species of mammals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Massicot_300-0"><a href="#cite_note-Massicot-300">[300]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/African_wild_dog" title="African wild dog">African wild dog</a> prehistorically had widespread distribution in the territory. However, with last sightings at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Finicha%27a" title="Finicha'a">Finicha'a</a>, this canid is thought to be potentially <a href="/wiki/Local_extinction" title="Local extinction">locally extinct</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_wolf" title="Ethiopian wolf">Ethiopian wolf</a> is perhaps the most researched of all the endangered species within Ethiopia.
</p><p>Ethiopia is a global centre of avian diversity. To date more than 856 bird species have been recorded in Ethiopia, twenty of which are endemic to the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-301"><a href="#cite_note-301">[301]</a></sup> Sixteen species are endangered or critically endangered. Many of these birds feed on butterflies, like the <i><a href="/wiki/Bicyclus_anynana" title="Bicyclus anynana">Bicyclus anynana</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-302"><a href="#cite_note-302">[302]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#What_information_to_include" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="A complete citation is needed. (March 2021)">full citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Historically, throughout the African continent, wildlife populations have been rapidly declining due to logging, civil wars, pollution, poaching, and other human factors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[303]</a></sup> A 17-year-long civil war, along with severe drought, negatively affected Ethiopia's environmental conditions, leading to even greater habitat degradation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[304]</a></sup> Habitat destruction is a factor that leads to endangerment. When changes to a habitat occur rapidly, animals do not have time to adjust. Human impact threatens many species, with greater threats expected as a result of climate change induced by <a href="/wiki/Greenhouse_gas" title="Greenhouse gas">greenhouse gases</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[305]</a></sup> With carbon dioxide emissions in 2010 of 6,494,000 tonnes, Ethiopia contributes just 0.02% to the annual human-caused release of greenhouse gases.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-306"><a href="#cite_note-306">[306]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ethiopia has many species listed as critically endangered and vulnerable to global extinction. The threatened species in Ethiopia can be broken down into three categories (based on <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IUCN" title="IUCN">IUCN</a> ratings): <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Critically_endangered" title="Critically endangered">critically endangered</a>, <a href="/wiki/Endangered_species" title="Endangered species">endangered</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vulnerable_species" title="Vulnerable species">vulnerable</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Massicot_300-1"><a href="#cite_note-Massicot-300">[300]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ethiopia is one of the eight fundamental and independent <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Centres_of_origin" title="Centres of origin">centres of origin</a> for cultivated plants in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-307"><a href="#cite_note-307">[307]</a></sup> However, deforestation is a major concern for Ethiopia as studies suggest loss of forest contributes to soil erosion, loss of nutrients in the soil, loss of animal habitats, and reduction in biodiversity. At the beginning of the 20th century, around 420,000 km<sup>2</sup> (or 35%) of Ethiopia's land was covered by trees, but recent research indicates that forest cover is now approximately 11.9% of the area.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[308]</a></sup> The country had a 2018 <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 7.16/10, ranking it 50th globally out of 172 countries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_309-0"><a href="#cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-309">[309]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ethiopia loses an estimated 1,410 km<sup>2</sup> of natural forests each year due to firewood collection, conversion to farmland, overgrazing, and use of forest wood for building material. Between 1990 and 2005 the country lost approximately 21,000 km<sup>2</sup> of forests.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-310"><a href="#cite_note-310">[310]</a></sup> Current government programs to control deforestation consist of education, promoting reforestation programs, and providing raw materials which are alternatives to timber. In rural areas the government also provides non-timber fuel sources and access to non-forested land to promote agriculture without destroying forest habitat.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2008)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-311"><a href="#cite_note-311">[311]</a></sup>
</p><p>Organizations such as SOS and Farm Africa are working with the federal government and local governments to create a system of forest management.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[312]</a></sup> Working with a grant of approximately 2.3 million Euros, the Ethiopian government recently began training people on reducing erosion and using proper irrigation techniques that do not contribute to deforestation. This project is assisting more than 80 communities.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2008)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Ethiopia" title="Economy of Ethiopia">Economy of Ethiopia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Industrial_sector_in_Ethiopia" title="Industrial sector in Ethiopia">Industrial sector in Ethiopia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_aid_to_Ethiopia" title="Foreign aid to Ethiopia">Foreign aid to Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GDP_per_capita_development_of_Ethiopia.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="850" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/GDP_per_capita_development_of_Ethiopia.svg/220px-GDP_per_capita_development_of_Ethiopia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/GDP_per_capita_development_of_Ethiopia.svg/330px-GDP_per_capita_development_of_Ethiopia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/GDP_per_capita_development_of_Ethiopia.svg/440px-GDP_per_capita_development_of_Ethiopia.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GDP_per_capita_development_of_Ethiopia.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Development of GDP per capita</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ethiopia_Product_Exports_(2019).svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="715" data-file-width="1100" decoding="async" height="228" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Ethiopia_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/350px-Ethiopia_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Ethiopia_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/525px-Ethiopia_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Ethiopia_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg/700px-Ethiopia_Product_Exports_%282019%29.svg.png 2x" width="350"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ethiopia_Product_Exports_(2019).svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A proportional representation of Ethiopia exports, 2019</div></div></div>
<p>Ethiopia registered the fastest economic growth under <a href="/wiki/Premiership_of_Meles_Zenawi" title="Premiership of Meles Zenawi">Meles Zenawi's administration</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[313]</a></sup>
According to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/IMF" title="IMF">IMF</a>, Ethiopia was one of the fastest growing economies in the world, registering over 10% economic growth from 2004 through 2009.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Outlook_2012_314-0"><a href="#cite_note-Outlook_2012-314">[314]</a></sup> It was the fastest-growing non-oil-dependent African economy in the years 2007 and 2008.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[315]</a></sup> In 2015, the World Bank highlighted that Ethiopia had witnessed rapid economic growth with real domestic product (GDP) growth averaging 10.9% between 2004 and 2014.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-316"><a href="#cite_note-316">[316]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2008 and 2011, Ethiopia's growth performance and considerable development gains were challenged by high <a href="/wiki/Inflation" title="Inflation">inflation</a> and a difficult <a href="/wiki/Balance_of_payments" title="Balance of payments">balance of payments</a> situation. Inflation surged to 40% in August 2011 because of loose <a href="/wiki/Monetary_policy" title="Monetary policy">monetary policy</a>, large <a href="/wiki/Civil_service" title="Civil service">civil service</a> wage increase in early 2011, and high food prices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ethiopia_Overview_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ethiopia_Overview-317">[317]</a></sup> For 2011–12, end-year inflation was projected to be about 22%, and single digit inflation is projected in 2012–13 with the implementation of tight monetary and fiscal policies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-statement_318-0"><a href="#cite_note-statement-318">[318]</a></sup>
</p><p>In spite of fast growth in recent years, GDP per capita is one of the lowest in the world, and the economy faces a number of serious structural problems. However, with a focused investment in public infrastructure and industrial parks, Ethiopia's economy is addressing its structural problems to become a hub for light manufacturing in Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[319]</a></sup> In 2019 a law was passed allowing expatriate Ethiopians to invest in Ethiopia's financial service industry.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[320]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Ethiopian constitution specifies that rights to own land belong only to "the state and the people", but citizens may lease land for up to 99 years, but are unable to mortgage or sell. Renting out land for a maximum of twenty years is allowed and this is expected to ensure that land goes to the most productive user. Land distribution and administration is considered an area where corruption is institutionalized, and facilitation payments as well as bribes are often demanded when dealing with land-related issues.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[321]</a></sup> As there is no land ownership, infrastructural projects are most often simply done without asking the land users, which then end up being displaced and without a home or land. A lot of anger and distrust sometimes results in public protests. In addition, agricultural productivity remains low, and frequent droughts still beset the country, also leading to internal displacement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[322]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy_and_hydropower">Energy and hydropower</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Ethiopia" title="Energy in Ethiopia">Energy in Ethiopia</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_power_stations_in_Ethiopia" title="List of power stations in Ethiopia">List of power stations in Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Renaissance_Dam_site.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="683" data-file-width="496" decoding="async" height="303" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Renaissance_Dam_site.jpg/220px-Renaissance_Dam_site.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Renaissance_Dam_site.jpg/330px-Renaissance_Dam_site.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/Renaissance_Dam_site.jpg/440px-Renaissance_Dam_site.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Renaissance_Dam_site.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Layout of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grand_Renaissance_Dam" title="Grand Renaissance Dam">Grand Renaissance Dam</a></div></div></div>
<p>Ethiopia has 14 major rivers flowing from its highlands, including the Nile. It has the largest water reserves in Africa. As of 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ethiopia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, hydroelectric plants represented around 88.2% of the total installed electricity generating capacity.
</p><p>The remaining electrical power was generated from fossil fuels (8.3%) and renewable sources (3.6%).
</p><p>The electrification rate for the total population in 2016 was 42%, with 85% coverage in urban areas and 26% coverage in rural areas. As of 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ethiopia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, total electricity production was 11.15 TW⋅h and consumption was 9.062 TW⋅h. There were 0.166 TW⋅h of electricity exported, 0 kW⋅h imported, and 2.784 GW of installed generating capacity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA2_18-1"><a href="#cite_note-CIA2-18">[18]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ethiopia delivers roughly 81% of water volume to the Nile through the river basins of the <a href="/wiki/Blue_Nile" title="Blue Nile">Blue Nile</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sobat_River" title="Sobat River">Sobat River</a> and <a href="/wiki/Atbara" title="Atbara">Atbara</a>. In 1959, Egypt and Sudan signed a bilateral treaty, the <a href="/wiki/Water_politics_in_the_Nile_Basin" title="Water politics in the Nile Basin">1959 Nile Waters Agreement</a>, which gave both countries exclusive maritime rights over the Nile waters. Ever since, Egypt has discouraged almost all projects in Ethiopia that sought to utilize the local Nile tributaries. This had the effect of discouraging external financing of hydropower and irrigation projects in western Ethiopia, thereby impeding water resource-based economic development projects. However, Ethiopia is in the process of constructing a large 6,450 MW hydroelectric dam on the Blue Nile river. When completed, this <a href="/wiki/Grand_Ethiopian_Renaissance_Dam" title="Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam">Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam</a> is slated to be the largest hydroelectric power station in Africa.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[323]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Gilgel_Gibe_III_Dam" title="Gilgel Gibe III Dam">Gibe III</a> hydroelectric project is so far the largest in the country with an installed capacity of 1,870 MW. For the year 2017–18 (2010 E.C) this hydroelectric dam generated 4,900 GW⋅h.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-324"><a href="#cite_note-324">[324]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture">Agriculture</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Ethiopia" title="Agriculture in Ethiopia">Agriculture in Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tef_in_Ethiopia_01.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2244" data-file-width="3294" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Tef_in_Ethiopia_01.jpg/220px-Tef_in_Ethiopia_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Tef_in_Ethiopia_01.jpg/330px-Tef_in_Ethiopia_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Tef_in_Ethiopia_01.jpg/440px-Tef_in_Ethiopia_01.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tef_in_Ethiopia_01.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Eragrostis_tef" title="Eragrostis tef">Tef</a> field near <a href="/wiki/Mojo,_Ethiopia" title="Mojo, Ethiopia">Mojo</a></div></div></div>
<p>Agriculture constitutes around 85% of the labour force. However, the service sector represents the largest portion of the <a href="/wiki/Gross_domestic_product" title="Gross domestic product">GDP</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA2_18-2"><a href="#cite_note-CIA2-18">[18]</a></sup> Many other economic activities depend on agriculture, including marketing, processing, and export of agricultural products. Production is overwhelmingly by small-scale farmers and enterprises, and a large part of commodity exports are provided by the small agricultural cash-crop sector. Principal crops include <a href="/wiki/Coffea" title="Coffea">coffee</a>, <a href="/wiki/Legume" title="Legume">legumes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rapeseed" title="Rapeseed">oilseeds</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cereal" title="Cereal">cereals</a>, potatoes, <a href="/wiki/Sugarcane" title="Sugarcane">sugarcane</a>, and vegetables. Ethiopia is also a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Center_of_origin" title="Center of origin">Vavilov</a> centre of diversity for domesticated crops, including <a href="/wiki/Ensete_ventricosum" title="Ensete ventricosum">enset</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[325]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Coffee_bean" title="Coffee bean">coffee</a> and <a href="/wiki/Teff" title="Teff">teff</a>.
</p><p>Exports are almost entirely agricultural commodities (with the exception of <a href="/wiki/Gold" title="Gold">Gold</a> exports), and coffee is the largest foreign exchange earner. Ethiopia is Africa's second biggest <a href="/wiki/Maize" title="Maize">maize</a> producer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[326]</a></sup> According to UN estimations the per capita GDP of Ethiopia has reached $357 as of 2011<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ethiopia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_327-0"><a href="#cite_note-auto-327">[327]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Exports">Exports</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Coffee_production_in_Ethiopia" title="Coffee production in Ethiopia">Coffee production in Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Treemap_on_exports_of_Ethiopia_2014_(mid_detail).png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="427" data-file-width="1055" decoding="async" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Treemap_on_exports_of_Ethiopia_2014_%28mid_detail%29.png/350px-Treemap_on_exports_of_Ethiopia_2014_%28mid_detail%29.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Treemap_on_exports_of_Ethiopia_2014_%28mid_detail%29.png/525px-Treemap_on_exports_of_Ethiopia_2014_%28mid_detail%29.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Treemap_on_exports_of_Ethiopia_2014_%28mid_detail%29.png/700px-Treemap_on_exports_of_Ethiopia_2014_%28mid_detail%29.png 2x" width="350"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Treemap_on_exports_of_Ethiopia_2014_(mid_detail).png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ethiopia Export Treemap from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/MIT" title="MIT">MIT</a>–<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Harvard" title="Harvard">Harvard</a> <a href="/wiki/The_Observatory_of_Economic_Complexity" title="The Observatory of Economic Complexity">Economic Complexity Observatory</a> (2014)<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ethiopia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Ethiopia is often considered as the birthplace of <a href="/wiki/Coffee" title="Coffee">coffee</a> since cultivation began in the 9th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:6_328-0"><a href="#cite_note-:6-328">[328]</a></sup> Exports from Ethiopia in the 2009–2010 financial year totalled US$1.4 billion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[329]</a></sup> Ethiopia produces more coffee than any other nation on the continent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[330]</a></sup> "Coffee provides a livelihood for close to 15 million Ethiopians, 16% of the population. Farmers in the eastern part of the country, where a warming climate is already impacting production, have struggled in recent years, and many are currently reporting largely failed harvests as a result of a prolonged drought".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[331]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ethiopia also has the 5th largest inventory of <a href="/wiki/Arado_cattle" title="Arado cattle">cattle</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[332]</a></sup> Other main export commodities are <a href="/wiki/Khat" title="Khat">khat</a>, gold, leather products, and oilseeds. Recent development of the <a href="/wiki/Floriculture" title="Floriculture">floriculture</a> sector means Ethiopia is poised to become one of the top flower and plant exporters in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[333]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Blessed_Coffee_brand_bags.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2832" data-file-width="4256" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Blessed_Coffee_brand_bags.jpg/220px-Blessed_Coffee_brand_bags.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Blessed_Coffee_brand_bags.jpg/330px-Blessed_Coffee_brand_bags.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Blessed_Coffee_brand_bags.jpg/440px-Blessed_Coffee_brand_bags.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Blessed_Coffee_brand_bags.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Ethiopian <i>Blessed Coffee</i> branded bags in the United States. Coffee is one of main exports of Ethiopia.</div></div></div>
<p>Cross-border trade by pastoralists is often informal and beyond state control and regulation. In <a href="/wiki/East_Africa" title="East Africa">East Africa</a>, over 95% of cross-border trade is through unofficial channels. The unofficial trade of live cattle, camels, sheep, and goats from Ethiopia sold to <a href="/wiki/Somalia" title="Somalia">Somalia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Djibouti" title="Djibouti">Djibouti</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kenya" title="Kenya">Kenya</a> generates an estimated total value of between 250 and US$300 million annually (100 times more than the official figure).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ODI_334-0"><a href="#cite_note-ODI-334">[334]</a></sup>
</p><p>This trade helps lower food prices, increase food security, relieve border tensions, and promote regional integration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ODI_334-1"><a href="#cite_note-ODI-334">[334]</a></sup> However, the unregulated and undocumented nature of this trade runs risks, such as allowing disease to spread more easily across national borders. Furthermore, the government of Ethiopia is purportedly unhappy with lost tax revenue and foreign exchange revenues.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ODI_334-2"><a href="#cite_note-ODI-334">[334]</a></sup> Recent initiatives have sought to document and regulate this trade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ODI_334-3"><a href="#cite_note-ODI-334">[334]</a></sup>
</p><p>With the private sector growing slowly, designer leather products like bags are becoming a big export business, with Taytu becoming the first luxury designer label in the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[335]</a></sup> Additional small-scale export products include cereals, pulses, cotton, sugarcane, potatoes, and hides. With the construction of various new dams and growing hydroelectric power projects around the country, Ethiopia also plans to export electric power to its neighbours.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[336]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[337]</a></sup>
</p><p>Most regard Ethiopia's large water resources and potential as its "white oil" and its coffee resources as "black gold".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[338]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[339]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ethiopia also has large mineral resources and oil potential in some of the less inhabited regions. Political instability in those regions, however, has inhibited development. Ethiopian geologists were implicated in a major gold swindle in 2008. Four chemists and geologists from the Ethiopian Geological Survey were arrested in connection with a fake gold scandal, following complaints from buyers in South Africa. Gold bars from the National Bank of Ethiopia were found by police to be gilded metal, costing the state around US$17 million, according to the Science and Development Network website.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[340]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2011, the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Ethiopian_Renaissance_Dam" title="Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam">Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam</a> project was commenced. When completed, it will provide surplus <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Ethiopia" title="Energy in Ethiopia">energy in Ethiopia</a> which will be available for export to neighbouring countries.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Ethiopia" title="Transport in Ethiopia">Transport in Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Addis_Ababa_Light_Rail_vehicle,_March_2015.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Addis_Ababa_Light_Rail_vehicle%2C_March_2015.jpg/220px-Addis_Ababa_Light_Rail_vehicle%2C_March_2015.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Addis_Ababa_Light_Rail_vehicle%2C_March_2015.jpg/330px-Addis_Ababa_Light_Rail_vehicle%2C_March_2015.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Addis_Ababa_Light_Rail_vehicle%2C_March_2015.jpg/440px-Addis_Ababa_Light_Rail_vehicle%2C_March_2015.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Addis_Ababa_Light_Rail_vehicle,_March_2015.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa_Light_Rail" title="Addis Ababa Light Rail">Light rail</a> in <a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa" title="Addis Ababa">Addis Ababa</a>, Ethiopia</div></div></div>
<p>Ethiopia has 926 km of electrified <span class="nowrap">1,435 mm</span> (<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1020198016">.mw-parser-output .frac{white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output .frac .num,.mw-parser-output .frac .den{font-size:80%;line-height:0;vertical-align:super}.mw-parser-output .frac .den{vertical-align:sub}.mw-parser-output .sr-only{border:0;clip:rect(0,0,0,0);height:1px;margin:-1px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;position:absolute;width:1px}</style><span class="nowrap">4 ft <span class="frac" role="math">8<span class="sr-only">+</span><span class="num">1</span>⁄<span class="den">2</span></span> in</span>) <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Standard_gauge" title="Standard gauge">standard gauge</a> railways, 656 km for the <a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa%E2%80%93Djibouti_Railway" title="Addis Ababa–Djibouti Railway">Addis Ababa–Djibouti Railway</a> between Addis Ababa and the <a href="/wiki/Port_of_Djibouti" title="Port of Djibouti">Port of Djibouti</a> (via <a href="/wiki/Awash,_Ethiopia" title="Awash, Ethiopia">Awash</a>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[341]</a></sup> and 270 km for the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Awash%E2%80%93Hara_Gebeya_Railway" title="Awash–Hara Gebeya Railway">Awash–Hara Gebeya Railway</a> between Addis Ababa and the <a href="/wiki/Twin_cities" title="Twin cities">twin cities</a> of <a href="/wiki/Dessie" title="Dessie">Dessie</a>/<a href="/wiki/Kombolcha" title="Kombolcha">Kombolcha</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AKH_342-0"><a href="#cite_note-AKH-342">[342]</a></sup> (also via Awash). Both railways are either in trial service or still under construction as of August 2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ethiopia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>. Once commissioned and fully operational in 2018–2019, both railways will allow passenger transport with a designated speed of 120 km/hour and freight transport with a speed of ~80 km/hour. Expected travel time from Addis Ababa to <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Djibouti_City" title="Djibouti City">Djibouti City</a> for passengers would be less than twelve hours and travel time from Addis Ababa to Dessie/Kombolcha would be around six hours.
</p><p>Beyond the first 270 km of the Awash–Hara Gebeya Railway, a second construction phase over 120 km foresees the extension of this railway from Dessie/Kombolcha to <a href="/wiki/Hara_Gebeya" title="Hara Gebeya">Hara Gebeya</a>/<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Woldiya" title="Woldiya">Woldiya</a>. It is not clear, when this section will be built and opened.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[343]</a></sup> A third, northern 216 km long railway is also under construction between Mek'ele and Woldiya, but it is also not clear when this railway will be commissioned and opened.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[344]</a></sup> All railways are part of a future railway network of more than 5,000 km of railways, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Railway_Network_of_Ethiopia" title="National Railway Network of Ethiopia">National Railway Network of Ethiopia</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ethiopian_Airlines_Boeing_787-8_ET-AOS_FRA_2012-10-28.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="799" data-file-width="1199" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Ethiopian_Airlines_Boeing_787-8_ET-AOS_FRA_2012-10-28.png/220px-Ethiopian_Airlines_Boeing_787-8_ET-AOS_FRA_2012-10-28.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Ethiopian_Airlines_Boeing_787-8_ET-AOS_FRA_2012-10-28.png/330px-Ethiopian_Airlines_Boeing_787-8_ET-AOS_FRA_2012-10-28.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Ethiopian_Airlines_Boeing_787-8_ET-AOS_FRA_2012-10-28.png/440px-Ethiopian_Airlines_Boeing_787-8_ET-AOS_FRA_2012-10-28.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ethiopian_Airlines_Boeing_787-8_ET-AOS_FRA_2012-10-28.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Boeing_787" title="Boeing 787">Boeing 787-8</a> of <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Airlines" title="Ethiopian Airlines">Ethiopian Airlines</a></div></div></div>
<p>As the first part of a ten-year Road Sector Development Program, between 1997 and 2002 the Ethiopian government began a sustained effort to improve its infrastructure of roads. As a result, as of 2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ethiopia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> Ethiopia has a total (Federal and Regional) of 100,000 km of roads, both paved and gravel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-345"><a href="#cite_note-345">[345]</a></sup>
