</p><p>Ethiopia had 58 airports as of 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ethiopia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA2_18-3"><a href="#cite_note-CIA2-18">[18]</a></sup> and 61 as of 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ethiopia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[346]</a></sup> Among these, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bole_International_Airport" title="Bole International Airport">Bole International Airport</a> in Addis Ababa and the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aba_Tenna_Dejazmach_Yilma_International_Airport" title="Aba Tenna Dejazmach Yilma International Airport">Aba Tenna Dejazmach Yilma International Airport</a> in Dire Dawa accommodate international flights.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Airlines" title="Ethiopian Airlines">Ethiopian Airlines</a>, a member of the <a href="/wiki/Star_Alliance" title="Star Alliance">Star Alliance</a>, is the country's <a href="/wiki/Flag_carrier" title="Flag carrier">flag carrier</a>, and is wholly owned by the <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Ethiopia" title="Government of Ethiopia">Government of Ethiopia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Eaeacp_347-0"><a href="#cite_note-Eaeacp-347">[347]</a></sup> From its hub at the Bole International Airport, the airline serves a network of 102 international passenger, 20 domestic passenger, and 44 cargo destinations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[348]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bpea_349-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bpea-349">[349]</a></sup> It is also one of the fastest-growing carriers in the industry and continent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ceabtdta_350-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ceabtdta-350">[350]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Ethiopia" title="Tourism in Ethiopia">Tourism in Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Semien_Mountains_12.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="867" data-file-width="1300" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Semien_Mountains_12.jpg/220px-Semien_Mountains_12.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Semien_Mountains_12.jpg/330px-Semien_Mountains_12.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Semien_Mountains_12.jpg/440px-Semien_Mountains_12.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Semien_Mountains_12.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Semien_Mountains" title="Semien Mountains">Semien Mountains</a> landscape, 2009</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Ethiopia" title="Tourism in Ethiopia">Tourism</a> is the most popular economic sector in Ethiopia, accounting 5.5% of GDP growth in 2006. In 2015, the <a href="/wiki/European_Council" title="European Council">European Council</a> named Ethiopia "World's Best Tourism Destination".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_351-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-351">[351]</a></sup> In 2020 alone, Ethiopia registered 518,000 tourists, ranked 126th in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-352"><a href="#cite_note-352">[352]</a></sup> Major <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNESCO_World_Heritage_Sites" title="UNESCO World Heritage Sites">UNESCO World Heritage Sites</a> are:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-353"><a href="#cite_note-353">[353]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Axum#Main_sites_of_Axum" title="Axum">Ruins of Aksum</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Lalibela#Churches" title="Lalibela">Rock-Hewn Churches at Lalibela</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Fasil_Ghebbi" title="Fasil Ghebbi">Fasil Ghebbi</a>, Gondar Region</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Harar#Attractions" title="Harar">Harar Jugol</a>, the Fortified Historic Town</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Konso" title="Konso">Konso Cultural Landscape</a></li>
<li>Lower Valley of the <a href="/wiki/Awash_River" title="Awash River">Awash</a></li>
<li>Lower Valley of the <a href="/wiki/Omo_River" title="Omo River">Omo</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Tiya" title="Tiya">Tiya</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Simien_Mountains_National_Park" title="Simien Mountains National Park">Simien Mountains National Park</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Negash_Mosque" title="Negash Mosque">Negash Mosque</a></li></ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Ethiopia" title="Demographics of Ethiopia">Demographics of Ethiopia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Ethiopians" title="Ethiopians">Ethiopians</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_ethnic_groups_in_Ethiopia" title="List of ethnic groups in Ethiopia">List of ethnic groups in Ethiopia</a></div>
<p>Ethiopia is the most populous landlocked country in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ciawfb_354-0"><a href="#cite_note-ciawfb-354">[354]</a></sup> 
Its total population has grown from 38.1 million in 1983 to 109.5 million in 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[355]</a></sup> The population was only about nine million in the 19th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[356]</a></sup> The 2007 Population and Housing Census results show that the population of Ethiopia grew at an average annual rate of 2.6% between 1994 and 2007, down from 2.8% during the period 1983–1994. Currently, the population growth rate is among the top ten countries in the world. The population is forecast to grow to over 210 million by 2060, which would be an increase from 2011 estimates by a factor of about 2.5.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[357]</a></sup> According to UN estimations, life expectancy had improved substantially in recent years with male life expectancy reported to be 56 years and for women 60 years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-auto_327-1"><a href="#cite_note-auto-327">[327]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="barbox tright" style="overflow-x: auto;">

<tr><td colspan="5" style="padding:5px; text-align:left;">Population in millions according to 2007 Census<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2007Census_6-2"><a href="#cite_note-2007Census-6">[6]</a></sup></td></tr>
</tbody></table>
</div>
</div>
<p>Ethiopia's population is highly diverse, containing over 80 different ethnic groups, the four largest of which are the <a href="/wiki/Oromo_people" title="Oromo people">Oromo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amhara_people" title="Amhara people">Amhara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Somalis" title="Somalis">Somali</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tigrayans" title="Tigrayans">Tigrayans</a>. According to the Ethiopian national census of 2007, the <a href="/wiki/Oromo_people" title="Oromo people">Oromo</a> are the largest ethnic group in Ethiopia, at 34.4% of the nation's population. The <a href="/wiki/Amhara_people" title="Amhara people">Amhara</a> represent 27.0% of the country's inhabitants, while <a href="/wiki/Somalis" title="Somalis">Somalis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tigrayans" title="Tigrayans">Tigrayans</a> represent 6.2% and 6.1% of the population respectively. Other prominent ethnic groups are as follows: <a href="/wiki/Sidama_people" title="Sidama people">Sidama</a> 4.0%, <a href="/wiki/Gurage_people" title="Gurage people">Gurage</a> 2.5%, <a href="/wiki/Welayta_people" title="Welayta people">Welayta</a> 2.3%, <a href="/wiki/Afar_people" title="Afar people">Afar</a> 1.7%, <a href="/wiki/Hadiya_people" title="Hadiya people">Hadiya</a> 1.7%, <a href="/wiki/Gamo_people" title="Gamo people">Gamo</a> 1.5% and <a href="/wiki/List_of_ethnic_groups_in_Ethiopia" title="List of ethnic groups in Ethiopia">Others</a> 12.6%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2007Census_6-3"><a href="#cite_note-2007Census-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Afroasiatic_languages" title="Afroasiatic languages">Afroasiatic-speaking</a> communities make up the majority of the population. Among these, Semitic speakers often collectively refer to themselves as the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Habesha_people" title="Habesha people">Habesha people</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a> form of this term (<i>al-Ḥabasha</i>) is the etymological basis of "Abyssinia", the former name of Ethiopia in English and other European languages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[358]</a></sup> Additionally, <a href="/wiki/Nilo-Saharan_languages" title="Nilo-Saharan languages">Nilo-Saharan-speaking</a> ethnic minorities inhabit the southern regions of the country, particularly in areas of the <a href="/wiki/Gambela_Region" title="Gambela Region">Gambela Region</a> which borders <a href="/wiki/South_Sudan" title="South Sudan">South Sudan</a>. The largest ethnic groups among these include the <a href="/wiki/Nuer_people" title="Nuer people">Nuer</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anuak_people" title="Anuak people">Anuak</a>.
</p><p>In addition, Ethiopia had over 75,000 <a href="/wiki/Italians_of_Ethiopia" title="Italians of Ethiopia">Italian settlers</a> during the Italian occupation of the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Istat_2010_359-0"><a href="#cite_note-Istat_2010-359">[359]</a></sup> After independence, many Italians remained for decades after receiving full pardons from Emperor Selassie, as he saw the opportunity to continue modernization efforts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Italoethiopians_360-0"><a href="#cite_note-Italoethiopians-360">[360]</a></sup> However, due to the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Civil_War" title="Ethiopian Civil War">Ethiopian Civil War</a> in 1974, nearly 22,000 Italo-Ethiopians left the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Italoethiopians_360-1"><a href="#cite_note-Italoethiopians-360">[360]</a></sup> In the 2000s, some Italian companies returned to operate in Ethiopia, and many Italian technicians and managers arrived with their families, residing mainly in the metropolitan area of the capital.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[361]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2009, Ethiopia hosted a population of refugees and asylum seekers numbering approximately 135,200. The majority of this population came from Somalia (approximately 64,300 persons), Eritrea (41,700) and Sudan (25,900). The Ethiopian government required nearly all refugees to live in refugee camps.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-World_Refugee_Survey_2009_362-0"><a href="#cite_note-World_Refugee_Survey_2009-362">[362]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Languages">Languages</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Ethiopia" title="Languages of Ethiopia">Languages of Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="PieChartTemplate thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px">

</div>
<div class="thumbcaption">
<p><a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Ethiopia" title="Languages of Ethiopia">Languages of Ethiopia</a> as of 2007<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ethiopia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> Census<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2007Census_6-4"><a href="#cite_note-2007Census-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Green; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Oromo_language" title="Oromo language">Oromo</a> (33.8%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Yellow; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Amharic" title="Amharic">Amharic</a> (29.3%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Red; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Somali_language" title="Somali language">Somali</a> (6.2%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Blue; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Tigrinya_language" title="Tigrinya language">Tigrinya</a> (5.9%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Purple; color:white;"> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sidamo_language" title="Sidamo language">Sidamo</a> (4.0%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Black; color:white;"> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wolaytta_language" title="Wolaytta language">Wolaytta</a> (2.2%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Brown; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Gurage_languages" title="Gurage languages">Gurage</a> (2.0%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Orange; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Afar_language" title="Afar language">Afar</a> (1.7%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Teal; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Hadiyya_language" title="Hadiyya language">Hadiyya</a> (1.7%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Gray; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Gamo-Gofa-Dawro_language" title="Gamo-Gofa-Dawro language">Gamo</a> (1.5%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:white; color:black;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Ethiopia#Overview" title="Languages of Ethiopia">others</a> (11.6%)</div>
</div>
</div></div>
<p>According to <i><a href="/wiki/Ethnologue" title="Ethnologue">Ethnologue</a></i>, there are 90 individual languages spoken in Ethiopia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ethnologue_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ethnologue-363">[363]</a></sup> Most people in the country speak <a href="/wiki/Afroasiatic_languages" title="Afroasiatic languages">Afroasiatic languages</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Cushitic_languages" title="Cushitic languages">Cushitic</a> or <a href="/wiki/Semitic_languages" title="Semitic languages">Semitic</a> branches. The former includes <a href="/wiki/Oromo_language" title="Oromo language">Oromo language</a>, spoken by the <a href="/wiki/Oromo_people" title="Oromo people">Oromo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Somali_language" title="Somali language">Somali</a>, spoken by the <a href="/wiki/Somalis" title="Somalis">Somalis</a>; the latter includes <a href="/wiki/Amharic" title="Amharic">Amharic</a>, spoken by the <a href="/wiki/Amhara_people" title="Amhara people">Amhara</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tigrinya_language" title="Tigrinya language">Tigrinya</a>, spoken by the <a href="/wiki/Tigrayans" title="Tigrayans">Tigrayans</a>. Together, these four groups make up about three-quarters of Ethiopia's population. Other Afroasiatic languages with a significant number of speakers include the Cushitic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sidamo_language" title="Sidamo language">Sidamo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Afar_language" title="Afar language">Afar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hadiyya_language" title="Hadiyya language">Hadiyya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Agaw_languages" title="Agaw languages">Agaw languages</a>, as well as the Semitic <a href="/wiki/Gurage_languages" title="Gurage languages">Gurage languages</a>, <a href="/wiki/Harari_language" title="Harari language">Harari</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Silt%27e_language" title="Silt'e language">Silt'e</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Argobba_language" title="Argobba language">Argobba</a> languages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2007Census_6-5"><a href="#cite_note-2007Census-6">[6]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a>, which also belongs to the Afroasiatic family, is likewise spoken in some areas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-364"><a href="#cite_note-364">[364]</a></sup>
</p><p>Additionally, <a href="/wiki/Omotic_languages" title="Omotic languages">Omotic languages</a> are spoken by Omotic ethnic minority groups inhabiting the southern regions. Among these idioms are <a href="/wiki/Aari_language" title="Aari language">Aari</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bench_language" title="Bench language">Bench</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dime_language" title="Dime language">Dime</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dizin_language" title="Dizin language">Dizin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gamo-Gofa-Dawro_language" title="Gamo-Gofa-Dawro language">Gamo-Gofa-Dawro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maale_language" title="Maale language">Maale</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hamer_language" title="Hamer language">Hamer</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Wolaytta_language" title="Wolaytta language">Wolaytta</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2007Census_6-6"><a href="#cite_note-2007Census-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p><p>Languages from the <a href="/wiki/Nilo-Saharan_languages" title="Nilo-Saharan languages">Nilo-Saharan family</a> are also spoken by ethnic minorities concentrated in the southwestern parts of the country. These languages include <a href="/wiki/Nuer_language" title="Nuer language">Nuer</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anuak_language" title="Anuak language">Anuak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nyangatom_language" title="Nyangatom language">Nyangatom</a>, <a href="/wiki/Majang_language" title="Majang language">Majang</a>, <a href="/wiki/Suri_language" title="Suri language">Suri</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Me%27en_language" title="Me'en language">Me'en</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mursi_language" title="Mursi language">Mursi</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2007Census_6-7"><a href="#cite_note-2007Census-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p><p>English is the most widely spoken foreign language, the medium of instruction in secondary schools and all tertiary education; federal laws are also published in British English in the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Negarit_Gazeta" title="Federal Negarit Gazeta">Federal Negarit Gazeta</a> including the 1995 constitution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FDRE_365-0"><a href="#cite_note-FDRE-365">[365]</a></sup>
</p><p>Amharic was the language of primary school instruction, but has been replaced in many areas by regional languages such as Oromo, Somali or Tigrinya.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Llicuv_366-0"><a href="#cite_note-Llicuv-366">[366]</a></sup> While all languages enjoy equal state recognition in the <a href="/wiki/1995_Constitution_of_Ethiopia" title="1995 Constitution of Ethiopia">1995 Constitution of Ethiopia</a> and Oromo is the most populous language by native speakers, Amharic is the most populous by number of total speakers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Constitution2_185-1"><a href="#cite_note-Constitution2-185">[185]</a></sup>
</p><p>The various <a href="/wiki/Regions_of_Ethiopia" title="Regions of Ethiopia">regions of Ethiopia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Charter_city" title="Charter city">chartered cities</a> are free to determine their own working languages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Llicuv_366-1"><a href="#cite_note-Llicuv-366">[366]</a></sup> Amharic is recognised as the official working language of <a href="/wiki/Amhara_Region" title="Amhara Region">Amhara Region</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Benishangul-Gumuz" title="Benishangul-Gumuz">Benishangul-Gumuz</a>, <a href="/wiki/Southern_Nations,_Nationalities,_and_Peoples%27_Region" title="Southern Nations, Nationalities, and Peoples' Region">Southern Nations, Nationalities, and Peoples' Region</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gambela_Region" title="Gambela Region">Gambela Region</a>, <a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa" title="Addis Ababa">Addis Ababa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dire_Dawa" title="Dire Dawa">Dire Dawa</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-367"><a href="#cite_note-367">[367]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Oromo_language" title="Oromo language">Oromo language</a> serves as the official working language and the primary language of education in the Oromia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CIA2_18-4"><a href="#cite_note-CIA2-18">[18]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Harar" title="Harar">Harar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dire_Dawa" title="Dire Dawa">Dire Dawa</a> and of the <a href="/wiki/Oromia_Zone" title="Oromia Zone">Oromia Zone</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Amhara_Region" title="Amhara Region">Amhara Region</a>. Somali is the official working language of <a href="/wiki/Somali_Region" title="Somali Region">Somali Region</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dire_Dawa" title="Dire Dawa">Dire Dawa</a>, while Afar,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[368]</a></sup> Harari,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-369"><a href="#cite_note-369">[369]</a></sup> and Tigrinya<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[370]</a></sup> are recognized as official working languages in their respective regions. Recently the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Government" title="Ethiopian Government">Ethiopian Government</a> announced that <a href="/wiki/Afar_language" title="Afar language">Afar</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Amharic_language" title="Amharic language">Amharic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oromo_language" title="Oromo language">Oromo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Somali_language" title="Somali language">Somali</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tigrinya_language" title="Tigrinya language">Tigrinya</a> are adopted as official federal working languages of Ethiopia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ventures_1-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ventures-1">[1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nazret_2-1"><a href="#cite_note-Nazret-2">[2]</a></sup>
<a href="/wiki/Italian_language" title="Italian language">Italian</a> is still spoken by some parts of the population, mostly among the older generation, and is taught in some schools (most notably the <a href="/wiki/Istituto_Statale_Italiano_Omnicomprensivo_di_Addis_Abeba" title="Istituto Statale Italiano Omnicomprensivo di Addis Abeba">Istituto Statale Italiano Omnicomprensivo di Addis Abeba</a>). Amharic and Tigrinya have both borrowed some words from the Italian language.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Yaqob_371-0"><a href="#cite_note-Yaqob-371">[371]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-altervista_372-0"><a href="#cite_note-altervista-372">[372]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Script">Script</span></h4>
<p>Ethiopia's principal orthography is the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ge%27ez_script" title="Ge'ez script">Ge'ez script</a>. Employed as an <a href="/wiki/Abugida" title="Abugida">abugida</a> for several of the country's languages, it first came into usage in the 6th and 5th centuries BCE as an <a href="/wiki/Abjad" title="Abjad">abjad</a> to transcribe the Semitic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ge%27ez_language" title="Ge'ez language">Ge'ez language</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-373"><a href="#cite_note-373">[373]</a></sup> Ge'ez now serves as the liturgical language of both the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Orthodox_Tewahedo_Church" title="Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church">Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eritrean_Orthodox_Tewahedo_Church" title="Eritrean Orthodox Tewahedo Church">Eritrean Orthodox Tewahedo</a> Churches. During the 1980s, the Ethiopic character set was computerized. It is today part of the <a href="/wiki/Unicode" title="Unicode">Unicode</a> standard as Ethiopic, <a href="/wiki/Ethiopic_Extended" title="Ethiopic Extended">Ethiopic Extended</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ethiopic_Supplement" title="Ethiopic Supplement">Ethiopic Supplement</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ethiopic_Extended-A" title="Ethiopic Extended-A">Ethiopic Extended-A</a>.
</p><p>Other <a href="/wiki/Writing_system" title="Writing system">writing systems</a> have also been used over the years by different Ethiopian communities. The latter include <a href="/wiki/Bakri_Sapalo" title="Bakri Sapalo">Bakri Sapalo</a>'s script for <a href="/wiki/Oromo_language" title="Oromo language">Oromo</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-HH-551_374-0"><a href="#cite_note-HH-551-374">[374]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Ethiopia" title="Religion in Ethiopia">Religion in Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="PieChartTemplate thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px">
<div class="mw-no-invert" style="background-color:white;margin:auto;position:relative;width:200px;height:200px;overflow:hidden;border-radius:100px;border:1px solid black;transform:scaleX(-1)rotate(-90deg)">
<div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:0; top:0; border-width:0 200px 200px 0; border-color:Red"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;left:100px; top:100px; border-width:100px 0 0 1987.7609902728px; border-left-color:Yellow"></div>

<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 100px 200px 0;border-color:Green"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:100px; border-width:88.523131133246px 46.515107807746px 0 0; border-top-color:Purple"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Purple"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:100px; border-width:86.392341719284px 50.362320163576px 0 0; border-top-color:Blue"></div>
<div style="position:absolute;line-height:0;border-style:solid;left:0;top:0;border-width:0 200px 100px 0;border-color:Blue"></div><div style="border:solid transparent;background-color: initial;position:absolute;width:100px;line-height:0;right:100px; top:0; border-width:0 243.58297171766px 100px 0; border-right-color:Orchid"></div>

<div class="thumbcaption">
<p>Religion in Ethiopia (2016 estimate)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-375"><a href="#cite_note-375">[375]</a></sup>
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Orchid; color:black;"> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Orthodox_Church" title="Ethiopian Orthodox Church">Ethiopian Orthodoxy</a> (43.8%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Blue; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/P%27ent%27ay" title="P'ent'ay">P'ent'ay</a> (22.8%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Purple; color:white;"> </span> Other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian" title="Christian">Christian</a> (0.7%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Green; color:white;"> </span> <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Ethiopia" title="Islam in Ethiopia">Islam</a> (31.3%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Yellow; color:black;"> </span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Traditional_African_religion" title="Traditional African religion">Traditional faiths</a> (0.6%)</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="legend"><span class="legend-color mw-no-invert" style="background-color:Red; color:black;"> </span> Other (0.8%)</div>
</div>
</div></div>
<p>Ethiopia has close historical ties with all three of the world's major <a href="/wiki/Abrahamic_religions" title="Abrahamic religions">Abrahamic religions</a>. In the 4th century, the Ethiopian empire was one of the first in the world to officially adopt Christianity as the state religion. As a result of the resolutions of the <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Chalcedon" title="Council of Chalcedon">Council of Chalcedon</a>, in 451 the <a href="/wiki/Miaphysitism" title="Miaphysitism">Miaphysites</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-first_seven_376-0"><a href="#cite_note-first_seven-376">[376]</a></sup> which included the vast majority of Christians in Egypt and Ethiopia, were accused of <a href="/wiki/Monophysitism" title="Monophysitism">monophysitism</a> and designated as heretics under the common name of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Coptic_Orthodox_Church_of_Alexandria" title="Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria">Coptic Christianity</a> (see <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oriental_Orthodoxy" title="Oriental Orthodoxy">Oriental Orthodoxy</a>). While no longer distinguished as a state religion, the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Orthodox_Tewahedo_Church" title="Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church">Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church</a> remains the majority <a href="/wiki/Christian_denomination" title="Christian denomination">Christian denomination</a>. There is also a substantial Muslim demographic, representing around a third of the population. Ethiopia was the destination of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/First_Hijrah" title="First Hijrah">First Hijrah</a>, a major emigration in Islamic history. A town in the Tigray Region, <a href="/wiki/Negash" title="Negash">Negash</a> is the oldest Muslim settlement in Africa.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lalibela,_san_giorgio,_esterno_24.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5848" data-file-width="6748" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Lalibela%2C_san_giorgio%2C_esterno_24.jpg/170px-Lalibela%2C_san_giorgio%2C_esterno_24.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Lalibela%2C_san_giorgio%2C_esterno_24.jpg/255px-Lalibela%2C_san_giorgio%2C_esterno_24.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Lalibela%2C_san_giorgio%2C_esterno_24.jpg/340px-Lalibela%2C_san_giorgio%2C_esterno_24.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lalibela,_san_giorgio,_esterno_24.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The subterranean rock-hewn <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Saint_George,_Lalibela" title="Church of Saint George, Lalibela">Church of Saint George</a> in <a href="/wiki/Lalibela" title="Lalibela">Lalibela</a> is a <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>.</div></div></div><p> According to the 2007 National Census, Christians make up 62.8% of the country's population (43.5% Ethiopian Orthodox, 19.3% other denominations), Muslims 33.9%, practitioners of traditional faiths 2.6%, and other religions 0.6%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2007Census_6-8"><a href="#cite_note-2007Census-6">[6]</a></sup> The ratio of the Christian to Muslim population has largely remained stable when compared to previous censuses conducted decades ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bx_377-0"><a href="#cite_note-bx-377">[377]</a></sup> Sunnis form the majority of Muslims with <a href="/wiki/Non-denominational_Muslim" title="Non-denominational Muslim">non-denominational Muslims</a> being the second largest group of Muslims, and <a href="/wiki/Shia_Islam" title="Shia Islam">the Shia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ahmadiyya" title="Ahmadiyya">Ahmadiyyas</a> are a minority. Sunnis are largely <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shafi%27i" title="Shafi'i">Shafi'is</a> or <a href="/wiki/Salafi_movement" title="Salafi movement">Salafis</a>, and there are also many <a href="/wiki/Sufism" title="Sufism">Sufi</a> Muslims there.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-378"><a href="#cite_note-378">[378]</a></sup> The large Muslim population in the northern Afar region has resulted in a Muslim separatist movement called the "Islamic State of Afaria" seeking a <a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">sharia</a>-compliant constitution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-379"><a href="#cite_note-379">[379]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some critics asserted that the Haile Selassie regime had been fabricating the census to present Ethiopia as a Christian country to the outside world, stating that Islam made up 50% of the total population in 1991, based on the 1984 census commissioned by the <a href="/wiki/Derg" title="Derg">Derg</a> regime.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[380]</a></sup> Several Muslim observers and bloggers claim that Muslims are in the majority and disagree with the above census numbers, without providing factual data supporting their claims.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[381]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Axum" title="Kingdom of Axum">Kingdom of Axum</a> was one of the first polities to officially embrace Christianity, when <a href="/wiki/Frumentius" title="Frumentius">Frumentius</a> of <a href="/wiki/Tyre,_Lebanon" title="Tyre, Lebanon">Tyre</a>, called Fremnatos or Abba Selama ("Father of Peace") in Ethiopia, converted Emperor <a href="/wiki/Ezana_of_Axum" title="Ezana of Axum">Ezana</a> during the 4th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-isbn0-313-32273-2_74-1"><a href="#cite_note-isbn0-313-32273-2-74">[74]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ofcansky_382-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ofcansky-382">[382]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a>, Christianity had entered Ethiopia even earlier, when an official in the Ethiopian royal treasury was baptized by <a href="/wiki/Philip_the_Evangelist" title="Philip the Evangelist">Philip the Evangelist</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-383"><a href="#cite_note-383">[383]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:01_-_Priests_dancing_for_Timkat.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2227" data-file-width="3959" decoding="async" height="124" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/01_-_Priests_dancing_for_Timkat.jpg/220px-01_-_Priests_dancing_for_Timkat.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/01_-_Priests_dancing_for_Timkat.jpg/330px-01_-_Priests_dancing_for_Timkat.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/01_-_Priests_dancing_for_Timkat.jpg/440px-01_-_Priests_dancing_for_Timkat.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:01_-_Priests_dancing_for_Timkat.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Orthodox priests dancing during the celebration of <i><a href="/wiki/Timkat" title="Timkat">Timkat</a></i></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Orthodox_Tewahedo_Church" title="Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church">Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church</a> is part of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oriental_Orthodoxy" title="Oriental Orthodoxy">Oriental Orthodoxy</a>. It is by far the largest Christian denomination, although a number of <a href="/wiki/P%27ent%27ay" title="P'ent'ay">P'ent'ay</a> (<a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestant</a>) churches have recently gained ground. Since 1930, a relatively small <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Catholic_Church" title="Ethiopian Catholic Church">Ethiopian Catholic Church</a> has existed in <a href="/wiki/Full_communion" title="Full communion">full communion</a> with Rome, with adherents making up less than 1% of the total population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bx_377-1"><a href="#cite_note-bx-377">[377]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-384"><a href="#cite_note-384">[384]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Me%C5%A1ita_v_Bahir_Daru.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2587" data-file-width="2845" decoding="async" height="200" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Me%C5%A1ita_v_Bahir_Daru.jpg/220px-Me%C5%A1ita_v_Bahir_Daru.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Me%C5%A1ita_v_Bahir_Daru.jpg/330px-Me%C5%A1ita_v_Bahir_Daru.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/47/Me%C5%A1ita_v_Bahir_Daru.jpg/440px-Me%C5%A1ita_v_Bahir_Daru.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Me%C5%A1ita_v_Bahir_Daru.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A mosque in <a href="/wiki/Bahir_Dar" title="Bahir Dar">Bahir Dar</a></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Ethiopia" title="Islam in Ethiopia">Islam in Ethiopia</a> dates back to the founding of the religion in 622 when a group of Muslims were counselled by <a href="/wiki/Muhammad" title="Muhammad">Muhammad</a> to escape persecution in <a href="/wiki/Mecca" title="Mecca">Mecca</a>. The disciples subsequently <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Migrated_to_Abyssinia" title="Migrated to Abyssinia">migrated to Abyssinia</a> via modern-day Eritrea, which was at the time ruled by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ashama_ibn-Abjar" title="Ashama ibn-Abjar">Ashama ibn-Abjar</a>, a pious Christian emperor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ofcansky_382-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ofcansky-382">[382]</a></sup> Also, the largest single ethnic group of <a href="/wiki/List_of_non-Arab_Sahabah" title="List of non-Arab Sahabah">non-Arab Sahabah</a> was that of the Ethiopians.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (February 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>According to the 2007 Population and Housing Census, around 1,957,944 people in Ethiopia are adherents of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Traditional_African_religion" title="Traditional African religion">traditional religions</a>. An additional 471,861 residents practice other creeds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2007Census_6-9"><a href="#cite_note-2007Census-6">[6]</a></sup> While followers of all religions can be found in each region, they tend to be concentrated in certain parts of the country. Christians predominantly live in the northern Amhara and Tigray regions, and are largely members of the non-Chalcedonian Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church. Those belonging to P'ent'ay predominate in the regions of Oromia and the SNNP (Southern Nations, Nationalities, and Peoples' Region). Muslims in Ethiopia predominantly adhere to <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni Islam</a> and generally inhabit eastern and northeastern areas; particularly the Somali, Afar, Dire Dawa and Harari regions. Practitioners of traditional religions mainly reside in the nation's far southwestern and western rural borderlands, in the SNNP, Benishangul-Gumuz and Gambela regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2007Census_6-10"><a href="#cite_note-2007Census-6">[6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ofcansky_382-2"><a href="#cite_note-Ofcansky-382">[382]</a></sup>
</p><p>Until the 1980s, a substantial population of <a href="/wiki/Beta_Israel" title="Beta Israel">Beta Israel</a> / ቤተ እስራኤል / ביתא ישראל (Ethiopian Jews) resided in Ethiopia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ofcansky_382-3"><a href="#cite_note-Ofcansky-382">[382]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-385"><a href="#cite_note-385">[385]</a></sup> About 4,000 Jews, who claim to be one of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lost_tribes_of_Israel" title="Lost tribes of Israel">lost tribes of Israel</a> are estimated to still live in Ethiopia, along with many more members of two related ethno-religious groups, the <a href="/wiki/Falash_Mura" title="Falash Mura">Falash Mura</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Beta_Abraham" title="Beta Abraham">Beta Abraham</a>. The Falash Mura are Beta Israel who, while identifying as Jews, adopted elements of Christianity due to missionary efforts, and now practice a <a href="/wiki/Syncretism" title="Syncretism">syncretic</a> form of Ethiopian Judaism mixed with Christianity; they number about 150,000 people. The Beta Abraham are regarded as a medieval offshoot of the Beta Israel, having incorporated elements of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Traditional_African_religion" title="Traditional African religion">traditional African religion</a>, and number about 8,000. While both still identify as Beta Israel, they exist outside the main community. The official Beta Israel community leaders tentatively accept the Falash Mura, and have requested they be allowed to migrate to Israel. The Beta Abraham have historically been shunned by most other communities, having had a reputation of being "sorcerers". In certain Ethiopian towns and villages such as <a href="/wiki/Wolleka" title="Wolleka">Wolleka</a>, near the Ethiopian city of <a href="/wiki/Gondar" title="Gondar">Gondar</a>, the concentration of Ethiopian-Jews is still significant but the US now has a significantly greater numbers of Ethiopian-Jews than that of Ethiopia.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Human_rights_group" title="Human rights group">Human rights groups</a> have regularly accused the government of arresting activists, journalists and bloggers to stamp out dissent among some religious communities. Lengthy prison terms were handed to 17 Muslim activists on 3<span class="nowrap"> </span>August 2015 ranging from seven to 22 years. They were charged with trying to create an Islamic state in the majority Christian country. All the defendants denied the charges and claimed that they were merely protesting in defence of their rights.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[386]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-387"><a href="#cite_note-387">[387]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[388]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Urbanization">Urbanization</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Ethiopia" title="List of cities and towns in Ethiopia">List of cities and towns in Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Addis_Abeba07_(Sam_Effron).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="848" data-file-width="1280" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Addis_Abeba07_%28Sam_Effron%29.jpg/220px-Addis_Abeba07_%28Sam_Effron%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Addis_Abeba07_%28Sam_Effron%29.jpg/330px-Addis_Abeba07_%28Sam_Effron%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Addis_Abeba07_%28Sam_Effron%29.jpg/440px-Addis_Abeba07_%28Sam_Effron%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Addis_Abeba07_(Sam_Effron).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Street in Addis Ababa</div></div></div>
<p>Population growth, migration, and urbanization are all straining both governments' and ecosystems' capacity to provide people with basic services.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[389]</a></sup> Urbanization has steadily been increasing in Ethiopia, with two periods of significantly rapid growth. First, in 1936–1941 during the Italian occupation under Mussolini's fascist government, and then from 1967 to 1975 when the populations of urban areas tripled.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-countrystudies1991_390-0"><a href="#cite_note-countrystudies1991-390">[390]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1936, Italy annexed Ethiopia, building infrastructure to connect major cities, and a dam providing power and water.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Accessed_15_May_2008_146-1"><a href="#cite_note-Accessed_15_May_2008-146">[146]</a></sup> This along with the influx of Italians and labourers was the major cause of rapid growth during this period. The second period of growth was from 1967 to 1975 when rural populations migrated to towns seeking work and better living conditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-countrystudies1991_390-1"><a href="#cite_note-countrystudies1991-390">[390]</a></sup>
</p><p>This pattern slowed due to the 1975 Land Reform program instituted by the government, which provided incentives for people to stay in rural areas. As people moved from rural areas to the cities, there were fewer people to grow food for the population. The Land Reform Act was meant to increase agriculture since food production was not keeping up with population growth over the period of 1970–1983. This program encouraged the formation of peasant associations, large villages based on agriculture. The legislation did lead to an increase in food production, although there is debate over the cause; it may be related to weather conditions more than the reform.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Anderson,_Frank_1991._Pages_159-175_391-0"><a href="#cite_note-Anderson,_Frank_1991._Pages_159-175-391">[391]</a></sup> Urban populations have continued to grow with an 8.1% increase from 1975 to 2000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Accessed_5-10-08_392-0"><a href="#cite_note-Accessed_5-10-08-392">[392]</a></sup>
</p>
<div>
<table style="font-size:88%;margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; width: 100%; border: 1px solid darkgray; background: #f9f9f9">

<td rowspan="11" style="text-align: center"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Addis_Ababa_(16314616596).jpg" title="Addis Ababa"><img alt="Addis Ababa" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="3365" data-file-width="5054" decoding="async" height="80" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Addis_Ababa_%2816314616596%29.jpg/120px-Addis_Ababa_%2816314616596%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Addis_Ababa_%2816314616596%29.jpg/180px-Addis_Ababa_%2816314616596%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Addis_Ababa_%2816314616596%29.jpg/240px-Addis_Ababa_%2816314616596%29.jpg 2x" width="120"/></a><br/><a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa" title="Addis Ababa">Addis Ababa</a><br/><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gonder_from_the_Goha_hotel.jpg" title="Gondar"><img alt="Gondar" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="2136" data-file-width="2848" decoding="async" height="90" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Gonder_from_the_Goha_hotel.jpg/120px-Gonder_from_the_Goha_hotel.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Gonder_from_the_Goha_hotel.jpg/180px-Gonder_from_the_Goha_hotel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Gonder_from_the_Goha_hotel.jpg/240px-Gonder_from_the_Goha_hotel.jpg 2x" width="120"/></a><br/><a href="/wiki/Gondar" title="Gondar">Gondar</a>

<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">1</td>
<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa" title="Addis Ababa">Addis Ababa</a></td>
<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa" title="Addis Ababa">Addis Ababa</a></td>
<td style="text-align:right;">3,352,000</td>
<td style="text-align:center;background:#f0f0f0;">11</td>
<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Shashamane" title="Shashamane">Shashamane</a></td>
<td style="text-align:left;"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oromia_Region" title="Oromia Region">Oromia</a></td>
<td style="text-align:right;">154,587
</td>
<td rowspan="11" style="text-align: center"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mosque,_Mekele,_Ethiopia_2013_-_panoramio.jpg" title="Mek'ele"><img alt="Mek'ele" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="2736" data-file-width="3648" decoding="async" height="90" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Mosque%2C_Mekele%2C_Ethiopia_2013_-_panoramio.jpg/120px-Mosque%2C_Mekele%2C_Ethiopia_2013_-_panoramio.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Mosque%2C_Mekele%2C_Ethiopia_2013_-_panoramio.jpg/180px-Mosque%2C_Mekele%2C_Ethiopia_2013_-_panoramio.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Mosque%2C_Mekele%2C_Ethiopia_2013_-_panoramio.jpg/240px-Mosque%2C_Mekele%2C_Ethiopia_2013_-_panoramio.jpg 2x" width="120"/></a><br/><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mek%27ele" title="Mek'ele">Mek'ele</a><br/><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:AdamaHotels.jpg" title="Adama"><img alt="Adama" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="1872" data-file-width="2816" decoding="async" height="80" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/AdamaHotels.jpg/120px-AdamaHotels.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/AdamaHotels.jpg/180px-AdamaHotels.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/AdamaHotels.jpg/240px-AdamaHotels.jpg 2x" width="120"/></a><br/><a href="/wiki/Adama" title="Adama">Adama</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>

<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Rural_and_urban_life">Rural and urban life</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Rural_flight_in_Ethiopia" title="Rural flight in Ethiopia">Rural flight in Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gonder_from_the_Goha_hotel.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2136" data-file-width="2848" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Gonder_from_the_Goha_hotel.jpg/220px-Gonder_from_the_Goha_hotel.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Gonder_from_the_Goha_hotel.jpg/330px-Gonder_from_the_Goha_hotel.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Gonder_from_the_Goha_hotel.jpg/440px-Gonder_from_the_Goha_hotel.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gonder_from_the_Goha_hotel.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Gondar" title="Gondar">Gondar</a> skyline</div></div></div>
<p>Migration to urban areas is usually motivated by the hope of better lives. In peasant associations daily life is a struggle to survive. About 16% of the population in Ethiopia lives on less than one dollar per day (2008). Only 65% of rural households in Ethiopia consume the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a>'s (WHO's) minimum standard of food per day (2,200 kilocalories), with 42% of children under 5 years old being underweight.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Crawley_394-0"><a href="#cite_note-Crawley-394">[394]</a></sup>
</p><p>Most poor families (75%) share their sleeping quarters with livestock, and 40% of children sleep on the floor, where nighttime temperatures average 5 degrees Celsius in the cold season.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Crawley_394-1"><a href="#cite_note-Crawley-394">[394]</a></sup> The average family size is six or seven, living in a 30 square metre mud and thatch hut, with less than two hectares of land to cultivate.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Crawley_394-2"><a href="#cite_note-Crawley-394">[394]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:On_The_Road_To_Simien_Mountains_National_Park,_Ethiopia_(2446794591).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1355" data-file-width="2423" decoding="async" height="123" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/On_The_Road_To_Simien_Mountains_National_Park%2C_Ethiopia_%282446794591%29.jpg/220px-On_The_Road_To_Simien_Mountains_National_Park%2C_Ethiopia_%282446794591%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/On_The_Road_To_Simien_Mountains_National_Park%2C_Ethiopia_%282446794591%29.jpg/330px-On_The_Road_To_Simien_Mountains_National_Park%2C_Ethiopia_%282446794591%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/On_The_Road_To_Simien_Mountains_National_Park%2C_Ethiopia_%282446794591%29.jpg/440px-On_The_Road_To_Simien_Mountains_National_Park%2C_Ethiopia_%282446794591%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:On_The_Road_To_Simien_Mountains_National_Park,_Ethiopia_(2446794591).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Rural area in the <a href="/wiki/Simien_Mountains_National_Park" title="Simien Mountains National Park">Simien Mountains National Park</a></div></div></div>
<p>The peasant associations face a cycle of poverty. Since the landholdings are so small, farmers cannot allow the land to lie fallow, which reduces soil fertility.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Crawley_394-3"><a href="#cite_note-Crawley-394">[394]</a></sup> This <a href="/wiki/Land_degradation" title="Land degradation">land degradation</a> reduces the production of fodder for livestock, which causes low milk yields.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Crawley_394-4"><a href="#cite_note-Crawley-394">[394]</a></sup> Since the community burns livestock manure as fuel, rather than plowing the nutrients back into the land, the crop production is reduced.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Crawley_394-5"><a href="#cite_note-Crawley-394">[394]</a></sup> The low productivity of agriculture leads to inadequate incomes for farmers, hunger, malnutrition and disease. These unhealthy farmers have difficulty working the land and the productivity drops further.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Crawley_394-6"><a href="#cite_note-Crawley-394">[394]</a></sup>
</p><p>Although conditions are drastically better in cities, all of Ethiopia suffers from poverty and poor sanitation. However, poverty in Ethiopia fell from 44% to 29.6% during 2000–2011, according to the World Bank.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[395]</a></sup> In the capital city of Addis Ababa, 55% of the population used to live in slums.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Accessed_15_May_2008_146-2"><a href="#cite_note-Accessed_15_May_2008-146">[146]</a></sup> Now, however, a construction boom in both the private and the public sector has led to a dramatic improvement in living standards in major cities, particularly in Addis Ababa. Notably, government-built condominium housing complexes have sprung up throughout the city, benefiting close to 600,000 individuals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[396]</a></sup> Sanitation is the most pressing need in the city, with most of the population lacking access to waste treatment facilities. This contributes to the spread of illness through unhealthy water.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Accessed_15_May_2008_146-3"><a href="#cite_note-Accessed_15_May_2008-146">[146]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Any_Day,_Adigrat_(12582724894).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3264" data-file-width="5915" decoding="async" height="121" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Any_Day%2C_Adigrat_%2812582724894%29.jpg/220px-Any_Day%2C_Adigrat_%2812582724894%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Any_Day%2C_Adigrat_%2812582724894%29.jpg/330px-Any_Day%2C_Adigrat_%2812582724894%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Any_Day%2C_Adigrat_%2812582724894%29.jpg/440px-Any_Day%2C_Adigrat_%2812582724894%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Any_Day,_Adigrat_(12582724894).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Street scene in <a href="/wiki/Adigrat" title="Adigrat">Adigrat</a></div></div></div>
<p>Despite the living conditions in the cities, the people of Addis Ababa are much better off than people living in the peasant associations owing to their educational opportunities. Unlike rural children, 69% of urban children are enrolled in primary school, and 35% of those are eligible to attend secondary school.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (December 2016)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Accessed_15_May_2008_146-4"><a href="#cite_note-Accessed_15_May_2008-146">[146]</a></sup> Addis Ababa has its own <a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa_University" title="Addis Ababa University">university</a> as well as many other secondary schools. The literacy rate is 82%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Accessed_15_May_2008_146-5"><a href="#cite_note-Accessed_15_May_2008-146">[146]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many NGOs (Non-Governmental Organizations) are working to solve this problem; however, most are far apart, uncoordinated, and working in isolation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Accessed_5-10-08_392-1"><a href="#cite_note-Accessed_5-10-08-392">[392]</a></sup> The Sub-Saharan Africa NGO Consortium is attempting to coordinate efforts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Accessed_5-10-08_392-2"><a href="#cite_note-Accessed_5-10-08-392">[392]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health">Health</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Ethiopia" title="Health in Ethiopia">Health in Ethiopia</a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Child_marriage_in_Ethiopia" title="Child marriage in Ethiopia">Child marriage in Ethiopia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Polygamy_in_Ethiopia" title="Polygamy in Ethiopia">Polygamy in Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Child_mortality_in_Sub-Saharan_Africa_and_Ethiopia.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="850" decoding="async" height="155" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Child_mortality_in_Sub-Saharan_Africa_and_Ethiopia.svg/220px-Child_mortality_in_Sub-Saharan_Africa_and_Ethiopia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Child_mortality_in_Sub-Saharan_Africa_and_Ethiopia.svg/330px-Child_mortality_in_Sub-Saharan_Africa_and_Ethiopia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e2/Child_mortality_in_Sub-Saharan_Africa_and_Ethiopia.svg/440px-Child_mortality_in_Sub-Saharan_Africa_and_Ethiopia.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Child_mortality_in_Sub-Saharan_Africa_and_Ethiopia.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Declining child mortality in Sub-Saharan Africa and Ethiopia since 1950</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a>'s 2006 World Health Report gives a figure of 1,936 physicians (for 2003),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[397]</a></sup> which comes to about 2.6 per 100,000. A <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brain_drain" title="Brain drain">brain drain</a> associated with <a href="/wiki/Globalization" title="Globalization">globalization</a> is said to affect the country, with many educated professionals leaving Ethiopia for better economic opportunities in the West.
</p><p>Ethiopia's main health problems are said to be communicable (contagious) diseases worsened by poor sanitation and <a href="/wiki/Malnutrition" title="Malnutrition">malnutrition</a>. Over 44 million people (nearly half the population) do not have access to clean water.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-398"><a href="#cite_note-398">[398]</a></sup> These problems are exacerbated by the shortage of trained doctors and nurses and health facilities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[399]</a></sup>
</p><p>The state of public health is considerably better in the cities. <a href="/wiki/Birth_rate" title="Birth rate">Birth rates</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Infant_mortality_rate" title="Infant mortality rate">infant mortality rates</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Death_rate" title="Death rate">death rates</a> are lower in cities than in rural areas due to better access to education, medicines, and hospitals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Accessed_15_May_2008_146-6"><a href="#cite_note-Accessed_15_May_2008-146">[146]</a></sup> Life expectancy is better in cities compared to rural areas, but there have been significant improvements witnessed throughout the country in recent years, the average Ethiopian living to be 62.2 years old, according to a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/UNDP" title="UNDP">UNDP</a> report.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[400]</a></sup> Despite sanitation being a problem, use of improved water sources is also on the rise; 81% in cities compared to 11% in rural areas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Accessed_5-10-08_392-3"><a href="#cite_note-Accessed_5-10-08-392">[392]</a></sup> As in other parts of Africa, there has been a steady migration of people towards the cities in hopes of better living conditions.
</p><p>In early 2005,<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ethiopia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> the WHO reported that Ethiopia had 119 hospitals (12 in Addis Ababa) and 412 health centres.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-who_2005_401-0"><a href="#cite_note-who_2005-401">[401]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Infant_mortality" title="Infant mortality">Infant mortality</a> rates are relatively high, as 41 infants die per 1,000 live births.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-402"><a href="#cite_note-402">[402]</a></sup> Ethiopia has been able to reduce under-five mortality by two-thirds (one of the <a href="/wiki/Millennium_Development_Goals" title="Millennium Development Goals">Millennium Development Goals</a>) since 1990.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-who_2005_401-1"><a href="#cite_note-who_2005-401">[401]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag failed verification of its source citation(s). (February 2022)">failed verification</span></a></i>]</sup> Although this is a dramatic decrease, birth-related complications such as <a href="/wiki/Obstetric_fistula" title="Obstetric fistula">obstetric fistula</a> affect many of the nation's women.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-403"><a href="#cite_note-403">[403]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/HIV/AIDS_in_Ethiopia" title="HIV/AIDS in Ethiopia">HIV/AIDS in Ethiopia</a> stood at 1.1% in 2014, a dramatic decrease from 4.5% 15 years ago.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The most affected are poor communities and women, due to lack of health education, empowerment, awareness and lack of social well-being. The government of Ethiopia and many international organizations like <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organization</a> (WHO), and the United Nations, are launching campaigns and are working aggressively to improve Ethiopia's health conditions and promote health awareness on AIDS and other communicable diseases.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[404]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Bracing_for_a_short,_sharp_jab.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1296" data-file-width="1944" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Bracing_for_a_short%2C_sharp_jab.jpg/220px-Bracing_for_a_short%2C_sharp_jab.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Bracing_for_a_short%2C_sharp_jab.jpg/330px-Bracing_for_a_short%2C_sharp_jab.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fd/Bracing_for_a_short%2C_sharp_jab.jpg/440px-Bracing_for_a_short%2C_sharp_jab.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Bracing_for_a_short,_sharp_jab.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An Ethiopian girl about to receive her <a href="/wiki/Measles" title="Measles">measles</a> vaccine</div></div></div>
<p>Ethiopia has a relatively high infant and maternal mortality rate. Although, Ethiopia did not meet the MDG target of reducing maternal mortality rate by two-thirds in 2015, there are improvements nonetheless. For instance, the contraception prevalence rate increased from 8.1% in 2000 to 41.8% in 2014, and Antenatal care service coverage increase from 29% to an astounding 98.1% in the same period.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Currently, the maternal mortality rate stands at 420 per 100,000 live births.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (June 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Only a minority of Ethiopians are born in hospitals, while most are born in rural households. Those who are expected to give birth at home have elderly women serve as midwives who assist with the delivery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[405]</a></sup> The "WHO estimates that a majority of maternal fatalities and disabilities could be prevented if deliveries were to take place at well-equipped health centres, with adequately trained staff".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[406]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Community_Health_Workers_(5762479865).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2056" data-file-width="3088" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Community_Health_Workers_%285762479865%29.jpg/220px-Community_Health_Workers_%285762479865%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Community_Health_Workers_%285762479865%29.jpg/330px-Community_Health_Workers_%285762479865%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Community_Health_Workers_%285762479865%29.jpg/440px-Community_Health_Workers_%285762479865%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Community_Health_Workers_(5762479865).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Community health care workers</div></div></div>
<p>The low availability of health-care professionals with modern medical training, together with lack of funds for medical services, leads to the preponderance of less-reliable traditional healers that use home-based therapies to heal common ailments.
</p><p>One common cultural practice, irrespective of religion or economic status, is <a href="/wiki/Female_genital_mutilation" title="Female genital mutilation">female genital mutilation</a> (FGM), also known as female genital cutting (FGC), a procedure that involves partial or total removal of the external female genitalia, or other injury to the female genital organs for non-medical reasons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[407]</a></sup> The practice was made illegal in Ethiopia in 2004.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[408]</a></sup> FGM is a pre-marital custom mainly endemic to Northeast Africa and parts of the <a href="/wiki/Near_East" title="Near East">Near East</a> that has its ultimate origins in <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">Ancient Egypt</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rohayes_409-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rohayes-409">[409]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bodman_410-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bodman-410">[410]</a></sup> Encouraged by women in the community, it is primarily intended to deter promiscuity and to offer protection from assault.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Frayser_411-0"><a href="#cite_note-Frayser-411">[411]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Addis_Ababa_Fistula_Hospital_-_from_Flickr_159817756.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Addis_Ababa_Fistula_Hospital_-_from_Flickr_159817756.jpg/220px-Addis_Ababa_Fistula_Hospital_-_from_Flickr_159817756.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Addis_Ababa_Fistula_Hospital_-_from_Flickr_159817756.jpg/330px-Addis_Ababa_Fistula_Hospital_-_from_Flickr_159817756.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Addis_Ababa_Fistula_Hospital_-_from_Flickr_159817756.jpg/440px-Addis_Ababa_Fistula_Hospital_-_from_Flickr_159817756.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Addis_Ababa_Fistula_Hospital_-_from_Flickr_159817756.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa_Fistula_Hospital" title="Addis Ababa Fistula Hospital">Addis Ababa Fistula Hospital</a></div></div></div>
<p>Ethiopia has a high prevalence of FGM, but prevalence is lower among young girls. Ethiopia's 2005 Demographic and Health Survey (EDHS) noted that the national prevalence rate is 74% among women ages 15–49.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-412"><a href="#cite_note-412">[412]</a></sup> The practice is almost universal in the regions of <a href="/wiki/Dire_Dawa" title="Dire Dawa">Dire Dawa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Somali_Region" title="Somali Region">Somali</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Afar_Region" title="Afar Region">Afar</a>. In the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oromia_Region" title="Oromia Region">Oromo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Harari_Region" title="Harari Region">Harari</a> regions, more than 80% of girls and women undergo the procedure. FGC is least prevalent in the regions of Tigray and Gambela, where 29% and 27% of girls and women, respectively, are affected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[413]</a></sup> According to a 2010 study performed by the Population Reference Bureau, Ethiopia has a prevalence rate of 81% among women ages 35 to 39 and 62% among women ages 15–19.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[414]</a></sup> A 2014 UNICEF report found that only 24% of girls under 14 had undergone FGM.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[415]</a></sup>
</p><p>Male <a href="/wiki/Circumcision" title="Circumcision">circumcision</a> is also practised in the country, and about 76% of Ethiopia's male population is reportedly circumcised.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ahuja_416-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ahuja-416">[416]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Government of the Federal Republic of Ethiopia is signatory to various international conventions and treaties that protect the rights of women and children. Its constitution provides for the fundamental rights and freedoms for women. There is an attempt being made to raise the social and economic status of women through eliminating all legal and customary practices, which hinder women's equal participation in society and undermine their social status.
</p><p>The National Mental Health Strategy, published in 2012, introduced the development of policy designed to improve mental health care in Ethiopia. This strategy mandated that mental health be integrated into the primary health care system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417"><a href="#cite_note-417">[417]</a></sup> However, the success of the National Mental Health Strategy has been limited. For example, the burden of depression is estimated to have increased 34.2% from 2007 to 2017.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-418"><a href="#cite_note-418">[418]</a></sup> Furthermore, the prevalence of stigmatizing attitudes, inadequate leadership and co-ordination of efforts, as well as a lack of mental health awareness in the general population, all remain as obstacles to successful mental health care.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-419"><a href="#cite_note-419">[419]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Ethiopia" title="Education in Ethiopia">Education in Ethiopia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Higher_education_in_Ethiopia" title="Higher education in Ethiopia">Higher education in Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Addis_Abeba_University_(Sam_Effron).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="751" data-file-width="1280" decoding="async" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Addis_Abeba_University_%28Sam_Effron%29.jpg/220px-Addis_Abeba_University_%28Sam_Effron%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Addis_Abeba_University_%28Sam_Effron%29.jpg/330px-Addis_Abeba_University_%28Sam_Effron%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Addis_Abeba_University_%28Sam_Effron%29.jpg/440px-Addis_Abeba_University_%28Sam_Effron%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Addis_Abeba_University_(Sam_Effron).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Entrance of <a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa_University" title="Addis Ababa University">Addis Ababa University</a></div></div></div>
<p>Educational system of Ethiopia was dominated by the <a href="/wiki/Orthodox_Tewahedo" title="Orthodox Tewahedo">Orthodox Tewahedo</a> Church since the Axumite Christian era in 330 CE. An <a href="/wiki/Traditional_education_in_Ethiopia" title="Traditional education in Ethiopia">ancient form of Ethiopian Christian education</a> was conducted by clergymen, with highly emphasized its dogma. Graduation of students leads to earning priesthood and intellectual elite known as <a href="/wiki/Debtera" title="Debtera">debtera</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[420]</a></sup> Modern education was introduced in 1908 when Emperor Menelik II opened the first school in Addis Ababa, <a href="/wiki/Menelik_II_School" title="Menelik II School">Menelik II School</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[421]</a></sup> In addition, Emperor Haile Selassie also contributed to open the first university, <a href="/wiki/Addis_Ababa_University" title="Addis Ababa University">Addis Ababa University</a>, founded in 1950 after it was renamed "Haile Selassie I University" until 1975. More recently, the government is improving numerous regional universities and facilities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[422]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Plants_in_a_Laboratory_for_High_School_Science,_Addis_Ababa.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2448" data-file-width="3264" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Plants_in_a_Laboratory_for_High_School_Science%2C_Addis_Ababa.jpg/220px-Plants_in_a_Laboratory_for_High_School_Science%2C_Addis_Ababa.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Plants_in_a_Laboratory_for_High_School_Science%2C_Addis_Ababa.jpg/330px-Plants_in_a_Laboratory_for_High_School_Science%2C_Addis_Ababa.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Plants_in_a_Laboratory_for_High_School_Science%2C_Addis_Ababa.jpg/440px-Plants_in_a_Laboratory_for_High_School_Science%2C_Addis_Ababa.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Plants_in_a_Laboratory_for_High_School_Science,_Addis_Ababa.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Plants in a laboratory of <a href="/wiki/Ethio-Parents%27_School" title="Ethio-Parents' School">Ethio-Parents' School</a> in Addis Ababa</div></div></div>
<p>The current system follows school expansion schemes which are very similar to the system in the rural areas during the 1980s, with an addition of deeper regionalization, providing rural education in students' own languages starting at the elementary level, and with more budgetary financing allocated to the education sector. Public education is free at primary levels and usually offers between age 7 and 12.
