The sequence of general education in Ethiopia is six years of primary school, then four years of lower secondary school followed by two years of higher secondary school.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-423"><a href="#cite_note-423">[423]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Ethiopian education is governed by <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Education_(Ethiopia)" title="Ministry of Education (Ethiopia)">Ministry of Education</a> and its cycle consists 4+4+2+2 system; elementary education consists of eight years, divided into two cycles of four years, and four years of secondary education, divided into two stages of two years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[424]</a></sup> National exams are conducted by the <a href="/wiki/National_Educational_Assessment_and_Examination_Agency" title="National Educational Assessment and Examination Agency">National Education Assessment and Examination Agency</a> (NEAEA). Since 2018, there are two national exams: the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_General_Secondary_Education_Certificate_Examination" title="Ethiopian General Secondary Education Certificate Examination">Ethiopian General Secondary Education Certificate Examination</a> (EGSECE), also known as Grade 10 national exam and  Grade 12 national exam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-425"><a href="#cite_note-425">[425]</a></sup>
</p><p>Today, there are 30 public universities. Prior to 1991, Ethiopia did not have tertiary institution, but now there are 61 accredited private HEIs. The overall number of tertiary students in both public and private institutions exploded by more than 2,000 percent, from 34,000 in 1991 to 757,000 in 2014, per UIS data.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_351-1"><a href="#cite_note-:0-351">[351]</a></sup>
Access to education in Ethiopia has improved significantly. Approximately three million people were in primary school in 1994–95 but by 2008–09, primary enrolment had risen to 15.5 million – an increase of over 500%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[426]</a></sup> In 2013–14, Ethiopia had witnessed a significant boost in gross enrolment across all regions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-427"><a href="#cite_note-427">[427]</a></sup> The national GER was 104.8% for boys, 97.8% for girls and 101.3% across both sexes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-428"><a href="#cite_note-428">[428]</a></sup>
</p><p>The literacy rate has increased in recent years: according to the 1994 census, the literacy rate in Ethiopia was 23.4%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ethnologue_363-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ethnologue-363">[363]</a></sup> In 2007 it was estimated to be 39% (male 49.1% and female 28.9%).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-429"><a href="#cite_note-429">[429]</a></sup> A report by UNDP in 2011 showed that the literacy rate in Ethiopia was 46.7%. The same report also indicated that the female literacy rate had increased from 27 to 39 per cent from 2004 to 2011, and the male literacy rate had increased from 49 to 59 per cent over the same period for persons 10 years and older.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-430"><a href="#cite_note-430">[430]</a></sup> By 2015, the literacy rate had further increased, to 49.1% (57.2% male and 41.1% female).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-431"><a href="#cite_note-431">[431]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Ethiopia" title="Culture of Ethiopia">Culture of Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Roasting_Ethiopian_coffee_ceremony.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1599" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="227" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Roasting_Ethiopian_coffee_ceremony.jpg/170px-Roasting_Ethiopian_coffee_ceremony.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Roasting_Ethiopian_coffee_ceremony.jpg/255px-Roasting_Ethiopian_coffee_ceremony.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Roasting_Ethiopian_coffee_ceremony.jpg/340px-Roasting_Ethiopian_coffee_ceremony.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Roasting_Ethiopian_coffee_ceremony.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An Ethiopian woman roasting coffee beans in a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Coffee_house" title="Coffee house">coffee house</a>. The coffee serving ceremony is the most important course in Ethiopia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-432"><a href="#cite_note-432">[432]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Ethiopia's rich and diverse culture heavily influenced by the local population, an interaction of Semitic, Cushitic and less populous Nilo-Saharan speaking people, which evolved from first millennium BCE. Semitic Tigrayans and Amharas, who dominated the politics in the past, distinguished from other population by hierarchical structure and agrarian life derived partly from South Arabia as a result of back migration, while the southern Cushitic (Oromo and Somali) are strong adherents to <a href="/wiki/Egalitarianism" title="Egalitarianism">egalitarianism</a> and pastoral life. Others including Kaffa, Sidamo, and Afar tradition derived from the latter people.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[433]</a></sup>
</p><p>The most common recognized culture observed in <a href="/wiki/Coffee_ceremony_of_Ethiopia_and_Eritrea" title="Coffee ceremony of Ethiopia and Eritrea">coffee ceremony</a>. Unlike most countries, coffee is served in presence of social gathering, in family, friend or neighborhood level. There are three rounds of coffee drinking: the first one called "awol" (<a href="/wiki/Tigrinya_language" title="Tigrinya language">Tigrinya</a>: <span lang="ti">ኣዎል</span>), the second "tona" (ቶና) and the third "baraka" (ባርካ). The tradition of coffee legend goes back to Kaldi, a <a href="/wiki/Goatherd" title="Goatherd">goat herder</a> from <a href="/wiki/Keffa_Zone" title="Keffa Zone">Keffa Zone</a> who noticed his goat was caught up with <a href="/wiki/Hysteria" title="Hysteria">hysteria</a> after they eat shrub that stimulate them to dance uncontrollably with rampant. After holding berries, he was advised exhibit to priests in nearby monastery. One monk called the generosity of Kaldi "the Devil work" and tossed to the fire, generating aromatic odor. The legend told that Kaldi lived in 850 CE, commonly associated with belief of starting coffee cultivation in Ethiopia in the 9th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:6_328-1"><a href="#cite_note-:6-328">[328]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Arts">Arts</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_art" title="Ethiopian art">Ethiopian art</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Alwan_Codex_27_Ethiopian_Biblical_Manuscript.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1605" data-file-width="1121" decoding="async" height="215" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Alwan_Codex_27_Ethiopian_Biblical_Manuscript.jpg/150px-Alwan_Codex_27_Ethiopian_Biblical_Manuscript.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Alwan_Codex_27_Ethiopian_Biblical_Manuscript.jpg/225px-Alwan_Codex_27_Ethiopian_Biblical_Manuscript.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/Alwan_Codex_27_Ethiopian_Biblical_Manuscript.jpg/300px-Alwan_Codex_27_Ethiopian_Biblical_Manuscript.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Alwan_Codex_27_Ethiopian_Biblical_Manuscript.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Alwan Codex 27 – Ethiopian biblical manuscript</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ethiopian_scribes.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1128" data-file-width="1312" decoding="async" height="189" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Ethiopian_scribes.jpg/220px-Ethiopian_scribes.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Ethiopian_scribes.jpg/330px-Ethiopian_scribes.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Ethiopian_scribes.jpg/440px-Ethiopian_scribes.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ethiopian_scribes.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Illustration showing two <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Aksum" title="Kingdom of Aksum">Aksumite</a> scribes</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_art" title="Ethiopian art">Arts of Ethiopia</a> were largely influenced by Christian iconography throughout much of its history. This consisted of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Illuminated_manuscripts" title="Illuminated manuscripts">illuminated manuscripts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Painting" title="Painting">painting</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_cross" title="Ethiopian cross">crosses</a>, <a href="/wiki/Icon" title="Icon">icons</a> and other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metalwork" title="Metalwork">metalwork</a> such as crowns. Most historical arts were commissioned by the Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church, the state religion for a millennium. The earlier Aksumite period arts were stone carvings as evidenced in their stelae, though there is no surviving Christian art from this era. As Christianity was introduced, its iconography was partly influenced by <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine art</a>. Most remaining arts beyond the early modern period were ruined as a result of invasion of the <a href="/wiki/Adal_Sultanate" title="Adal Sultanate">Adal Sultanate</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Highlands" title="Ethiopian Highlands">Ethiopian Highlands</a>, but were revived by Catholic emissaries. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Western_art" title="Western art">Western</a> intervention in Ethiopian art began in the 20th century, with also maintaining traditional Ethiopian character.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Ethiopia" title="Architecture of Ethiopia">Architecture of Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ET_Gondar_asv2018-02_img03_Fasil_Ghebbi.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4243" data-file-width="5304" decoding="async" height="176" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/ET_Gondar_asv2018-02_img03_Fasil_Ghebbi.jpg/220px-ET_Gondar_asv2018-02_img03_Fasil_Ghebbi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/ET_Gondar_asv2018-02_img03_Fasil_Ghebbi.jpg/330px-ET_Gondar_asv2018-02_img03_Fasil_Ghebbi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/ET_Gondar_asv2018-02_img03_Fasil_Ghebbi.jpg/440px-ET_Gondar_asv2018-02_img03_Fasil_Ghebbi.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ET_Gondar_asv2018-02_img03_Fasil_Ghebbi.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Royal Enclosure at <a href="/wiki/Fasil_Ghebbi" title="Fasil Ghebbi">Fasil Ghebbi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gondar" title="Gondar">Gondar</a></div></div></div>
<p>Perhaps the most impressive architecture in antiquity was founded during Dʿmt period. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ashlar_masonry" title="Ashlar masonry">Ashlar masonry</a> was an archetype of <a href="/wiki/South_Arabia" title="South Arabia">South Arabian</a> architecture with most architectural structure similarity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-434"><a href="#cite_note-434">[434]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Aksumite continued to flourish its architecture around 4th century CE. Aksumite stelae commonly utilized single block and rocks. The Tomb of the False Door built for Aksumite emperors used monolithic style.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-435"><a href="#cite_note-435">[435]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Lalibela" title="Lalibela">Lalibela</a> civilization was largely of Aksumite influence, but the layer of stones or wood is quite different for some dwelling.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-436"><a href="#cite_note-436">[436]</a></sup>
</p><p>In Gondarine period, the architecture of Ethiopia was infused by Baroque, Arab, Turkish and Gujarati Indian styles independently taught by Portuguese emissaries in the 16th and 17th centuries. Example includes the imperial fortress <a href="/wiki/Fasil_Ghebbi" title="Fasil Ghebbi">Fasil Ghebbi</a>, which is influenced by either of these styles. The medieval architecture also forborne the later 19th- and 20th-century era of designations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-437"><a href="#cite_note-437">[437]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Philosophy">Philosophy</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_philosophy" title="Ethiopian philosophy">Ethiopian philosophy</a></div>
<p>Ethiopian philosophy has been superlatively prolific since ancient times in Africa, though offset of <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek_philosophy" title="Ancient Greek philosophy">Greek</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Patristic" title="Patristic">Patristic</a> philosophy. The best known philosophical revival was in the early modern period figures such as <a href="/wiki/Zera_Yacob_(philosopher)" title="Zera Yacob (philosopher)">Zera Yacob</a> (1599–1692) and his student <a href="/wiki/Walda_Heywat" title="Walda Heywat">Walda Heywat</a>, who wrote <i><a href="/wiki/Hatata" title="Hatata">Hatata</a></i> (<i>Inquiry</i>) in 1667 as an argument for the <a href="/wiki/Existence_of_God" title="Existence of God">existence of God</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_literature" title="Ethiopian literature">Ethiopian literature</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Giyorgis_MET_DP367372.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3001" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Giyorgis_MET_DP367372.jpg/220px-Giyorgis_MET_DP367372.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Giyorgis_MET_DP367372.jpg/330px-Giyorgis_MET_DP367372.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Giyorgis_MET_DP367372.jpg/440px-Giyorgis_MET_DP367372.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Giyorgis_MET_DP367372.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Giyorgis_of_Segla" title="Giyorgis of Segla">Giyorgis of Segla</a>, prolific religious author in the <a href="/wiki/Late_Middle_Ages" title="Late Middle Ages">Late Middle Ages</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_literature" title="Ethiopian literature">Ethiopian literature</a> traced back to the Aksumite period in the 4th century, most of them are merely religious motifs. In royal inscription, they employed both <a href="/wiki/Ge%CA%BDez_script" title="Geʽez script">Ge'ez</a> and <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Greek</a> language, but the latter was dismissed in 350. Unlike most Sub-Saharan African countries, Ethiopia has ancient distinct language, the Ge'ez, which dominated political and educational aspects. In spite of the current political instability in the country instigates endangering cultural heritage of these works, some improvements are made for preservation in recent years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:4_438-0"><a href="#cite_note-:4-438">[438]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Ethiopian literary works mostly consisted of handwritten <a href="/wiki/Codex" title="Codex">codex</a> (branna, or ብራና in Amharic). It is prepared by gathering parchment leaves and sewing to stick together. The codex size is considerably varies depending on volumes and preparation. For example, pocket size codex lengthens 45 cm, which is heavier in weight. Historians speculated that archaic codex is existed in Ethiopia. Today manuscripts resembling primitive codex are still evident for existence where parchment leaves are convenient for writing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:4_438-1"><a href="#cite_note-:4-438">[438]</a></sup>
</p><p>Another notable writing book is protective (or magic) <a href="/wiki/Scroll" title="Scroll">scroll</a>, serving as written amulet. Some of these were intended for magical purpose, for example <i>ketab</i> is used for magical defence. Scrolls typically produced by <i><a href="/wiki/Debtera" title="Debtera">debtera</a></i>, non-ordained clergy expertise on <a href="/wiki/Exorcism" title="Exorcism">exorcism</a> and healings. About 30 cm scroll is portable whereas 2 cm is often unrolled and hanged to the wall of house. Scrolls emulating original medium of Ethiopia literature is highly disputed, where there is overwhelming evidence that Ge'ez language books were written in codex. In lesser, Ethiopia used accordion books (called <i>sensul</i>) which was dated to late 15th or 16th century, made up of folded parchment paper, with or without cover. Those book usually contain pictorial representation of life and death of religious figures, or significant texts have also juxtaposed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:4_438-2"><a href="#cite_note-:4-438">[438]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Poetry">Poetry</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:152px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tsegaye_Gabre-Medhin_2.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="356" data-file-width="326" decoding="async" height="164" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Tsegaye_Gabre-Medhin_2.jpg/150px-Tsegaye_Gabre-Medhin_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Tsegaye_Gabre-Medhin_2.jpg/225px-Tsegaye_Gabre-Medhin_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Tsegaye_Gabre-Medhin_2.jpg/300px-Tsegaye_Gabre-Medhin_2.jpg 2x" width="150"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tsegaye_Gabre-Medhin_2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Tsegaye Gebre-Medhin in 1980s</div></div></div>
<p>Ethiopia is highly popularized in <a href="/wiki/Poetry" title="Poetry">poetry</a>. Most poets recount past events, social unrests, poverty and famine. <i><a href="/wiki/Qene" title="Qene">Qene</a></i> is the most used element of Ethiopian poetry – regarded as a form of Amharic poetry, though the term generally refers to any poems. True qene requires advanced ingenious mindset. By providing two metaphorical words, i.e. one with obvious clues and the other is too convoluted conundrum, one must answer parallel meanings. Thus, this is called <i>sem ena work</i> (gold and wax).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:9_439-0"><a href="#cite_note-:9-439">[439]</a></sup> The most notable poets are <a href="/wiki/Tsegaye_Gabre-Medhin" title="Tsegaye Gabre-Medhin">Tsegaye Gebre-Medhin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kebede_Michael" title="Kebede Michael">Kebede Michael</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mengistu_Lemma" title="Mengistu Lemma">Mengistu Lemma</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Calendar">Calendar</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_calendar" title="Ethiopian calendar">Ethiopian calendar</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oromo_calendar" title="Oromo calendar">Oromo calendar</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Celebrate_The_Return_of_Axum_Obelisk_(Detail)_(3172365788).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1972" data-file-width="2986" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Celebrate_The_Return_of_Axum_Obelisk_%28Detail%29_%283172365788%29.jpg/220px-Celebrate_The_Return_of_Axum_Obelisk_%28Detail%29_%283172365788%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Celebrate_The_Return_of_Axum_Obelisk_%28Detail%29_%283172365788%29.jpg/330px-Celebrate_The_Return_of_Axum_Obelisk_%28Detail%29_%283172365788%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Celebrate_The_Return_of_Axum_Obelisk_%28Detail%29_%283172365788%29.jpg/440px-Celebrate_The_Return_of_Axum_Obelisk_%28Detail%29_%283172365788%29.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Celebrate_The_Return_of_Axum_Obelisk_(Detail)_(3172365788).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Model commemorating the <a href="/wiki/Obelisk_of_Axum" title="Obelisk of Axum">Obelisk of Aksum</a>'s return to Ethiopia from Italy, showing the date of its departure and return according to the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_calendar" title="Ethiopian calendar">Ethiopian calendar</a></div></div></div>
<p>Ethiopia has several local calendars. The most widely known is the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_calendar" title="Ethiopian calendar">Ethiopian calendar</a>, also known as the Ge'ez calendar, and written with the ancient <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ge%27ez_script" title="Ge'ez script">Ge'ez script</a>, one of the oldest alphabets still in use in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wilfpag_440-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wilfpag-440">[440]</a></sup> It is based on the older Alexandrian or <a href="/wiki/Coptic_calendar" title="Coptic calendar">Coptic calendar</a>, which in turn derives from the <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_calendar" title="Egyptian calendar">Egyptian calendar</a>. Like the Coptic calendar, the Ethiopian calendar has twelve months of exactly 30 days each plus five or six <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Epagomenal" title="Epagomenal">epagomenal</a> days, which form a thirteenth month. The Ethiopian months begin on the same days as those of the Coptic calendar, but their names are in Ge'ez<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Like the <a href="/wiki/Julian_calendar" title="Julian calendar">Julian calendar</a>, the sixth epagomenal day—which in essence is a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Leap_day" title="Leap day">leap day</a>—is added every four years without exception on 29 August of the Julian calendar, six months before the Julian leap day. Thus, the first day of the Ethiopian year, 1<span class="nowrap"> </span>Mäskäräm, for years between 1901 and 2099 (inclusive), is usually 11 September (<a href="/wiki/Gregorian_calendar" title="Gregorian calendar">Gregorian</a>), but falls on 12 September in years before the Gregorian leap year. It is approximately seven years and three months behind the Gregorian calendar because of an alternate calculation in determining the date of the <a href="/wiki/Annunciation" title="Annunciation">Annunciation</a> of Jesus.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Another calendrical system was developed around 300 BCE by the <a href="/wiki/Oromo_people" title="Oromo people">Oromo people</a>. A lunar-stellar calendar, this <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oromo_calendar" title="Oromo calendar">Oromo calendar</a> relies on astronomical observations of the moon in conjunction with seven particular stars or constellations. Oromo months (stars/lunar phases) are <i>Bittottessa</i> (Iangulum), <i>Camsa</i> (Pleiades), <i>Bufa</i> (Aldebarran), <i>Waxabajjii</i> (Belletrix), <i>Obora Gudda</i> (Central Orion-Saiph), <i>Obora Dikka</i> (Sirius), <i>Birra</i> (full moon), <i>Cikawa</i> (gibbous moon), <i>Sadasaa</i> (quarter moon), <i>Abrasa</i> (large crescent), <i>Ammaji</i> (medium crescent), and <i>Gurrandala</i> (small crescent).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[441]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_cuisine" title="Ethiopian cuisine">Ethiopian cuisine</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/List_of_Ethiopian_dishes_and_foods" title="List of Ethiopian dishes and foods">List of Ethiopian dishes and foods</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Alicha_1.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Alicha_1.jpg/220px-Alicha_1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Alicha_1.jpg/330px-Alicha_1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Alicha_1.jpg/440px-Alicha_1.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Alicha_1.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Typical Ethiopian cuisine: <i><a href="/wiki/Injera" title="Injera">injera</a></i> (pancake-like bread) and several kinds of <i>wat</i> (stew)</div></div></div>
<p>The best-known <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_cuisine" title="Ethiopian cuisine">Ethiopian cuisine</a> consists of various types of thick meat <a href="/wiki/Stew" title="Stew">stews</a>, known as <i><a href="/wiki/Wat_(food)" title="Wat (food)">wat</a></i> in Ethiopian culture, and vegetable side dishes served on top of <a href="/wiki/Injera" title="Injera">injera</a>, a large <a href="/wiki/Sourdough" title="Sourdough">sourdough</a> <a href="/wiki/Flatbread" title="Flatbread">flatbread</a> made of <a href="/wiki/Teff" title="Teff">teff</a> flour. This is not eaten with utensils, but instead the injera is used to scoop up the entrées and side dishes. Almost universally in Ethiopia, it is common to eat from the same dish in the middle of the table with a group of people. It is also a common custom to feed others within a group or own hands—a tradition referred to as "<a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_cuisine#Gursha" title="Ethiopian cuisine">gursha</a>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-442"><a href="#cite_note-442">[442]</a></sup> Traditional Ethiopian cuisine employs no <a href="/wiki/Pork" title="Pork">pork</a> or <a href="/wiki/Shellfish" title="Shellfish">shellfish</a> of any kind, as both are forbidden in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Orthodox" title="Ethiopian Orthodox">Ethiopian Orthodox</a> Christian, Islamic and Jewish faiths.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Fit-fit#Kitcha_fit-fit" title="Fit-fit">Chechebsa</a>, Marqa, Chukko, Michirra and Dhanga are the most popular dishes from the <a href="/wiki/Oromo_people" title="Oromo people">Oromo</a>. <a href="/wiki/Kitfo" title="Kitfo">Kitfo</a>, which originated among the <a href="/wiki/Gurage_people" title="Gurage people">Gurage</a>, is one of the country's most popular delicacies. In addition, <i>Doro Wot</i> (ዶሮ ወጥ in <a href="/wiki/Amharic" title="Amharic">Amharic</a>) and Tsebehi Derho (ጽብሒ ድርሆ in <a href="/wiki/Tigrinya_language" title="Tigrinya language">Tigrinya</a>), are other popular dishes, originating from northwestern Ethiopia.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2017)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> <a href="/wiki/Tihlo" title="Tihlo">Tihlo</a> (ጥሕሎ)—which is a type of <a href="/wiki/Dumpling" title="Dumpling">dumpling</a>—is prepared from roasted barley flour and originated in the <a href="/wiki/Tigray_Region" title="Tigray Region">Tigray Region</a>. Tihlo is now very popular in <a href="/wiki/Amhara_Region" title="Amhara Region">Amhara</a> and spreading further south.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[443]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Holidays">Holidays</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Ethiopia" title="Public holidays in Ethiopia">Public holidays in Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Meskel-festival-in-Ethiopia_01.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="916" data-file-width="1389" decoding="async" height="145" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Meskel-festival-in-Ethiopia_01.jpg/220px-Meskel-festival-in-Ethiopia_01.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Meskel-festival-in-Ethiopia_01.jpg/330px-Meskel-festival-in-Ethiopia_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Meskel-festival-in-Ethiopia_01.jpg/440px-Meskel-festival-in-Ethiopia_01.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Meskel-festival-in-Ethiopia_01.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Meskel" title="Meskel">Meskel</a> commemorates the discovery of <a href="/wiki/True_Cross" title="True Cross">True Cross</a> by Roman queen <a href="/wiki/Helena,_mother_of_Constantine_I" title="Helena, mother of Constantine I">Helena</a> in 326 CE</div></div></div>
<p>Most holidays are belonged to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Orthodox_Tewahedo" title="Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo">Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo</a>, and secondly of <a href="/wiki/Islam_in_Ethiopia" title="Islam in Ethiopia">Islam</a>. Secular holidays espouse national or historical chronicles.
</p><p>Secular holidays are follows with date of celebration:
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Adwa_Victory_Day" title="Adwa Victory Day">Adwa Victory Day</a> (2 March)</li>
<li>International Workers' Day (1 May)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Patriots%27_Victory_Day" title="Ethiopian Patriots' Victory Day">Ethiopian Patriots' Victory Day</a> (5 May)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Downfall_of_the_Derg_(holiday)" title="Downfall of the Derg (holiday)">Downfall of the Derg</a> (28 May)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Enkutatash" title="Enkutatash">Enkutatash</a> (11 September or 12 September (leap year))</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Nations,_Nationalities_and_Peoples%27_Day" title="Nations, Nationalities and Peoples' Day">Nations, Nationalities and Peoples' Day</a> (8 December)</li></ul>
<p>Ethiopian Orthodox holidays are:
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Christmas" title="Ethiopian Christmas">Ethiopian Christmas</a> (7 January)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Timkat" title="Timkat">Timkat</a> (19 January)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Good_Friday" title="Good Friday">Good Friday</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Easter" title="Easter">Easter</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Meskel" title="Meskel">Meskel</a> (27 September or 28 September (leap year))</li></ul>
<p>Islamic holidays are:
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Ramadan" title="Ramadan">Ramadan</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Mawlid" title="Mawlid">Mawlid</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Eid_al-Fitr" title="Eid al-Fitr">Eid al-Fitr</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Eid_al-Adha" title="Eid al-Adha">Eid al-Adha</a></li></ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Communications_in_Ethiopia" title="Communications in Ethiopia">Communications in Ethiopia</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Media_in_Ethiopia" title="Media in Ethiopia">Media in Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ethiopian_Television.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2767" data-file-width="2750" decoding="async" height="221" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Ethiopian_Television.JPG/220px-Ethiopian_Television.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Ethiopian_Television.JPG/330px-Ethiopian_Television.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Ethiopian_Television.JPG/440px-Ethiopian_Television.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ethiopian_Television.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Broadcasting_Corporation" title="Ethiopian Broadcasting Corporation">Ethiopian Broadcasting Corporation</a> headquarter in Addis Ababa</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Broadcasting_Corporation" title="Ethiopian Broadcasting Corporation">Ethiopian Broadcasting Corporation</a> (EBC), formerly known as ETV, is the <a href="/wiki/State_media" title="State media">state media</a>. Radio broadcasting was commenced earlier in 1935 before the television service began in 1962 with assistance of British firm Thomson and Emperor Haile Selassie.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-africanews.com_3-1"><a href="#cite_note-africanews.com-3">[3]</a></sup> Since 2015, EBC has upgraded its studios with modernized transmission.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Kana_TV" title="Kana TV">Kana TV</a> is the most popular TV channel in Ethiopia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-444"><a href="#cite_note-444">[444]</a></sup> It is mainly known for <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dubbing_(filmmaking)" title="Dubbing (filmmaking)">dubbing</a> foreign content into <a href="/wiki/Amharic" title="Amharic">Amharic</a>. Over several decades, the state television has served as the major mass media until in late 2000s, when <a href="/wiki/EBS_TV_(Ethiopia)" title="EBS TV (Ethiopia)">EBS TV</a> launched as the first private television channel. Moreover, numerous private channels were commenced in 2016, culminating in the growth of privately owned media companies in the country. As an example, <a href="/wiki/Fana_TV" title="Fana TV">Fana TV</a> has been the largest TV network since its launch in 2017.
</p><p>The most widely circulated newspapers in Ethiopia are <a href="/wiki/Addis_Fortune" title="Addis Fortune">Addis Fortune</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Capital_Ethiopia" title="Capital Ethiopia">Capital Ethiopia</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Reporter" title="Ethiopian Reporter">Ethiopian Reporter</a>, Addis Zemen<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2017)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> (<i>Amharic</i>) and <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Herald" title="Ethiopian Herald">Ethiopian Herald</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2017)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>The sole internet service provider is the national telecommunications firm <a href="/wiki/Ethio_telecom" title="Ethio telecom">Ethio telecom</a>. A large portion of users in the country access the internet through mobile devices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_445-0"><a href="#cite_note-:3-445">[445]</a></sup> As of July 2016<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ethiopia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, there are around 4.29 million people who have internet access at their home as compared to a quarter of a million users a decade before that.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-446"><a href="#cite_note-446">[446]</a></sup> The Ethiopian government has at times intentionally shut down internet service in the country or restricted access to certain social media sites during periods of political unrest. In August 2016, following protest and demonstration in the Oromia Region, all access to the internet was shut down for a period of two days.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-447"><a href="#cite_note-447">[447]</a></sup> In June 2017, the government shut down access to the internet for mobile users during a period that coincided with the administration of university entrance examination. Although the reason for the restriction was not confirmed by the government,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:3_445-1"><a href="#cite_note-:3-445">[445]</a></sup> the move was similar to a measure taken during the same period in 2016, after a leak of test questions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-448"><a href="#cite_note-448">[448]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-449"><a href="#cite_note-449">[449]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Science_and_technology">Science and technology</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Science_and_technology_in_Ethiopia" title="Science and technology in Ethiopia">Science and technology in Ethiopia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Ethiopian_scientists" title="List of Ethiopian scientists">List of Ethiopian scientists</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:258px;max-width:258px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:127px;max-width:127px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Portrait-aklilu-lemma-11.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1276" data-file-width="902" decoding="async" height="177" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Portrait-aklilu-lemma-11.jpg/125px-Portrait-aklilu-lemma-11.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Portrait-aklilu-lemma-11.jpg/188px-Portrait-aklilu-lemma-11.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Portrait-aklilu-lemma-11.jpg/250px-Portrait-aklilu-lemma-11.jpg 2x" width="125"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Pathobiologist <a href="/wiki/Aklilu_Lemma" title="Aklilu Lemma">Aklilu Lemma</a>. In 1964, he discovered an <a href="/wiki/Alternative_medicine" title="Alternative medicine">alternative</a> treatment for <a href="/wiki/Schistosomiasis" title="Schistosomiasis">schistosomiasis</a>, known as snail fever.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-450"><a href="#cite_note-450">[450]</a></sup></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:127px;max-width:127px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Zeresenay_Alemseged_(2013-01).JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="1449" data-file-width="1043" decoding="async" height="174" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Zeresenay_Alemseged_%282013-01%29.JPG/125px-Zeresenay_Alemseged_%282013-01%29.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Zeresenay_Alemseged_%282013-01%29.JPG/188px-Zeresenay_Alemseged_%282013-01%29.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Zeresenay_Alemseged_%282013-01%29.JPG/250px-Zeresenay_Alemseged_%282013-01%29.JPG 2x" width="125"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Paleoanthropologist <a href="/wiki/Zeresenay_Alemseged" title="Zeresenay Alemseged">Zeresenay Alemseged</a> in 2013. He was best known for discovering fossilized <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hominin" title="Hominin">hominin</a> called <i><a href="/wiki/Selam_(Australopithecus)" title="Selam (Australopithecus)">Selam</a></i> or "Lucy's baby" in December 2000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-451"><a href="#cite_note-451">[451]</a></sup></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Science and technology in Ethiopia emerging as progressive due to lack of organized institutions. Manufacturing and service providers often place themselves in <a href="/wiki/Competitive_programming" title="Competitive programming">competitive programming</a> in order to advance innovative and technological solutions through in-house arenas. The <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Space_Science_and_Technology_Institute" title="Ethiopian Space Science and Technology Institute">Ethiopian Space Science and Technology</a> is responsible for conducting multifaceted tasks regarding space and technology. In addition, Ethiopia also launched 70 kg ET-RSS1 multi-spectral remote sensing satellite in December 2019. The President Sahle-Work Zewde told prior in October 2019 that "the satellite will provide all the necessary data on changes in climate and weather-related phenomena that would be utilized for the country's key targets in agriculture, forestry as well as natural resources protection initiatives." By January 2020, satellite manufacturing, assembling, integrating and testing began. This would also incremented facility built by French company funded by European Investment Bank (EIB). The main observatory Entoto Observatory and Space Science Research Center (EORC) allocated space programmes. The Ethiopian Biotechnology Institute is a part of Scientific Research &amp; Development Services Industry, responsible for environmental and climate conservation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-452"><a href="#cite_note-452">[452]</a></sup> Numerous profound scientists have contributed degree of honours and reputations. Some are <a href="/wiki/Kitaw_Ejigu" title="Kitaw Ejigu">Kitaw Ejigu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mulugeta_Bekele" title="Mulugeta Bekele">Mulugeta Bekele</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aklilu_Lemma" title="Aklilu Lemma">Aklilu Lemma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gebisa_Ejeta" title="Gebisa Ejeta">Gebisa Ejeta</a> and <a href="/wiki/Melaku_Worede" title="Melaku Worede">Melaku Worede</a>.
</p><p>Ethiopia is known for use of <a href="/wiki/Traditional_medicine" title="Traditional medicine">traditional medicine</a> since millennia. The first epidemic occurred in Ethiopia was in 849, causing the Aksumite Emperor Abba Yohannes evicted from place due to "God's punishment for misdeeds". The first traditional medicine was claimed to be derived from this catastrophe, but the exact source is debated. Though differ from ethnic groups, traditional medicine often implements herbs, spiritual healing, bone-setting and minor surgical procedures in treating disease.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[453]</a></sup> Others fields include  conventional <a href="/wiki/Mathematics_in_Ethiopia" title="Mathematics in Ethiopia">mathematics</a> used to measure astrology, calendar and unit of measurement.
</p><p>Ethiopia was ranked 126th in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index" title="Global Innovation Index">Global Innovation Index</a> in 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-454"><a href="#cite_note-454">[454]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Ethiopia" title="Music of Ethiopia">Music of Ethiopia</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Golden_Age_of_music" title="Ethiopian Golden Age of music">Ethiopian Golden Age of music</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Yared.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="235" data-file-width="360" decoding="async" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Yared.jpg/220px-Yared.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Yared.jpg/330px-Yared.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/07/Yared.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Yared.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Aksumite composer Yared credited as forebear of traditional music for both Ethiopia and Eritrea</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Ethiopia" title="Music of Ethiopia">music of Ethiopia</a> is extremely diverse, with each of the country's 80 ethnic groups being associated with unique sounds. Ethiopian music uses a distinct <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Musical_mode" title="Musical mode">modal system</a> that is <a href="/wiki/Pentatonic_scale" title="Pentatonic scale">pentatonic</a>, with characteristically long intervals between some notes. As with many other aspects of Ethiopian culture and tradition, tastes in music and lyrics are strongly linked with those in neighbouring Eritrea, Somalia, Djibouti, and Sudan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Abdullahi_455-0"><a href="#cite_note-Abdullahi-455">[455]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Tekle_456-0"><a href="#cite_note-Tekle-456">[456]</a></sup> Traditional singing in Ethiopia presents diverse styles of <a href="/wiki/Polyphony" title="Polyphony">polyphony</a>, (<a href="/wiki/Heterophony" title="Heterophony">heterophony</a>, <a href="/wiki/Drone_(music)" title="Drone (music)">drone</a>, imitation, and <a href="/wiki/Counterpoint" title="Counterpoint">counterpoint</a>). Traditionally, lyricism in Ethiopian song writing is strongly associated with views of patriotism or national pride, romance, friendship, and a unique type of memoire known as <i><a href="/wiki/Tizita" title="Tizita">tizita</a></i>.
</p><p>Saint <a href="/wiki/Yared" title="Yared">Yared</a>, a 6th-century Aksumite composer, is widely regarded as the forerunner of traditional music of Eritrea and Ethiopia, creating liturgical music of the Ethiopian and <a href="/wiki/Eritrean_Orthodox_Tewahedo_Church" title="Eritrean Orthodox Tewahedo Church">Eritrean Orthodox Tewahedo Church</a>. He also composed <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Zema" title="Zema">Zema</a></i>, subdivided into three chants: Ge'ez, Ezel and Araray. Yared life thought to have been "failure and success" where his was poor performance in education. Yared then fired from the school and went to his uncle birthplace Murade Qal. There his saw caterpillar endeavours to reach a tree's peak. He epitomized to his real life and returned to the school with good spirit, later became prominent to political sphere. During the remaining of his lifetime, he was a friend of Aksumite Emperor Gebre Meskel and the exiled <a href="/wiki/Nine_Saints" title="Nine Saints">Nine Saints</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-457"><a href="#cite_note-457">[457]</a></sup>
</p><p>Modern music traced back to the reign of Emperor Haile Selassie, where 40 Armenian orphans called <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Arba_Lijoch" title="Arba Lijoch">Arba Lijoch</a> arrived from <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem" title="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a> to Addis Ababa. By 1924, the band was almost established as orchestral; but after World War II, several alike bands were emerged such as Imperial Bodyguard Band, Army Band, and Police Band.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-458"><a href="#cite_note-458">[458]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mahmoudahmedfeature.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="255" data-file-width="267" decoding="async" height="210" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ae/Mahmoudahmedfeature.jpg/220px-Mahmoudahmedfeature.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/a/ae/Mahmoudahmedfeature.jpg 1.5x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mahmoudahmedfeature.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mahmoud_Ahmed" title="Mahmoud Ahmed">Mahmoud Ahmed</a> performing in 2005</div></div></div>
<p>In the 1960s and 1970s, traditional infused modern Ethiopian music was revived in what is known as the "<a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_Golden_Age_of_music" title="Ethiopian Golden Age of music">Golden Age</a>". Several notable musical artists emerged thereafter, for example, <a href="/wiki/Tilahun_Gessesse" title="Tilahun Gessesse">Tilahun Gessesse</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alemayehu_Eshete" title="Alemayehu Eshete">Alemayehu Eshete</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bizunesh_Bekele" title="Bizunesh Bekele">Bizunesh Bekele</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muluken_Melesse" title="Muluken Melesse">Muluken Melesse</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mahmoud_Ahmed" title="Mahmoud Ahmed">Mahmoud Ahmed</a>. It also employed tradition style called <i>tizita</i>. During the Derg regime, these artists were prohibited to perform in the country and often forced into exile in North America and Europe, mixing with jazz and funk influences. For example, Roha Band, <a href="/wiki/Walias_Band" title="Walias Band">Walias Band</a>, and Ethio Stars. By this time, <a href="/wiki/Neway_Debebe" title="Neway Debebe">Neway Debebe</a> was critical of the Derg government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:9_439-1"><a href="#cite_note-:9-439">[439]</a></sup>
</p><p>Modern music became developed shortly in 1990s and 2000s. In this period, the most popular artists were <a href="/wiki/Aster_Aweke" title="Aster Aweke">Aster Aweke</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gigi_(singer)" title="Gigi (singer)">Gigi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Teddy_Afro" title="Teddy Afro">Teddy Afro</a>. Ethiopian music further modernized in the next decade, employing electronic type and more popular. DJ <a href="/wiki/Rophnan" title="Rophnan">Rophnan</a> was renowned for pioneering EDM after releasing his debut album <i>Reflection</i> in 2018.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:9_439-2"><a href="#cite_note-:9-439">[439]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cinema">Cinema</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Ethiopia" title="Cinema of Ethiopia">Cinema of Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:HagerFikirTheatre.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="960" data-file-width="1280" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/HagerFikirTheatre.jpg/220px-HagerFikirTheatre.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/HagerFikirTheatre.jpg/330px-HagerFikirTheatre.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/HagerFikirTheatre.jpg/440px-HagerFikirTheatre.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:HagerFikirTheatre.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Hager_Fikir_Theatre" title="Hager Fikir Theatre">Hager Fikir Theatre</a> in April 2006</div></div></div>
<p>The first cinema was introduced in 1898, three years after the first world film was projected. Cinematic artifacts ascribed by Italian minister <a class="new" href="/w/index.php?title=Federico_Ciccodicola&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" title="Federico Ciccodicola (page does not exist)">Federico Ciccodicola</a><span class="noprint" style="font-size:85%; font-style: normal;"> [<a class="extiw" href="https://it.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federico_Ciccodicola" title="it:Federico Ciccodicola">it</a>]</span> which then offered to Emperor Menelik II. The early 20th century appearance with spectacle was around 1909 and embraced by documentary or biographical films. <i>Au de Menilek</i> was the first film directed by Charles Martel. The first 16mm black-and-white film dedicated to coronation of Emperor <a href="/wiki/Zewditu" title="Zewditu">Zewditu</a>, then coronation of Emperor Haile Selassie was filmed.
</p><p>The 1990s saw international booming of Ethiopian films. The most influential people in this era were <a href="/wiki/Haile_Gerima" title="Haile Gerima">Haile Gerima</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salem_Mekuria" title="Salem Mekuria">Salem Mekuria</a>, Yemane Demissie, and <a href="/wiki/Teshome_Gabriel" title="Teshome Gabriel">Teshome Gabriel</a>.
</p><p>Films began modernized in 2000s and implemented <a href="/wiki/Amharic" title="Amharic">Amharic</a> language. The most internationally grossed films are <i><a href="/wiki/Selanchi" title="Selanchi">Selanchi</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Difret" title="Difret">Difret</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Lamb_(2015_Ethiopian_film)" title="Lamb (2015 Ethiopian film)">Lamb</a></i>, <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prince_of_Love" title="Prince of Love">Prince of Love</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Lambadina" title="Lambadina">Lambadina</a></i>. The modern era saw several reoccurring actors including <a href="/wiki/Selam_Tesfaye" title="Selam Tesfaye">Selam Tesfaye</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fryat_Yemane" title="Fryat Yemane">Fryat Yemane</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hanan_Tarik" title="Hanan Tarik">Hanan Tarik</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mahder_Assefa" title="Mahder Assefa">Mahder Assefa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Amleset_Muchie" title="Amleset Muchie">Amleset Muchie</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ruth_Negga" title="Ruth Negga">Ruth Negga</a>.
</p><p>One of the most prestigious film award is <a href="/wiki/Gumma_Film_Awards" title="Gumma Film Awards">Gumma Film Awards</a> held in Addis Ababa. The award, which was started in 2014, broadcast on live television in some stations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-459"><a href="#cite_note-459">[459]</a></sup> Festivals including <a href="/wiki/Addis_International_Film_Festival" title="Addis International Film Festival">Addis International Film Festival</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Ethiopian_International_Film_Festival" title="Ethiopian International Film Festival">Ethiopian International Film Festival</a> showcase amateur and professional filmmakers works; the latter being voted by judges. They were established in 2007<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460"><a href="#cite_note-460">[460]</a></sup> and 2005 respectively.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-461"><a href="#cite_note-461">[461]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sport">Sport</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Ethiopia" title="Sport in Ethiopia">Sport in Ethiopia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Genzebe_Dibaba_Istanbul_2012.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="426" data-file-width="640" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Genzebe_Dibaba_Istanbul_2012.jpg/220px-Genzebe_Dibaba_Istanbul_2012.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Genzebe_Dibaba_Istanbul_2012.jpg/330px-Genzebe_Dibaba_Istanbul_2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b8/Genzebe_Dibaba_Istanbul_2012.jpg/440px-Genzebe_Dibaba_Istanbul_2012.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Genzebe_Dibaba_Istanbul_2012.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Genzebe_Dibaba" title="Genzebe Dibaba">Genzebe Dibaba</a> middle- and long-distance runner. A 1500 metres <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/2016_Rio_Olympics" title="2016 Rio Olympics">2016 Rio Olympics</a> silver medalist, she won a gold medal in this event and a bronze in the 5000 metres at the 2015 World Championships.</div></div></div>
<p>The main sports in Ethiopia are <a href="/wiki/Track_and_field" title="Track and field">track and field</a> (particularly <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Long_distance_running" title="Long distance running">long distance running</a>) and football. Ethiopian athletes have won many <a href="/wiki/Olympic_Games" title="Olympic Games">Olympic</a> gold medals in track and field, most of them in long distance running.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-462"><a href="#cite_note-462">[462]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Abebe_Bikila" title="Abebe Bikila">Abebe Bikila</a> became the first athlete from a <a href="/wiki/Sub-Saharan_Africa" title="Sub-Saharan Africa">Sub-Saharan</a> country to win an Olympic gold medal when he won the Marathon at the 1960 Rome Olympic Games in a world record time of 2:15:16.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-463"><a href="#cite_note-463">[463]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-464"><a href="#cite_note-464">[464]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Haile_Gebrselassie" title="Haile Gebrselassie">Haile Gebrselassie</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kenenisa_Bekele" title="Kenenisa Bekele">Kenenisa Bekele</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tirunesh_Dibaba" title="Tirunesh Dibaba">Tirunesh Dibaba</a> are all world-renowned long distance runners, each with multiple Olympic and <a href="/wiki/World_Athletics_Championships" title="World Athletics Championships">World Championship</a> gold medals. <a href="/wiki/Letesenbet_Gidey" title="Letesenbet Gidey">Letesenbet Gidey</a> holds the world records in both the women's 5,000 metre and 10,000 metre run. Other notable Ethiopian runners are <a href="/wiki/Mamo_Wolde" title="Mamo Wolde">Mamo Wolde</a>, <a href="/wiki/Miruts_Yifter" title="Miruts Yifter">Miruts Yifter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Derartu_Tulu" title="Derartu Tulu">Derartu Tulu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Meseret_Defar" title="Meseret Defar">Meseret Defar</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Birhane_Adere" title="Birhane Adere">Birhane Adere</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tiki_Gelana" title="Tiki Gelana">Tiki Gelana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Genzebe_Dibaba" title="Genzebe Dibaba">Genzebe Dibaba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tariku_Bekele" title="Tariku Bekele">Tariku Bekele</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gelete_Burka" title="Gelete Burka">Gelete Burka</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Yomif_Kejelcha" title="Yomif Kejelcha">Yomif Kejelcha</a>.
</p><p>As of 2012<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ethiopia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> and going into 2013, the current national <a href="/wiki/Ethiopia_national_football_team" title="Ethiopia national football team">Ethiopian national football team</a> (nicknamed the Walayia Antelopes) made history by qualifying for the <a href="/wiki/2012_Africa_Cup_of_Nations" title="2012 Africa Cup of Nations">2012 Africa Cup of Nations</a> and reached the last 10 African football teams in the last stage of <a href="/wiki/2014_FIFA_World_Cup_qualification_(CAF)" title="2014 FIFA World Cup qualification (CAF)">qualification for the 2014 FIFA World Cup</a>. Noted players include captain <a href="/wiki/Adane_Girma" title="Adane Girma">Adane Girma</a> and top scorer <a href="/wiki/Saladin_Said" title="Saladin Said">Saladin Said</a>.
</p><p>Ethiopia has Sub-Saharan Africa's longest basketball tradition as it established a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ethiopia_national_basketball_team" title="Ethiopia national basketball team">national basketball team</a> in 1949.
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Index_of_Ethiopia-related_articles" title="Index of Ethiopia-related articles">Index of Ethiopia-related articles</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Ethiopia" title="Outline of Ethiopia">Outline of Ethiopia</a></li>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>

<li id="cite_note-Mcdougall2005-50"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Mcdougall2005_50-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFMcdougallBrownFleagle2005">Mcdougall, I.; Brown, H.; Fleagle, G. "Stratigraphic placement and age of modern humans from Kibish, Ethiopia". <i>Nature</i>. <b>433</b> (7027): 733–36. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bibcode_(identifier)" title="Bibcode (identifier)">Bibcode</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2005Natur.433..733M" rel="nofollow">2005Natur.433..733M</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1038%2Fnature03258" rel="nofollow">10.1038/nature03258</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15716951" rel="nofollow">15716951</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a> <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:1454595" rel="nofollow">1454595</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Nature&amp;rft.atitle=Stratigraphic+placement+and+age+of+modern+humans+from+Kibish%2C+Ethiopia&amp;rft.volume=433&amp;rft.issue=7027&amp;rft.pages=733-36&amp;rft.date=2005-02&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1038%2Fnature03258&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A1454595%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F15716951&amp;rft_id=info%3Abibcode%2F2005Natur.433..733M&amp;rft.aulast=Mcdougall&amp;rft.aufirst=I.&amp;rft.au=Brown%2C+H.&amp;rft.au=Fleagle%2C+G.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEthiopia"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-61"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-61">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFSmith2019">Smith, Kiona N. <li id="cite_note-62"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-62">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFHistory2019">History, Charles Q. <li id="cite_note-:12-78"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-:12_78-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.worldhistory.org/Kingdom_of_Abyssinia/" rel="nofollow">"Kingdom of Abyssinia"</a>. <i>World History Encyclopedia</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-81"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-81">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The name "Menelik" is <a href="/wiki/Amharic" title="Amharic">Amharic</a> (a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Semitic_language" title="Semitic language">Semitic language</a> spoken in Ethiopia) in origin, and has two meanings:<a class="external autonumber" href="http://www.newKerala.com/baby-name/4260/menelik" rel="nofollow">[1]</a>
<ol><li>"Son of the wise man"</li>
<li>"What will he send?"</li></ol>
</span></li>

<li id="cite_note-berndl2005-104"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-berndl2005_104-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFBerndl2005">Berndl, Klaus (2005). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/nationalgeograph0000unse_m8x7/page/333/mode/2up" rel="nofollow"><i>National Geographic Visual History of the World</i></a>. National Geographic Society. p. 333. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7922-3695-5" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7922-3695-5"><bdi>978-0-7922-3695-5</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=National+Geographic+Visual+History+of+the+World&amp;rft.pages=333&amp;rft.pub=National+Geographic+Society&amp;rft.date=2005&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7922-3695-5&amp;rft.aulast=Berndl&amp;rft.aufirst=Klaus&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fnationalgeograph0000unse_m8x7%2Fpage%2F333%2Fmode%2F2up&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEthiopia"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-105"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-105">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See the discussion in Solomon Getamun, <i>History of the City of Gondar</i> (Africa World Press, 2005), pp.1–4</span>

<li id="cite_note-176"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-176">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6171429.stm" rel="nofollow">"Mengistu found guilty of genocide"</a>. <li id="cite_note-255"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-255">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The political history of the Ethiopian community, and their struggle for ownership of this small monastery, is retold in Chris Proutky, <i>Empress Taytu and Menelik II</i> (Trenton: The Red Sea Press, 1986), pp. 247–256</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-256"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-256">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Although Bahru Zewde, <i>A History of Modern Ethiopia</i>, second edition (Oxford: James Currey, 2001), believes that the Suez Canal brought strategic value to the Red Sea region (p. 73), Sven Rubenson, <i>The Survival of Ethiopian Independence</i> (Hollywood: Tsehai,1991) argues that only with the Mahdi War did the United Kingdom interest themselves once again in Ethiopia (pp. 283ff).</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-289"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-289">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFBaker2013">Baker, Katie (12 December 2013). <a class="external text" href="https://www.newsweek.com/graveyard-homosexuals-244926" rel="nofollow">"<span class="cs1-kern-left"></span>'A Graveyard for Homosexuals'<span class="cs1-kern-right"></span>"</a>. <i>Newsweek</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-290"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-290">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2014/4/11/ethiopia-groups-to-stage-anti-gay-protest" rel="nofollow">"Ethiopia groups to stage anti-gay protest"</a>. <i>www.aljazeera.com</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-291"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-291">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The number of adults (all were 18 to 64 years of age) surveyed in Ethiopia was 710, yielding a margin of error of 4 percent with a 95 percent confidence level.</span>

<li id="cite_note-325"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-325">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFWilkinDemissewWillisWoldeyes2019">Wilkin, Paul; Demissew, Sebsebe; Willis, Kathy; Woldeyes, Feleke; Davis, Aaron P.; Molla, Ermias L.; Janssens, Steven; Kallow, Simon; Berhanu, Admas (2019). <a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6526316" rel="nofollow">"Enset in Ethiopia: a poorly characterized but resilient starch staple"</a>. <i>Annals of Botany</i>. <b>123</b> (5): 747–766. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1093%2Faob%2Fmcy214" rel="nofollow">10.1093/aob/mcy214</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMC_(identifier)" title="PMC (identifier)">PMC</a> <span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6526316" rel="nofollow">6526316</a></span>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30715125" rel="nofollow">30715125</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Annals+of+Botany&amp;rft.atitle=Enset+in+Ethiopia%3A+a+poorly+characterized+but+resilient+starch+staple&amp;rft.volume=123&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.pages=747-766&amp;rft.date=2019&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC6526316%23id-name%3DPMC&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F30715125&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1093%2Faob%2Fmcy214&amp;rft.aulast=Wilkin&amp;rft.aufirst=Paul&amp;rft.au=Demissew%2C+Sebsebe&amp;rft.au=Willis%2C+Kathy&amp;rft.au=Woldeyes%2C+Feleke&amp;rft.au=Davis%2C+Aaron+P.&amp;rft.au=Molla%2C+Ermias+L.&amp;rft.au=Janssens%2C+Steven&amp;rft.au=Kallow%2C+Simon&amp;rft.au=Berhanu%2C+Admas&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC6526316&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEthiopia"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-333"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-333">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20070418195017/http://www.mg.co.za/articlePage.aspx?articleid=264689&amp;area=%2Fbreaking_news%2Fbreaking_news__business%2F" rel="nofollow">"Ethiopia's flower trade in full bloom"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Mail_%26_Guardian" title="Mail &amp; Guardian">Mail &amp; Guardian</a></i>. 19 February 2006. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">21 June</span> 2007</span>. <q>Floriculture has become a flourishing business in Ethiopia in the past five years, with the industry's exports earnings set to grow to $100-million by 2007, a five-fold increase on the $20-million earned in 2005. Ethiopian flower exports could generate an estimated $300-million within two to three years, according to the head of the government export-promotion department, Melaku Legesse.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Mail+%26+Guardian&amp;rft.atitle=Ethiopia%27s+flower+trade+in+full+bloom&amp;rft.date=2006-02-19&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mg.co.za%2FarticlePage.aspx%3Farticleid%3D264689%26area%3D%2Fbreaking_news%2Fbreaking_news__business%2F&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEthiopia"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-335"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-335">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFAverill2007">Averill, Victoria (31 May 2007). <a class="external text" href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/6703551.stm" rel="nofollow">"Ethiopia's designs on leather trade"</a>. <li id="cite_note-AKH-342"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-AKH_342-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20170802170326/http://akhrailway.com/index.php/about-project/project-summary" rel="nofollow">"Project Summary"</a>. AKH Project owners. January 2017. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">13 August</span> 2017</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.btitle=Project+Summary&amp;rft.pub=AKH+Project+owners&amp;rft.date=2017-01&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fakhrailway.com%2Findex.php%2Fabout-project%2Fproject-summary&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEthiopia"></span></span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-bx-377"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-bx_377-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-bx_377-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1" id="CITEREFAbegaz2005">Abegaz, Berhanu (1 June 2005). <a class="external text" href="http://bxabeg.people.wm.edu/Ethiopia.Census%20Portrait.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Ethiopia: A Model Nation of Minorities"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span><span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>

<li id="cite_note-419"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-419">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" </li>
<li id="cite_note-420"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-420">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFMilkias1976">Milkias, Paulos (1976). <a class="external text" href="https://www.jstor.org/stable/523876" rel="nofollow">"Traditional Institutions and Traditional Elites: The Role of Education in the Ethiopian Body-Politic"</a>. <i>African Studies Review</i>. <b>19</b> (3): 79–93. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.2307%2F523876" rel="nofollow">10.2307/523876</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/JSTOR_(identifier)" title="JSTOR (identifier)">JSTOR</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.jstor.org/stable/523876" rel="nofollow">523876</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a> <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:143199784" rel="nofollow">143199784</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-454"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-454">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="https://www.wipo.int/global_innovation_index/en/2021/" rel="nofollow">"Global Innovation Index 2021"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/World_Intellectual_Property_Organization" title="World Intellectual Property Organization">World Intellectual Property Organization</a></i>. <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a><span class="reference-accessdate">. </li>
<li id="cite_note-Abdullahi-455"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Abdullahi_455-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFAbdullahi2001">Abdullahi, Mohamed Diriye (2001). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=2Nu918tYMB8C&amp;pg=PA170" rel="nofollow"><i>Culture and Customs of Somalia</i></a>. Greenwood Publishing Group. p. 170. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-313-31333-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-313-31333-2"><bdi>978-0-313-31333-2</bdi></a>. <q>Somali music, a unique kind of music that might be mistaken at first for music from nearby countries such as Ethiopia, the Sudan, or even Arabia, can be recognized by its own tunes and styles.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Culture+and+Customs+of+Somalia&amp;rft.pages=170&amp;rft.pub=Greenwood+Publishing+Group&amp;rft.date=2001&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-313-31333-2&amp;rft.aulast=Abdullahi&amp;rft.aufirst=Mohamed+Diriye&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D2Nu918tYMB8C%26pg%3DPA170&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEthiopia"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Tekle-456"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Tekle_456-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="CITEREFTekle1994">Tekle, Amare (1994). <a class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=xbQTEF0rd7wC&amp;pg=PA197" rel="nofollow"><i>Eritrea and Ethiopia: from conflict to cooperation</i></a>. The Red Sea Press. p. 197. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-932415-97-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-932415-97-4"><bdi>978-0-932415-97-4</bdi></a>. <q>Djibouti, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Somalia and Sudan have significant similarities emanating not only from culture, religion, traditions, history and aspirations ... They appreciate similar foods and spices, beverages and sweets, fabrics and tapestry, lyrics and music, and jewellery and fragrances.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Eritrea+and+Ethiopia%3A+from+conflict+to+cooperation&amp;rft.pages=197&amp;rft.pub=The+Red+Sea+Press&amp;rft.date=1994&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-932415-97-4&amp;rft.aulast=Tekle&amp;rft.aufirst=Amare&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DxbQTEF0rd7wC%26pg%3DPA197&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEthiopia"></span></span>
</li>

The Red Sea Press. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780932415196" title="Special:BookSources/9780932415196"><bdi>9780932415196</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=The+Ethiopian+Borderlands%3A+Essays+in+Regional+History+from+Ancient+Times+to+the+End+of+the+18th+Century&amp;rft.pub=The+Red+Sea+Press&amp;rft.date=1997&amp;rft.isbn=9780932415196&amp;rft.aulast=Pankhurst&amp;rft.aufirst=Richard&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DzpYBD3bzW1wC&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEthiopia"></span></li>
<li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation book cs1" id="Valdes_Vivo">Valdes Vivo, Raul (1977). <i>Ethiopia's Revolution</i>. New York, NY: International Publishers. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a> <a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-7178-0556-3" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-7178-0556-3"><bdi>978-0-7178-0556-3</bdi></a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Ethiopia%27s+Revolution&amp;rft.place=New+York%2C+NY&amp;rft.pub=International+Publishers&amp;rft.date=1977&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-7178-0556-3&amp;rft.au=Valdes+Vivo%2C+Raul&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEthiopia"></span></li></ul>
</div>

<div class="navbox-styles nomobile"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1061467846" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/></div><div aria-labelledby="Kingdoms_and_dynasties_of_the_medieval_Horn_of_Africa" class="navbox" role="navigation" style="padding:3px"><table class="nowraplinks hlist mw-collapsible mw-collapsed navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit"><tbody><tr><th class="navbox-title" colspan="2" scope="col"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1063604349" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Medieval_Horn_of_Africa" title="Template:Medieval Horn of Africa"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Medieval_Horn_of_Africa" title="Template talk:Medieval Horn of Africa"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Medieval_Horn_of_Africa&amp;action=edit"><abbr style=";;background:none transparent;border:none;box-shadow:none;padding:0;" title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div><div id="Kingdoms_and_dynasties_of_the_medieval_Horn_of_Africa" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em">Kingdoms and dynasties of the medieval <a href="/wiki/Horn_of_Africa" title="Horn of Africa">Horn of Africa</a></div></th></tr><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%">States</th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em"></div><table class="nowraplinks navbox-subgroup" style="border-spacing:0"><tbody><tr><th class="navbox-group" scope="row" style="width:1%;padding-left:0.5em;padding-right:0.5em;font-weight:normal;">Islamic sultanates &amp; Empires</th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Adal_Sultanate" title="Adal Sultanate">Adal</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ajuran_Empire" title="Ajuran Empire">Ajuran</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Imamate_of_Aussa" title="Imamate of Aussa">Aussa Imamate</a></li>
